@@ -28,4 +28,6 @@
 
 In 1990, PIJ moved to the [[Syria]]n capital, [[Damascus]], where it continues to be based, with offices in [[Beirut]], [[Tehran]], and [[Khartoum]]. Its financial backing is believed to come from Syria and [[Iran]]. PIJ has much in common with [[Hamas]], with both fighting against the existence of the State of Israel. Both groups were formed as offshoots of the Muslim Brotherhood and receive a large amount of funding from [[Iran]]. With similar goals, Hamas and PIJ have worked together on a number of projects. PIJ has Sunni members only, promotes Islamism and Sharia law and fights to establish an Islamic state. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} 
+
+PIJ masterminded several [[suicide bombing]]s in Israel.<ref name=hjournal>{{cite news |title=Palestinians swear revenge for assassination |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JbceAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VM8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5403,3041425&hl=en |newspaper=Herald Journal |date=28 October 1995 |location=Gaza City |accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> Shaqaqi was a key player in setting up the National Alliance in January 1994, a coalition of eight PLO groups, Islamic Jihad and Hamas rejecting the [[Oslo process]].<ref name="JVLib"/> PIJ is considered by Israel to be the most extreme organization in its operational methods and commitment to the destruction of Israel.<ref name="ReichGoldberg">{{cite book |last1=Reich |first1=Bernard |last2=Goldberg |first2=David H. |date=2008 |title=Historical Dictionary of Israel |url=http://books.google.co.il/books?id=Mf-xAAAAQBAJ |location= |publisher=Scarecrow Press |page=373-375 |isbn=0-3133-2485-9 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> By 1995 PIJ was, according to Fisk, "perhaps the fiercest of all Israel's modern-day enemies."<ref name="Fisk">{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/the-doctor-who-finds-death-a-laughing-matter-1570442.html |title=The doctor who finds death a laughing matter |last1=Fisk |first1=Robert |last2= |first2= |date=30 January 1995 |website= |publisher=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=31 April 2013}}</ref> Shaqaqi was assassinated in 1995, and [[Ramadan Shalah]] became secretary-general of the organisation. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} 
 
 On February 20, 2003, [[University of South Florida]] [[computer engineering]] professor [[Sami Al-Arian]] was arrested after being indicted on a terrorism-related charge. [[United States Attorney General|U.S.&nbsp;Attorney General]] [[John Ashcroft]] alleged at a [[press conference]] that Al-Arian was the [[North American]]  head of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad. On December 6, 2006, Sami Al-Arian was sentenced to 57&nbsp;months in prison, pursuant to a [[plea bargain]].<ref>''[[St. Petersberg Times]]'', April 23, 2006.</ref> In November 2006 he was found guilty of civil contempt for refusing to testify before a federal [[grand jury]] and served 21&nbsp;months in prison on that conviction. On June 27, 2014, the US Federal Government dropped all charges against Al-Arian.<ref>"Details and Statements On Federal Court Dismissing All Charges Against Sami Al-Arian," Jadaliyya, June 27, 2014. http://interviews.jadaliyya.com/pages/index/18297/details-and-statements-on-federal-court-dismissing</ref>
@@ -33,5 +35,5 @@
 Islamic Jihad is alleged to have used minors. On March 29, 2004, 15-year-old Tamer Khuweir of [[Rifidia]], a suburb of Palestinian city [[Nablus]] in the [[West Bank]], was captured by Israeli forces as he planned to carry out a suicide mission. His older brother claimed he was brainwashed and demanded the [[Palestinian Authority]] investigate the incident and arrest those responsible for it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brother slams Palestinian militants for luring teenager into suicide mission|url=http://astandforjustice.org/2004/3/3-30-3.htm|accessdate=5 September 2014|agency=AFP|publisher=Yahoo News|date=30 March 2004}}</ref>
 
-PIJ masterminded several [[suicide bombing]]s in Israel.<ref name=hjournal>{{cite news |title=Palestinians swear revenge for assassination |url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JbceAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VM8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5403,3041425&hl=en |newspaper=Herald Journal |date=28 October 1995 |location=Gaza City |accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> Shaqaqi was a key player in setting up the National Alliance in January 1994, a coalition of eight PLO groups, Islamic Jihad and Hamas rejecting the [[Oslo process]].<ref name="JVLib"/> PIJ is considered by Israel to be the most extreme organization in its operational methods and commitment to the destruction of Israel.<ref name="ReichGoldberg">{{cite book |last1=Reich |first1=Bernard |last2=Goldberg |first2=David H. |date=2008 |title=Historical Dictionary of Israel |url=http://books.google.co.il/books?id=Mf-xAAAAQBAJ |location= |publisher=Scarecrow Press |page=373-375 |isbn=0-3133-2485-9 |accessdate=10 March 2011}}</ref> By 1995 PIJ was, according to Fisk, "perhaps the fiercest of all Israel's modern-day enemies."<ref name="Fisk">{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/the-doctor-who-finds-death-a-laughing-matter-1570442.html |title=The doctor who finds death a laughing matter |last1=Fisk |first1=Robert |last2= |first2= |date=30 January 1995 |website= |publisher=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=31 April 2013}}</ref> Shaqaqi was assassinated in 1995, and [[Ramadan Shalah]] became secretary-general of PIJ. {{Citation needed|date=July 2014}} Following further terrorist attacks on civilians in Israel, in 2006, Shalah and Awda were added to the United States [[FBI Most Wanted Terrorists]] list.<ref>[http://www.fbi.gov/wanted/wanted_terrorists/abd-al-aziz-awda FBI Most Wanted Terrorists]</ref>

@@ -42,5 +42,5 @@
 On October 13, the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women (UN-Women) equated the brutalities of Hamas with Israel's military response.<ref name=":8" /> Similarly, CEDAW was criticized for its silence on the violence committed by [[Hamas]].<sup>[33]</sup> The international [[MeToo movement|#MeToo movement]] also remained silent.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rosenberg |first=Michelle |title=#MeToo Unless Ur A Jew: The activists highlighting Hamas' sexual violence |url=https://www.jewishnews.co.uk/meet-the-activists-highlighting-sexual-violence-during-hamas-attacks-2/ |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=www.jewishnews.co.uk |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":8" /><ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-11-14 |title='Where are you?' - Israeli hostage families urge women's groups to speak up |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/where-are-you-israeli-hostage-families-urge-womens-groups-speak-up-2023-11-13/ |access-date=2023-11-30}}</ref><ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-23 |title=Crimes sexuels du Hamas en Israël : l’inquiétant silence des organisations internationales |url=https://www.lepoint.fr/monde/crimes-sexuels-du-hamas-en-israel-l-inquietant-silence-des-organisations-internationales-23-11-2023-2544251_24.php |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=Le Point |language=fr}}</ref>
 
-On November 28, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres stated that there are numerous accounts of sexual violence during the October 7 attack. These crimes, he said, must be vigorously investigated and prosecuted.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-30 |title=Guterres: 'Accounts of sexual violence on Oct. 7 must be investigated' |url=https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-775770 |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-29 |title=Reporting on Resolution 2712 (2023) Implementation, Secretary-General Warns Security Council People of Gaza in Midst of Epic Humanitarian Catastrophe  {{!}} ReliefWeb |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/reporting-resolution-2712-2023-implementation-secretary-general-warns-security-council-people-gaza-midst-epic-humanitarian-catastrophe |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=reliefweb.int |language=en}}</ref> A UN commission of inquiry investigating war crimes will specifically focus on instances of sexual violence by Hamas.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Farge |first=Emma |date=2023-11-29 |title=UN commission to investigate Hamas sexual violence, appeal for evidence |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/un-commission-investigate-hamas-sexual-violence-appeal-evidence-2023-11-29/ |access-date=2023-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-30 |title=Гутерриш признал доказательства сексуального насилия со стороны ХАМАСа |url=https://www.newsru.co.il/world/30nov2023/g_105.html |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=NEWSru.co.il |language=ru}}</ref>
+On November 28, UN Secretary-General [[António Guterres|Antonio Guterres]] stated that there are numerous accounts of sexual violence during the October 7 attack. These crimes, he said, must be vigorously investigated and prosecuted.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-30 |title=Guterres: 'Accounts of sexual violence on Oct. 7 must be investigated' |url=https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-775770 |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=The Jerusalem Post {{!}} JPost.com |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-29 |title=Reporting on Resolution 2712 (2023) Implementation, Secretary-General Warns Security Council People of Gaza in Midst of Epic Humanitarian Catastrophe  {{!}} ReliefWeb |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/reporting-resolution-2712-2023-implementation-secretary-general-warns-security-council-people-gaza-midst-epic-humanitarian-catastrophe |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=reliefweb.int |language=en}}</ref> A UN commission of inquiry investigating war crimes will specifically focus on instances of sexual violence by Hamas.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Farge |first=Emma |date=2023-11-29 |title=UN commission to investigate Hamas sexual violence, appeal for evidence |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/un-commission-investigate-hamas-sexual-violence-appeal-evidence-2023-11-29/ |access-date=2023-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-30 |title=Гутерриш признал доказательства сексуального насилия со стороны ХАМАСа |url=https://www.newsru.co.il/world/30nov2023/g_105.html |access-date=2023-11-30 |website=NEWSru.co.il |language=ru}}</ref>

 ====UN and the Palestinian state====
 {{main|International recognition of the State of Palestine}}
-The PLO have [[Palestine 194|campaigned]] for full member status for the state of Palestine at the UN and for recognition on the 1967 borders. A campaign that has received widespread support,<ref name="almasry">{{cite news|author=Staff writers |title=Israeli minister says Palestinians losing UN bid |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/478436 |date=18 July 2011 |newspaper=Almasry Alyoum |access-date=1 September 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20121210033454/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/478436 |archive-date=10 December 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Ravid, Barak|title=UN envoy Prosor: Israel has no chance of stopping recognition of Palestinian state|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/un-envoy-prosor-israel-has-no-chance-of-stopping-recognition-of-palestinian-state-1.381062|date=28 August 2011|newspaper=Haaretz|access-date=31 August 2011}}</ref> though it has been criticised by the US and Israel for allegedly avoiding bilateral negotiation.<ref>{{cite news|title=US to 'adamantly object' PA's UN bid|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4121506,00.html|work=ynetnetws.com|access-date=15 September 2018|date=2011-09-13|last1=Benhorin |first1=Yitzhak }}</ref><ref>{{cite |access-date=24 June 2014}}</ref> Netanyahu has criticized the Palestinians of purportedly trying to bypass direct talks,<ref>{{cite news|title=Netanyahu: PA attempt to become a permanent UN member will fail|newspaper=Ynetnews |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4123628,00.html|publisher=Ynet News|access-date=18 September 2011|date=2011-09-18|last1=Medzini |first1=Ronen }}</ref> web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2014/12/30/world/palestinian-statehood-draft-vote/index.html|title=Security Council rejects Palestinian statehood resolution|work=CNN|date=31 December 2014|access-date=2018-11-14}}</ref> in late 2012 the [[UN General Assembly]] overwhelmingly approved the ''de facto'' recognition of sovereign Palestine by granting non-member state status.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-palestinians-statehood-idUSBRE8AR0EG20121129|title=Palestinians win implicit U.N. recognition of sovereign state|date=29 November 2012|work=Reuters |access-date=29 November 2012}}</ref>
+The PLO have [[Palestine 194|campaigned]] for full member status for the state of Palestine at the UN and for recognition on the 1967 borders. The campaign has received widespread support,<ref name="almasry">{{cite news|author=Staff writers |title=Israeli minister says Palestinians losing UN bid |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/478436 |date=18 July 2011 |newspaper=Almasry Alyoum |access-date=1 September 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20121210033454/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/478436 |archive-date=10 December 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Ravid, Barak|title=UN envoy Prosor: Israel has no chance of stopping recognition of Palestinian August 2011}}</ref> although it has been criticised by the US and Israel for allegedly avoiding bilateral negotiation.<ref>{{cite news| title=US to 'adamantly object' PA's UN bid|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4121506,00.html| work=ynetnetws.com|access-date=15 September 2018|date=2011-09-13|last1=Benhorin |first1=Yitzhak }}</ref><ref>{{cite |access-date=24 June 2014}}</ref> Netanyahu has criticized the Palestinians of purportedly trying to bypass direct talks,<ref>{{cite news| title=Netanyahu: PA attempt to become a permanent UN member will fail|newspaper=Ynetnews |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4123628,00.html|publisher=Ynet News|access-date=18 September 2011|date=2011-09-18|last1=Medzini |first1=Ronen }}</ref> whereas Abbas has argued that the continued construction of Israeli-Jewish settlements is "undermining the realistic potential" for the two-state solution.<ref>{{cite news|title=Abbas defies US with formal call for Palestinian recognition by UN|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/23/abbas-call-palestinian-recognition-un?intcmp=239|work=The Guardian|access-date=23 September 2011|location=London| first=Chris|last=McGreal|date=23 September 2011}}</ref> Although Palestine has been denied full member status by the UN [[Security Council]],<ref>{{cite web| url=https://edition.cnn.com/2014/12/30/world/palestinian-statehood-draft-vote/index.html| title=Security Council rejects Palestinian statehood resolution|work=CNN|date=31 December 2014|access-date=2018-11-14}}</ref> in late 2012 the [[UN General Assembly]] overwhelmingly approved the ''de facto'' recognition of sovereign Palestine by granting non-member state status.<ref>{{cite @@ -39,7 +39,7 @@
 Ahli Arab Hospital, in operation since 1882, was founded by the [[Church of England]]'s [[Church Mission Society]].<ref name="PaulsenEpiscopal">{{Cite web |last=Paulsen |first=David |date=16 October 2023 |title=Anglican hospital among facilities struggling to respond to growing humanitarian crisis in Gaza |url=https://www.episcopalnewsservice.org/2023/10/16/anglican-hospital-among-facilities-struggling-to-respond-to-growing-humanitarian-crisis-in-gaza/ |access-date=17 October 2023 |website=Episcopal News Service |language=en-US |archive-date=17 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017003044/https://www.episcopalnewsservice.org/2023/10/16/anglican-hospital-among-facilities-struggling-to-respond-to-growing-humanitarian-crisis-in-gaza/ |url-status=live}}</ref> It was managed by the [[Anglican Diocese of Jerusalem]] and had about 80 beds.<ref name=Boorstein>{{cite news|last1=Boorstein|first1=Michelle |last2=Brasch |first2=Ben |title=Bombed Gaza hospital owned by a branch of the Anglican Communion|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/10/17/israel-hamas-gaza-hospital-anglican-church/|newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=18 October 2023 |archive-date=18 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018013024/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/10/17/israel-hamas-gaza-hospital-anglican-church/ |url-status=live}}</ref> It was the only Christian hospital in the Gaza Strip.<ref name="WSJWhatWeKnow">{{Cite web |last=Ackerman |first=Andrew |date=17 October 2023 |title=What We Know About the Gaza Hospital Blast|url=https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/what-we-know-about-the-gaza-hospital-blast-b238a40d |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018022743/https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/what-we-know-about-the-gaza-hospital-blast-b238a40d |archive-date=18 October 2023 |access-date= |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |language=}}</ref>
 
-On Saturday 14 October, according to a statement by the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Justin Welby]], Israeli rocket fire damaged two upper floors of the hospital, leaving four staff members injured.<ref name="anglicannews">{{Cite web|url=https://www.anglicannews.org/news/2023/10/anglican-run-al-ahli-arab-hospital-in-gaza-damaged-by-israeli-rocket-fire-as-conflict-continues.aspx |title=Anglican-run al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza damaged by Israeli rocket fire as war continues |date=16 October 2023|website=Anglican Communication News Service |publisher=The Anglican Church|access-date=19 October 2023 |archive-date=19 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231019062350/https://www.anglicannews.org/news/2023/10/anglican-run-al-ahli-arab-hospital-in-gaza-damaged-by-israeli-rocket-fire-as-conflict-continues.aspx |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Boorstein" /><ref name="archbishopofcanterbury">{{Cite web |title=Gaza hospitals are 'facing catastrophe', says Archbishop of Canterbury|url=https://www.archbishopofcanterbury.org/news/news-and-statements/gaza-hospitals-are-facing-catastrophe-says-archbishop-canterbury |access-date=17 October 2023 |website=The Archbishop of Canterbury|language=en|archive-date=17 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017193812/https://www.archbishopofcanterbury.org/news/news-and-statements/gaza-hospitals-are-facing-catastrophe-says-archbishop-canterbury|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="GuardianLiveBlog">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/oct/18/israel-hamas-war-live-news-gaza-hospital-west-bank-update-joe-biden-visit-protests-latest-updates?page=with:block-652fe3078f08785dda7ef645#block-652fe3078f08785dda7ef645 |title=Israel-Hamas war live: Hospital blast 'done by other team', says Biden, after Israel claims it has proof of failed rocket launch within Gaza &#124; Israel-Hamas war &#124; the Guardian |website=[[TheGuardian.com]] |access-date=18 October 2023 |archive-date=18 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018145128/https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/oct/18/israel-hamas-war-live-news-gaza-hospital-west-bank-update-joe-biden-visit-protests-latest-updates?page=with:block-652fe3078f08785dda7ef645#block-652fe3078f08785dda7ef645 |url-status=live}}</ref> The damage to the uppermost floors of the facility specifically impacted the Ultrasound and Mammography wards.<ref name="Episcopal Charity">{{cite web |title=AHLI HOSPITAL STRUCK BY ROCKET FIRE. October 15, 2023 |url=https://afedj.org/ahli-hospital-struck-by-rocket-fire/ |website=American Friends of the Episcopal Diocese of Jerusalem |access-date=25 October 2023 |date=15 October 2023}}</ref> The damaged area included the Diagnostic Cancer Treatment Centre<!-- "Diagnostic Cancer Treatment Centre" is strangely worded, but exactly as stated in the reference -->, which was described as the "Crown Jewel of Ahli Hospital" by the [[Anglican Archbishop of Jerusalem]], before the damage it provided cancer diagnosis as a prelude to treatment options at Ahli and other hospitals.<ref name="anglicannews" /> <!-- was this warning before the damage to upper floors? -->The [[Anglican Diocese of Jerusalem]] stated the hospital had received at least three evacuation warnings from the Israeli military on Saturday, Sunday, and Monday.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Abdulrahim |first1=Raja |last2=Yazbek |first2=Hiba |last3=Al-Hlou |first3=Yousur |title=A Sudden Blast, Then Carnage in a Hospital Courtyard|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/18/world/middleeast/gaza-hospital-deaths-aftermath.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=21 October 2023 |archive-date=18 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018131622/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/18/world/middleeast/gaza-hospital-deaths-aftermath.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
+On Saturday 14 October, according to a statement by the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Justin Welby]], Israeli rocket fire damaged two upper floors of the hospital, leaving four staff members injured.<ref name="anglicannews">{{Cite web|url=https://www.anglicannews.org/news/2023/10/anglican-run-al-ahli-arab-hospital-in-gaza-damaged-by-israeli-rocket-fire-as-conflict-continues.aspx |title=Anglican-run al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza damaged by Israeli rocket fire as war continues |date=16 October 2023|website=Anglican Communication News Service |publisher=The Anglican Church|access-date=19 October 2023 |archive-date=19 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231019062350/https://www.anglicannews.org/news/2023/10/anglican-run-al-ahli-arab-hospital-in-gaza-damaged-by-israeli-rocket-fire-as-conflict-continues.aspx |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Boorstein" /><ref name="archbishopofcanterbury">{{Cite web |title=Gaza hospitals are 'facing catastrophe', says Archbishop of Canterbury|url=https://www.archbishopofcanterbury.org/news/news-and-statements/gaza-hospitals-are-facing-catastrophe-says-archbishop-canterbury |access-date=17 October 2023 |website=The Archbishop of Canterbury|language=en|archive-date=17 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017193812/https://www.archbishopofcanterbury.org/news/news-and-statements/gaza-hospitals-are-facing-catastrophe-says-archbishop-canterbury|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="GuardianLiveBlog">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/oct/18/israel-hamas-war-live-news-gaza-hospital-west-bank-update-joe-biden-visit-protests-latest-updates?page=with:block-652fe3078f08785dda7ef645#block-652fe3078f08785dda7ef645 |title=Israel-Hamas war live: Hospital blast 'done by other team', says Biden, after Israel claims it has proof of failed rocket launch within Gaza &#124; @@ -17,9 +17,9 @@
 ===Failed Northern Pass initiative===
 {{cleanup|section|reason=needs to be shifted into the past tense|date=May 2020}}
-In December 2008, [[Hydro-Québec]], along with American utilities [[Eversource Energy|Northeast Utilities]] (parent company of Public Service of New Hampshire) and [[NSTAR (company)|NSTAR]] (parent company of Boston Edison), created a joint venture to build a new HVDC line from [[Windsor, Quebec]] to [[Deerfield, New Hampshire]], with an HVDC converter terminal built in [[Franklin, New Hampshire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northernpass.us/route_information.html |author=Northern Pass Transmission |title=Route Information |publisher=Northern Pass Transmission LLC |year=2010 |access-date=2010-10-13 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220225647/http://northernpass.us/route_information.html |archive-date=December 20, 2010 }}</ref> Hydro-Québec will own the segment within Quebec, while the segment within the US will be owned by ''Northern Pass Transmission LLC'', a partnership between Northeast Utilities (75%) and NSTAR (25%).<ref>{{cite news|date=2010-10-05 |first=Kyle |last=Alspach |title=NStar to build hydro power line |work=Boston Business Journal |url=http://boston.bizjournals.com/boston/stories/2010/10/04/daily23.html |access-date=2010-10-12}}</ref> Estimated to cost US$1.1 billion to build,<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Dillon |title=New Transmission Line Reaches Milestone |work=Vermont Public Radio |date=2010-10-08|url=http://www.vpr.net/news_detail/88975/ |access-date=2010-10-12 }}</ref> it is projected that the line will either run in existing right-of-way adjacent to the HVDC line that runs through New Hampshire, or it will connect to a right-of-way in northern New Hampshire that will run through the [[White Mountains (New Hampshire)|White Mountains]]. This {{convert|180|to|190|mi|adj=on}} line, projected to carry 1,200 megawatts, will bring electricity to approximately one million homes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rutlandherald.com/article/20081219/NEWS03/812190315/1004/NEWS03 |title=Utilities plan for N.E. expansion |work=Rutland Herald |first=Louis |last=Porter |date=19 December 2008 |access-date=2009-05-09 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090615232130/http://www.rutlandherald.com/article/20081219/NEWS03/812190315/1004/NEWS03 |archive-date=15 June 2009 }}</ref>
+In December 2008, [[Hydro-Québec]], along with American utilities [[Eversource Energy|Northeast Utilities]] (parent company of Public Service of New Hampshire) and [[NSTAR (company)|NSTAR]] (parent company of Boston Edison), created a joint venture to build a new HVDC line from [[Windsor, Quebec]] to [[Deerfield, New Hampshire]], with an HVDC converter terminal built in [[Franklin, New Hampshire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northernpass.us/route_information.html |author=Northern Pass Transmission |title=Route Information |publisher=Northern Pass Transmission LLC |year=2010 |access-date=2010-10-13 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101220225647/http://northernpass.us/route_information.html |archive-date=December 20, 2010 }}</ref> Hydro-Québec will own the segment within Quebec, while the segment within the US will be owned by ''Northern Pass Transmission LLC'', a partnership between Northeast Utilities (75%) and NSTAR (25%).<ref>{{cite news|date=2010-10-05 |first=Kyle |last=Alspach |title=NStar to build hydro power line |work=Boston Business Journal |url=http://boston.bizjournals.com/boston/stories/2010/10/04/daily23.html |access-date=2010-10-12}}</ref> Estimated to cost US$1.1 billion to build,<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Dillon |title=New Transmission Line Reaches Milestone |work=Vermont Public Radio |date=2010-10-08|url=http://www.vpr.net/news_detail/88975/ |access-date=2010-10-12 }}</ref> it is projected that the line will either run in existing right-of-way adjacent to the HVDC line that runs through New Hampshire, or it will connect to a right-of-way in northern New Hampshire that will run through the [[White Mountains (New Hampshire)|White Mountains]]. This {{convert|180|to|190|mi|adj=on}} line, projected to carry 1,200 megawatts, will bring electricity to approximately one million homes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rutlandherald.com/article/20081219/NEWS03/812190315/1004/NEWS03 |title=Utilities plan for N.E. expansion |work=Rutland Herald |first=Louis |last=Porter |date=19 December 2008 |access-date=2009-05-09 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090615232130/http://www.rutlandherald.com/article/20081219/NEWS03/812190315/1004/NEWS03 |archive-date=15 June 2009 }}</ref>
 
-In order to go ahead, the project must receive regulatory approval in Quebec and the United States. The proposed transmission line could have been in operation in 2015.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kenny |last=Constant |title=Energy project unveiled; impact called 'staggering' |work=The Citizen of Laconia |location=Laconia, NH |date=2010-10-13 |url=https://www.fosters.com/article/20101013/GJNEWS02/710139923 <!-- originally url=http://www.citizen.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20101013/GJNEWS02/710139923/-1/CITNEWS flagged as deadlink in 2014; repaired 30 May 2020 -->|access-date=2010-10-13 }}</ref> According to Jim Robb, a senior executive from Northeast Utilities, [[New England]] could meet one third of its [[Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative]] commitments with the hydropower coming through this new power line alone.<ref>{{cite news|first=Rebecca |last=Penty |title=U.S. calls power line a landmark investment |work=[[Telegraph-Journal]] |date=2009-11-14 |location=Saint John, NB |page=C1 |url=http://telegraphjournal.canadaeast.com/front/article/856987 |access-date=2009-11-14 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408000521/http://telegraphjournal.canadaeast.com/front/article/856987 |archive-date=April 8, 2011 }}</ref>
+In order to go ahead, the project must receive regulatory approval in Quebec and the United States. The proposed transmission line could have been in operation in 2015.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kenny |last=Constant |title=Energy project unveiled; impact called 'staggering' |work=The Citizen of Laconia |location=Laconia, NH |date=2010-10-13 |url=https://www.fosters.com/article/20101013/GJNEWS02/710139923 <!-- originally url=http://www.citizen.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20101013/GJNEWS02/710139923/-1/CITNEWS flagged as deadlink in 2014; repaired 30 May 2020 -->|access-date=2010-10-13 }}</ref> According to Jim Robb, a senior executive from Northeast Utilities, [[New England]] could meet one third of its [[Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative]] commitments with the hydropower coming through this new power line alone.<ref>{{cite news|first=Rebecca |last=Penty |title=U.S. calls power line a landmark investment |work=[[Telegraph-Journal]] |date=2009-11-14 |location=Saint John, NB |page=C1 |url=http://telegraphjournal.canadaeast.com/front/article/856987 |access-date=2009-11-14 |url-status=dead |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110408000521/http://telegraphjournal.canadaeast.com/front/article/856987 |archive-date=April 8, 2011 }}</ref>
 
-In October 2010, Northeast Utilities announced that it would merge with NSTAR, with the resulting company initially retaining the Northeast Utilities name. The deal is subject to regulatory approval.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2010/10/northeast_utili_2.html|title=Archived copy|access-date=October 18, 2010|url-status=unfit|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101020234228/http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2010/10/northeast_utili_2.html|archive-date=October 20, 2010}}</ref> In effect, Northern Pass Transmission would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Northeast Utilities, which would be renamed [[Eversource Energy]] in 2015.
+In October 2010, Northeast Utilities announced that it would merge with NSTAR, with the resulting company initially retaining the Northeast Utilities name. The deal is subject to regulatory approval.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2010/10/northeast_utili_2.html |title=Archived copy|access-date=October 18, 2010|url-status=unfit|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20101020234228/http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2010/10/northeast_utili_2.html |archive-date=October 20, 2010}}</ref> In effect, Northern Pass Transmission would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Northeast Utilities, which would be renamed [[Eversource Energy]] in 2015.
 
 The purchase of power from Hydro-Québec was an issue during the [[2010 Massachusetts gubernatorial election|Massachusetts gubernatorial election of 2010]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Beth |last=Daley |title=Canadian firm offers N.E. more hydropower |work=Boston Globe |date=2010-10-23 |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2010/10/23/canadian_firm_offers_ne_more_hydropower/?page=full |access-date=2010-10-24}}</ref>
@@ -36,5 +36,6 @@
 }}</ref>
 
-Massachusetts is now pursuing a similar project that would bring Canadian hydropower through transmission lines in Maine. The proposed New England Clean Energy Connect is estimated to cost $1 billion.<ref name=whitetowel/>
+Construction of the ''New England Clean Energy Connect'', a similar project, started in February 2021.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wade |first1=Will |title=NextEra is blocking a major new clean power transmission project - BNN Bloomberg |url=https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/nextera-is-blocking-a-major-new-clean-power-transmission-project-1.1606296 |website=BNN |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20210522181502/https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/nextera-is-blocking-a-major-new-clean-power-transmission-project-1.1606296 |archive-date=2021-05-22 |date=2021-05-20 |url-status=live}}</ref>

@@ -24,5 +24,5 @@
 The special envoy of the Quartet [[James Wolfensohn]] said, "Gaza had been effectively sealed off from the outside world since the Israeli disengagement [August–September 2005], and the humanitarian and economic consequences for the Palestinian population were profound. There were already food shortages. Palestinian workers and traders to Israel were unable to cross the border".<ref>[[James Wolfensohn]] (2010). ''A Global Life''. p. 422-423</ref>
 
-On 15 January 2006, the Karni crossing - the sole point for exports of goods from Gaza - was closed completely for all kinds of exports.<ref>James Wolfensohn (2010). ''A Global Life''. p. 433</ref><ref name="un">https://www.un.org/unispal/document/auto-insert-195535/</ref> The greenhouse project suffered a huge blow, as the harvest of high-value crops, meant to be exported for Europe via Israel, was essentially lost (with a small part of the harvest donated to local institutions).<ref name="un"/><ref name="june">https://www.un.org/unispal/document/auto-insert-208409/</ref><ref name="bbc">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4818478.stm|title = Gaza farmers dumping their crops|date = 17 March 2006}}</ref> Moreover, closing of Karni cut off the so-far resilient textile and furniture industries in Gaza from their source of income.<ref name="Wolfensohn, James 2010 p. 430"/> Starting February 2006, the Karni crossing was sporadically open for exports, but the amount of goods allowed to be exported was minuscule compared to the amount of goods imported<ref name="daily"/> (which, in turn, barely supported Gaza's needs).<ref name="march">https://www.un.org/unispal/document/auto-insert-198269/</ref><ref name="daily"/> Between 1 January and 11 May, more than 12,700 tonnes of produce were harvested in Gaza's greenhouses, almost all of it destined for export; out of it, only 1,600 tonnes (less than 13%) were actually exported.<ref name="june"/>
+On 15 January 2006, the Karni crossing - the sole point for exports of goods from Gaza - was closed completely for all kinds of exports.<ref>James Wolfensohn (2010). ''A Global Life''. p. 433</ref><ref name="un">{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/unispal/document/auto-insert-195535/|title=Gaza Strip: Situation Report - Impact of Karni crossing closure (31 January 2006) - OCHA report}}</ref> The greenhouse project suffered a huge blow, as the harvest of high-value crops, meant to be exported for Europe via Israel, was essentially lost (with a small part of the harvest donated to local institutions).<ref name="un"/><ref name="june">{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/unispal/document/auto-insert-208409/|title=Gaza Strip: Situation Report (7 June 2006) - OCHA report}}</ref><ref name="bbc">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4818478.stm|title = Gaza farmers dumping their crops|date = 17 March 2006}}</ref> Moreover, closing of Karni cut off the so-far resilient textile and furniture industries in Gaza from their source of income.<ref name="Wolfensohn, James 2010 p. 430"/> Starting February 2006, the Karni crossing was sporadically open for exports, but the amount of goods allowed to be exported was minuscule compared to the amount of goods imported<ref name="daily"/> (which, in turn, barely supported Gaza's needs).<ref name="march">{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/unispal/document/auto-insert-198269/|title=Gaza Strip: Situation Report (29 March 2006) - OCHA report}}</ref><ref name="daily"/> Between 1 January and 11 May, more than 12,700 tonnes of produce were harvested in Gaza's greenhouses, almost all of it destined for export; out of it, only 1,600 tonnes (less than 13%) were actually exported.<ref name="june"/>
 
 ===Sanctions on Hamas-led PA governments===
@@ -31,5 +31,5 @@
 Besides Israel’s position in relation to a Hamas-led PA government, following the election, the [[Quartet on the Middle East]] had stated that continued aid to and dialogue with the PA under a Hamas government was conditional on Hamas agreeing to three conditions: recognition of Israel, the disavowal of violent actions, and acceptance of previous agreements between Israel and the PA, including the Oslo Accords. Haniya refused to accept these conditions, and the Quartet stopped all dialogue with the PA and especially any member of the Hamas government, ceased providing aid to the PA and imposed [[2006–07 economic sanctions against the Palestinian National Authority|sanctions against the PA under Hamas]].<ref>{{cite news |date=18 February 2006 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/18/international/middleeast/18mideast.html |title=''Hamas Leader Faults Israeli Sanction Plan'' |work=The New York Times |first=Steven |last=Erlanger |access-date=21 February 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204210833/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/02/18/international/middleeast/18mideast.html |archive-date=4 February 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> <ref name="John Pike">{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/hamas.htm|title=Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement) |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |access-date=27 May 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140909191643/http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/hamas.htm|archive-date=9 September 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> Though initially opposed by the United States, a Quartet member, the US government agreed in April 2006 to discontinue $400 million of [[foreign aid]] to the PA. Instead the US redirected $100 million to the United Nations and other non-Palestinian groups, but no aid money was given directly to the government of [[Mahmoud Abbas]].<ref>{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last1 = Weisman| first1 = Steven R.| last2 = Smith| first2 = Craig S.| title = U.S. and Europe Halt Aid to Palestinian Government| work = The New York Times| access-date = 2017-12-04| date = 2006-04-08| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/08/world/middleeast/08hamas.html| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180214060149/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/08/world/middleeast/08hamas.html| archive-date = 14 February 2018| url-status = live}}</ref>
 
-As noted by [[James Wolfensohn|Wolfensohn]] (and also in an [[European Union|EU]] paper), withholding of the PA's own tax revenue - an action taken by Israel alone, not by the Quartet - was more damaging than the ceasing of international aid to the PA. These taxes, collected in Palestine (both in the West Bank and Gaza) by Israeli authorities, were supposed to be transferred to the PA's budget. By releasing or withholding these revenues, Israel was able, in the words of the International Crisis Group, to "virtually turn the Palestinian economy on and off".<ref>James Wolfensohn, A Global Life, 2010, pp. 432-433</ref> Israel withheld these transfers from the PA until June 2007.<ref name=unctad-2015>[http://unctad.org/en/PublicationsLibrary/tdb62d3_en.pdf ''Report on UNCTAD assistance to the Palestinian people: Developments in the economy of the Occupied Palestinian Territory''], para 9-24. United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, 6 July 2015 (doc.nr. TD/B/62/3). [http://unctad.org/en/Pages/PressRelease.aspx?OriginalVersionID=260 Source]</ref><ref name=alhaq_seizure_of_tax>[http://www.alhaq.org/publications/publications-index?task=callelement&format=raw&item_id=111&element=304e4493-dc32-44fa-8c5b-57c4d7b529c1&method=download ''Israel’s retaliatory seizure of tax''], pp. 10-11. Al-Haq, 1 April 2015. [http://www.alhaq.org/advocacy/targets/accountability/81-general/908-israels-%20retaliatory-seizure-of-tax-a-war-crime-to-punish-palestinian-icc-membership Here available]</ref> Withholding the tax revenue by Israel meant that the PA lacked money to pay its employees, including the police, further destabilizing the situation in Gaza.<ref>https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2006/jun/02/palestinian-police-protest-lack-of-pay/</ref>
+As noted by [[James Wolfensohn|Wolfensohn]] (and also in an [[European Union|EU]] paper), withholding of the PA's own tax revenue - an action taken by Israel alone, not by the Quartet - was more damaging than the ceasing of international aid to the PA. These taxes, collected in Palestine (both in the West Bank and Gaza) by Israeli authorities, were supposed to be transferred to the PA's budget. By releasing or withholding these revenues, Israel was able, in the words of the International Crisis Group, to "virtually turn the Palestinian economy on and off".<ref>James Wolfensohn, A Global Life, 2010, pp. 432-433</ref> Israel withheld these transfers from the PA until June 2007.<ref name=unctad-2015>[http://unctad.org/en/PublicationsLibrary/tdb62d3_en.pdf ''Report on UNCTAD assistance to the Palestinian people: Developments in the economy of the Occupied Palestinian Territory''], para 9-24. United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, 6 July 2015 (doc.nr. TD/B/62/3). [http://unctad.org/en/Pages/PressRelease.aspx?OriginalVersionID=260 Source]</ref><ref name=alhaq_seizure_of_tax>[http://www.alhaq.org/publications/publications-index?task=callelement&format=raw&item_id=111&element=304e4493-dc32-44fa-8c5b-57c4d7b529c1&method=download ''Israel’s retaliatory seizure of tax''], pp. 10-11. Al-Haq, 1 April 2015. [http://www.alhaq.org/advocacy/targets/accountability/81-general/908-israels-%20retaliatory-seizure-of-tax-a-war-crime-to-punish-palestinian-icc-membership Here available]</ref> Withholding the tax revenue by Israel meant that the PA lacked money to pay its employees, including the police, further destabilizing the situation in Gaza.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.spokesman.com/stories/2006/jun/02/palestinian-police-protest-lack-of-pay/|title=Palestinian police protest lack of pay &#124; The Spokesman-Review|website=www.spokesman.com}}</ref>
 
 In March 2007, Fatah agreed to join Hamas in a [[Palestinian National Unity Government of March 2007|PA unity government]], also headed by Haniya. Shortly after, in June, Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the [[Battle of Gaza (2007)|Battle of Gaza]],<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news | title=Hamas takes control of Gaza | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/jun/15/israel4 | access-date=3 June 2010 | newspaper=The Guardian| date=15 June 2007 | location=London | first1=Ian | last1=Black | first2=Mark | last2=Tran | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130831134036/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/jun/15/israel4 | archive-date=31 August 2013 | url-status=live }}</ref> seizing PA government institutions in the Strip and replacing Fatah and other PA officials with Hamas members.<ref name="intern_fight_p14-15"/> 
@@ -46,12 +46,12 @@
 In 2016 most Palestinian parties welcomed Turkish initiatives to end the strict Israeli siege on the Gaza Strip by building a [[Gaza Seaport plans|seaport]] for the movement of people and goods. This step was condemned by Fatah and the PA, a senior Fatah leader saying that his movement would not allow this to happen, while the Fatah Executive Committee said this was an Israeli trick to separate Gaza from the West Bank. In turn a Hamas official condemned the PA's position; "This position proves that the PA is part of the Israeli-led siege which has been imposed on Gaza for ten years".<ref>[https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/24242-palestinian-factions-welcome-turkish-efforts-to-lift-gaza-siege ''Palestinian factions welcome Turkish efforts to lift Gaza siege''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307124636/https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/24242-palestinian-factions-welcome-turkish-efforts-to-lift-gaza-siege |date=7 March 2016 }}. MEMO, 1 March 2016</ref>

 ==Funding and aid==
-In 2017, the PA government imposed sanctions against the Hamas-ruled Gaza Strip, including ceasing to pay salaries to thousands of civil servants in Gaza, as well as financial assistance to families in the Gaza Strip. Since 2018, [[Qatar]] has been providing funding for Palestinians in Gaza. O. I.|last=staff|website=www.timesofisrael.com}}</ref> 
 
-After the 11-day Gaza War in May 2021, Israel stopped the Qatari money coming into Gaza out of concern that it would be diverted to Hamas for military purposes.<ref> [https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/un-to-handle-the-disbursement-of-the-qatari-money-in-gaza-672809 Bennett: No more suitcases of cash for Hamas in Gaza]</ref> In July 2021, it was reported that the United Nations had agreed to oversee the distribution of the Qatari money to Gazans through banks affiliated with the [[Palestinian Monetary Authority]] in Ramallah. Israel agreed to the arrangement on condition that none of the money is diverted to Hamas.<ref> [https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/un-to-handle-the-disbursement-of-the-qatari-money-in-gaza-672809 UN to handle the disbursement of the Qatari money in Gaza] </ref> However, as at 5 July, payment of Hamas salaries has delayed the resumption of the Qatari funding, because the channel for paying them is through the Palestinian Authority, which does not want to pay salaries to anyone affiliated with Hamas.<ref> [https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/payment-of-hamas-salaries-delays-qatar-funding-for-gaza-675996 Payment of Hamas salaries delays Qatar funding for Gaza] </ref> The PA banks are refusing to take part, fearing that their cooperation would expose them to legal actions for supporting and funding terrorism.<ref> [https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/gazan-incendiary-balloons-suspected-as-cause-for-kissufim-fire-676041 IDF attacks Hamas base, rocket launcher in response to balloon fires]</ref> On 19 August, the United Nations and Qatar signed an agreement for the resumption of Qatari cash payments to 100,000 needy Gazans.  Palestinians were invariably banned from traveling between Gaza and the West Bank. Following the [[Israeli disengagement from Gaza]] in September 2005, Israel "[established] a domestic legal framework apparently aimed at sealing off Gaza from Israel and from the West Bank"<ref name="gisha">https://www.gisha.org/UserFiles/File/publications_english/Disengagement_Danger_6feb_06.pdf</ref> Israel had previously agreed, as part of the Oslo Accords, to treat Gaza and the West Bank as a single territorial unit, a position upheld by the Israeli High Court.<ref name="gisha"/> However, following the 2005 disengagement, Israel adopted the position that Gaza residents have "no vested right" to cross into the West Bank; and that although there is "a certain connection" between the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, it "does not give Gaza residents a right to enter [the West Bank]".<ref name="gisha"/> Those Gaza residents who did not try to cross the territory of Israel proper, but instead traveled around it, using the "long and expensive" route via Egypt and Jordan to travel from Gaza to the West Bank, were still turned back by Israeli border personnel at the [[Allenby Bridge]] when attempting to enter the West Bank from Jordan.<ref name="gisha"/> This policy was still in place as of 2014: Gaza residents, except in rare "humanitarian" cases, are not allowed to enter the West Bank - even if they do not travel via Israel proper but around it, trying to enter via the [[Allenby Bridge]].<ref name="btselem">https://www.btselem.org/download/201401_so_near_and_yet_so_far_eng.pdf</ref>
 
-AMA stipulated the opening hours of crossings between Gaza and Israel and the number of trucks/truckloads to pass through them.<ref name="Wolfensohn, James 2010 p. 428-429">Wolfensohn, James (2010). Palestinian hospitals are unable to meet the need of their patients due to economic underdevelopment and the varying strictness of the Israeli blockade.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.who.int/hac/crises/international/wbgs/WHO_Initial_Health_Assessment_Report_Gaza_Strip_-_December_2012.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=16 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061645/http://www.who.int/hac/crises/international/wbgs/WHO_Initial_Health_Assessment_Report_Gaza_Strip_-_December_2012.pdf |archive-date=4 March 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> According to B'Tselem,[http://www.btselem.org/freedom_of_movement/economy] the blockade, which not only restricts Gazans' access to Israel but also communication between Gaza and the West Bank, has denied Gazan fishermen access to 85% of the waters they have been guaranteed access to.<ref>[[Palestinian freedom of movement]]</ref>
+According to the [[World Health Organization]], the shortage of essential medicines and equipment has been the primary obstacle to providing adequate health care in the Gaza Strip since the 2012 conflict.  Gazan hospitals had a shortage of more than 50% of "medical consumables" even before the conflict.  Workers in some hospitals reported having to sterilize and re-use single-use equipment due to the lack of critical items.  Palestinian hospitals are unable to meet the need of their patients due to economic underdevelopment and the varying strictness of the Israeli blockade.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.who.int/hac/crises/international/wbgs/WHO_Initial_Health_Assessment_Report_Gaza_Strip_-_December_2012.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=16 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061645/http://www.who.int/hac/crises/international/wbgs/WHO_Initial_Health_Assessment_Report_Gaza_Strip_-_December_2012.pdf |archive-date=4 March 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> According to B'Tselem,[http://www.btselem.org/freedom_of_movement/economy Restrictions on Movement] the blockade, which not only restricts Gazans' access to Israel but also communication between Gaza and the West Bank, has denied Gazan fishermen access to 85% of the waters they have been guaranteed access to.<ref>[[Palestinian freedom of movement]]</ref>
 
 During the [[2014 Israel-Gaza Conflict]], 108,000 people were displaced, almost all of whom are still living in UNWRA refugee camps or inadequate improvised shelters.  28 schools, numerous wells, and other important civil infrastructure like major sewage and electricity plants were destroyed during Operation Protective Edge.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2015/country-chapters/israel-and-palestine|title=World Report 2015: Israel/Palestine|date=11 January 2015|access-date=4 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715082137/http://www.hrw.org/world-report/2015/country-chapters/israel-and-palestine|archive-date=15 July 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> Since then over 2,000 truckloads of materials for reconstruction have been allowed into Gaza, but according to a UN estimate, 735 truckloads per day, for three years, would be necessary to rebuild all the damaged infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sf/world/2015/02/13/gaza-misery/|title=Half a year after devastating war, life in Gaza seems worse than ever.|access-date=24 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920195210/http://www.washingtonpost.com/sf/world/2015/02/13/gaza-misery/|archive-date=20 September 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

He said that despite the restrictions, UNRWA had been able to provide a basic food supply to over a million refugees in the Gaza Strip. He said that despite the restrictions, UNRWA had been able to provide a basic food supply to over a million refugees in the Gaza Strip. He added that he "visited a food station where hundreds of displaced persons waited to collect their meager staples of rice, sugar, lentils and cooking oil. While this program may save people from starvation, it is a diet that does not prevent the highest level of [[anemia]] in the region, with alarming rates of childhood stunting due to inadequate nutrition."<ref name=UNGazaReport>{{Cite web |url=https://www.un.org/ga/president/63/news/GazaReport.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=28 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170319185815/http://www.un.org/ga/president/63/news/GazaReport.pdf |archive-date=19 March 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
 The Palestinians who negotiated the 2008 cease-fire believed that commerce in Gaza was to be restored to the levels preceding Israel's 2005 withdrawal and Hamas's electoral victory.<ref name=revive>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/20/world/middleeast/20mideast.html?scp=2&sq=Ethan%20Bronner%20December%202008%20gaza&st=cse Gaza Truce May Be Revived by Necessity] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160722030124/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/20/world/middleeast/20mideast.html?scp=2&sq=Ethan%20Bronner%20December%202008%20gaza&st=cse |date=22 July 2016 }}. By Ethan Bronner. ''The New York Times''. Published 19 December 2008.</ref><ref name= nichols/> Israeli policy tied the easing of the blockade to success in reducing rocket fire.<ref name=bare>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7570605.stm Truce barely eases Gaza embargo] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128115531/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7570605.stm |date=28 January 2015 }}. By Aleem Maqbool. [[BBC News]]. Published 19 August 2008.</ref> Israel permitted a 20% increase in goods trucked into Gaza in the pre-lull period, up from 70 to 90 truckloads a day,<ref name=revive/> including not only humanitarian supplies but also clothes, shoes, refrigerators, and construction materials.<ref name=guide>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7545636.stm Guide: Gaza under blockade] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090128132819/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7545636.stm |date=28 January 2009 }}. By Heather Sharp. [[BBC News]]. Published 11 November 2008.</ref> Fuel supplies increased from 55[[megawatt|MW]] worth to 65[[megawatt|MW]] worth.<ref name=guide/> [[BBC News]] reported on 11 November that Gaza was then receiving only 28% of the amount of goods traded before the Hamas takeover.<ref name=guide/>

@@ -1,5 +1,5 @@
 {{pp-30-500|small=yes}}
 [[File:Israel and occupied territories map.png|thumb|right|300px]]
-The '''Israeli-occupied territories'''  is a political concept, referring to the territories [[Military occupation|occupied]] by [[Israel]] during the [[Six-Day War]] of 1967. Originally, those territories included the Syrian [[Golan Heights]], the Egyptian [[Sinai Peninsula]] and [[Occupation of the Gaza Strip by Egypt|Egyptian-occupied Gaza Strip]] and [[Jordanian annexation of the West Bank|Jordanian-annexed West Bank]]. The first use of the term 'territories occupied' was in [[United Nations Security Council]] [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 242|Resolution 242]] following the Six-Day War in 1967, which called for "the establishment of a just and lasting peace in the Middle East" to be achieved by "the application of both the following principles: ... Withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict ... Termination of all claims or states of belligerency" and respect for the right of every state in the area to live in peace within secure and recognized boundaries.
+The '''Israeli-occupied territories''' are the territories [[Military occupation|occupied]] by [[Israel]] during the [[Six-Day War]] of 1967. Originally, those territories included the Syrian [[Golan Heights]], the Egyptian [[Sinai Peninsula]] and [[Occupation of the Gaza Strip by Egypt|Egyptian-occupied Gaza Strip]] and [[Jordanian annexation of the West Bank|Jordanian-annexed West Bank]]. The first use of the term 'territories occupied' was in [[United Nations Security Council]] [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 242|Resolution 242]] following the Six-Day War in 1967, which called for "the establishment of a just and lasting peace in the Middle East" to be achieved by "the application of both the following principles: ... Withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict ... Termination of all claims or states of belligerency" and respect for the right of every state in the area to live in peace within secure and recognized boundaries.
 
 From 1967 to 1982, the four areas were governed under the [[Israeli Military Governorate]] (also named as ''Occupied Arab territories''{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} by the UN). The IMG was dissolved in 1982, after the [[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty]]. In the process, Israel handed the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt, the Golan Heights was incorporated into the [[Northern District (Israel)|Northern District]] by the [[Golan Heights Law]], and West Bank continued to be administrated via the [[Israeli Civil Administration]]. Despite dissolving the military government, in line with Egyptian demands, the term ''Israeli-occupied territories'' remains in use, referring to the [[West Bank]] including [[East Jerusalem]], the [[Gaza Strip]] and Western [[Golan Heights]]. Between 1998 and 2012, the term [[Palestinian territories, Occupied]] was used to refer to territories controlled by the [[Palestinian Authority]] in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

@@ -21,4 +21,9 @@
 == Blockade ==
 The total blockade of Gaza was announced on 9 October 2023 by the [[Defence Minister of Israel]], [[Yoav Gallant]]. “We are putting a complete siege on Gaza … No electricity, no food, no water, no gas – it’s all closed” he announced.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Israel Gaza live news: Israel orders 'siege' of Gaza with 'no electricity, food, or fuel' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/world-middle-east-67050350 |access-date=2023-10-09 |website=BBC News |language=en-gb |archive-date=9 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231009000434/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/world-middle-east-67050350 |url-status=live }}</ref> "We are fighting barbarians and will respond accordingly," he added.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-09 |title=Israeli Military Launches ‘Complete Siege’ of Gaza as Air Force Bombards Strip: ‘We Are Fighting Barbarians’ |url=https://www.nationalreview.com/news/israeli-military-launches-complete-siege-of-gaza-as-air-force-bombards-strip-we-are-fighting-barbarians/ |access-date=2023-10-10 |website=National Review |language=en-US |archive-date=10 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231010021126/https://www.nationalreview.com/news/israeli-military-launches-complete-siege-of-gaza-as-air-force-bombards-strip-we-are-fighting-barbarians/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=John |first=Hadas Gold,Eyad Kourdi,Jonny Hallam,Ibrahim Dahman,Helen Regan,Tara |date=2023-10-09 |title=Israeli defense minister orders 'complete siege' of Gaza, as Hamas threatens hostages |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/10/09/middleeast/israel-gaza-hamas-fighting-monday-intl-hnk/index.html |access-date=2023-10-10 |website=CNN |language=en |archive-date=10 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231010022921/https://www.cnn.com/2023/10/09/middleeast/israel-gaza-hamas-fighting-monday-intl-hnk/index.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=CNN |first=Hadas Gold, Eyad Kourdi, Jonny Hallam, Ibrahim Dahman, Helen Regan and Tara John |date=2023-10-09 |title=Israeli defense minister orders ‘complete siege’ of Gaza, as Hamas threatens hostages |url=https://www.albanyherald.com/news/israeli-defense-minister-orders-complete-siege-of-gaza-as-hamas-threatens-hostages/article_d6f313a1-fbf7-54e9-874c-7fdf569e5c11.html |access-date=2023-10-10 |website=Albany Herald |language=en}}</ref> The spokesman for the [[Ministry of Energy (Israel)|Minister of Energy of Israel]], [[Israel Katz]], said that Katz had ordered the water supply to Gaza to be cut, effective immediately.<ref>{{Cite web|first1=Ted|last1=Regencia|first2=Virginia|last2=Pietromarchi|first3=Umut|last3=Uras|first4=Edna|last4=Mohamed|first5=Dalia|last5=Hatuqa|title=Israel to impose ‘total Gaza blockade’, dozens killed in refugee camp hit|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/10/9/israel-hamas-war-live-news-gaza-under-non-stop-bombardment|access-date=2023-10-09|website=Al Jazeera|date=2023-10-09|language=en|archive-date=9 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231009081813/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/10/9/israel-hamas-war-live-news-gaza-under-non-stop-bombardment|url-status=live}}</ref> Israeli tanks and drones have been tasked with guarding openings in the Gaza–Israel border fence and enforcing the blockade.<ref name=":0" />
+
+==Reactions==
+The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights: "Blockage actions that endanger the lives of citizens by cutting off access to basic goods are prohibited under international humanitarian law; And if any restriction is not justified from the point of view of military necessity, it is an example of collective punishment.<ref>[https://www.alef.ir/news/4020718105.html United Nations: The blockade of Gaza is a violation of international law] </ref>
+
+UN Secretary-General: "Citizens in the Gaza Strip are in dire need of medical equipment and food." He asked all the involved parties to provide conditions to facilitate the delivery of relief and necessary supplies to the region.<ref>[https://www.independentpersian.com/node/363586 The Secretary-General of the United Nations expressed concern about the complete siege of the Gaza Strip.] independentpersian.com</ref>
 
 ==See also==

diffText:
@@ -412,5 +412,5 @@
 In 2015, Rav Aluf [[Gadi Eizenkot]] ordered the unit's closure in order to assimilate the Druze soldiers no differently than Jewish soldiers, as part of an ongoing reorganization of the army. Several Druze officers reached ranks as high as Major General, and many received commendations for distinguished service. In proportion to their numbers, the Druze people achieve much higher—documented—levels in the Israeli army than other soldiers. Nevertheless, some Druze still charge that discrimination continues, such as exclusion from the [[Israel Air Force|Air Force]], although the official low security classification for Druze has been abolished for some time. The first Druze aircraft navigator completed his training course in 2005. Like all air force pilots, his identity is not disclosed. During the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]], many Druze who had initially sided with the Arabs deserted their ranks to either return to their villages or side with Israel in various capacities.<ref name="Gelber">{{cite news |title= Druze and Jews in the war of 1948. (Israel-Arab War of 1948–49)|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-16921885.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070528194735/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-16921885.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=28 May 2007|author=Gelber, Yoav |date=1 April 1995|work=Middle Eastern Studies}}</ref>
 
-Since the late 1970s, the Druze Initiative Committee, centered at the village of [[Beit Jan]] and linked to [[Maki (political party)|Maki]], has campaigned to abolish Druze conscription.
+Since the late 1970s, the [[Druze Initiative Committee]], centered at the village of [[Beit Jan]] and linked to [[Maki (political party)|Maki]], has campaigned to abolish Druze conscription.
 
 Military service is a tradition among some of the Druze population, with most opposition in Druze communities of the [[Golan Heights]]. 83 percent of Druze boys serve in the army, according to the IDF's statistics.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=129391 |title=Covenant of blood |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |author=Larry Derfner |date=15 January 2009 |access-date=10 June 2010 |archive-date=1 October 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101001060221/http://www.jpost.com/home/article.aspx?id=129391 |url-status=live }}</ref> According to the Israeli army in 2010, 369 Druze soldiers had been killed in combat operations since 1948.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dover.idf.il/IDF/News_Channels/Personal/10/10/1102.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324151019/http://dover.idf.il/IDF/News_Channels/Personal/10/10/1102.htm|archive-date=24 March 2012|title=מוכנים לטייס הדרוזי הראשון?|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
-The '''Quebec - New England Transmission''' is a long-distance [[HVDC]] line between [[Radisson, James Bay]], [[Quebec]] in [[Canada]] and Sandy Pond in [[Ayer, Massachusetts|Ayer]], [[Massachusetts]]. In contrast to most other HVDC facilities, it is equipped  with multiple static inverter stations.
+The '''Quebec - New England Transmission''' is a long-distance [[HVDC]] line between [[Radisson, Quebec|Radisson]], [[Quebec]], and Sandy Pond in [[Ayer, Massachusetts|Ayer]], [[Massachusetts]]. In contrast to most other HVDC facilities, it is equipped  with multiple static inverter stations.
 
-Originally, the Quebec - New England Transmission consisted of the 172 [[kilometer]] section between [[Estrie|Des Cantons]] in [[Quebec]], Canada and [[Littleton, New Hampshire|Comerford]], [[New Hampshire]] which, because of the asynchronous operation of the American and Québec power grids, had to be implemented as HVDC. This line, which is an overhead line for its whole length, went into service in [[1986]]. It could transfer a maximum power of 690 [[megawatt]]s. The operating voltage was +/-450 [[kV]].
+Originally, the Quebec - New England Transmission consisted of the 172 [[kilometer]] section between [[Estrie|Des Cantons]] in [[Quebec]] and [[Littleton, New Hampshire|Comerford]], [[New Hampshire]] which, because of the asynchronous operation of the American and Québec power grids, had to be implemented as HVDC. This line, which is an overhead line for its whole length, went into service in [[1986]]. It could transfer a maximum power of 690 [[megawatt]]s. The operating voltage was +/-450 [[kV]].
 
-The line was planned to extend beyond the two terminals in Des Cantons and Comerford to the [[hydroelectric]] power plants at [[James Bay]] and to the high consumption area around [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], Massachusetts. For this reason the line was extended by 1100 kilometers to the north toward the [[static inverter plant]] at Radisson and to the south to the static inverter plant at Sandy Pond in Massachusetts. The transmission power was increased by extending the existing static inverter stations to 2000 megawatts. The value of the transmission voltage remained unchanged at +/-450kV. For the connection of the [[Montreal]] area, a further static inverter station at [[Nicolet-Yamaska Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Nicolet]] was put into service in [[1992]] with a transmission capacity of 2000 megawatts.
+The line was planned to extend beyond the two terminals in Des Cantons and Comerford to the [[hydroelectric]] power plants of the [[James Bay Project|La Grande Complex]], in the James Bay region of Québec, and to the high consumption area around [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], Massachusetts. For this reason the line was extended by 1,100 kilometers to the north toward the [[static inverter plant]] at Radisson and to the south to the static inverter plant at Sandy Pond in Massachusetts. The transmission power was increased by extending the existing static inverter stations to 2000 megawatts. The value of the transmission voltage remained unchanged at +/-450kV. For the connection of the [[Montreal]] area, a further static inverter station at [[Nicolet-Yamaska Regional County Municipality, Quebec|Nicolet]] was put into service in [[1992]] with a transmission capacity of 2,000 megawatts.
 
 ==External links==

@@ -46,7 +46,9 @@
 ==Other violence against journalists==
 
-Alongside those killed, missing or detained, the  Committee to Protect Journalists has received numerous reports of damage done to journalists' offices and homes, and estimates that "48 media facilities in Gaza have been hit or destroyed".<ref name=aljhbk/>
+Alongside those killed, missing or detained, the  Committee to Protect Journalists has received numerous reports of damage done to journalists' offices and homes, and estimates that "48 media facilities in Gaza have been hit or destroyed".<ref name=aljhbk/> 
 
-In Israel, the Israeli journalist Israel Frey was also forced into hiding after he dedicated a prayer to the victims of the war in Gaza and a right-wing mob stormed his home, threatening his family.<ref name=aljhbk/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-10-15/ty-article/.premium/far-right-israelis-threaten-attack-journalist-who-dedicated-a-prayer-to-gaza-victims/0000018b-3434-d450-a3af-7d3ccb9d0000 |title=Far-right Israelis Threaten, Attack Left-wing Journalist Who Dedicated a Prayer to Gaza Victims |publisher=Haaretz}}</ref>
+In Gaza, Mohammed Balousha, a journalist who broke the story of premature babies dead at the Nasr pediatric hospital, was shot and injured by the IDF.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Harb |first1=Hajar |title=Journalist who broke story on decomposing babies in Gaza is shot, injured |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/12/18/israel-gaza-journalist-shot-mohammed-balousha/?utm_campaign=wp_post_most&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&wpisrc=nl_most |website=The Washington Post |access-date=19 December 2023}}</ref>
+
+In Israel, a right-wing mob stormed the home of Israeli journalist Israel Frey and forced him into hiding after he dedicated a prayer to the victims of the war in Gaza, threatening his family.<ref name=aljhbk/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-10-15/ty-article/.premium/far-right-israelis-threaten-attack-journalist-who-dedicated-a-prayer-to-gaza-victims/0000018b-3434-d450-a3af-7d3ccb9d0000 |title=Far-right Israelis Threaten, Attack Left-wing Journalist Who Dedicated a Prayer to Gaza Victims |publisher=Haaretz}}</ref>

@@ -348,4 +348,6 @@
 
 Video evidence surfaced of what was described as a "flagrant violation of international laws related to the protection of civilians" by Euro-Mediterranean Human Rights Monitor. Israeli soldiers were shown surrounding detainees in [[Yatta, Hebron]] who were being dragged and assaulted by the Israeli soldiers. Many of the detainees had been stripped naked, having both their arms and feet bound, and beaten with the butts of rifles and trampled.<ref>{{cite web |date=1 November 2023 |title=Egregious acts of torture, abuse committed by Israeli army against Palestinian civilians in the West Bank |url=https://euromedmonitor.org/en/article/5906 |work=Euromed}}</ref> Video evidence depicting degradation towards detainees shows Israeli soldiers transporting Palestinians from Ofer prison, all of whom are blindfolded and stripped completely naked.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://arn.ps/post/277763.html | title= ت الاحتلال ينقل أسرى من سجن عوفر وهم عراة |work=Ajeel}}</ref> In another video uploaded by an Israeli soldier, a blindfolded and bound Palestinian is shown kneeling on the ground. The soldier taunts him in Arabic, telling him "صباح الخير يا قحبة" (Good morning, whore) before repeatedly kicking and spitting on him.<ref>{{cite web |title=IDF soldiers film themselves abusing, humiliating West Bank Palestinians|date=1 November 2023 |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/idf-soldiers-film-themselves-abusing-humiliating-west-bank-palestinians/amp/ |work=The Times of Israel|first=Gianluca|last=Pacchiani|access-date=24 November 2023}}</ref> On 11 December, Human Rights Watch director, Omar Shakir, stated the blindfolding and stripping of Palestinian detainees represented a war crime.<ref>{{cite web |title=HRW says inhumane treatment of Palestinian detainees amounts to 'war crime' |url=https://aje.io/2hwa2q?update=2550195 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=12 December 2023}}</ref> On 20 December, [[Amnesty International]] called for an investigation into mass detentions, disappearances, inhumane treatment, and detainee deaths.<ref>{{cite web |title=Urgently investigate inhumane treatment and enforced disappearance of Palestinians detainees from Gaza |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2023/12/urgently-investigate-inhumane-treatment-and-enforced-disappearance-of-palestinians-detainees-from-gaza/ |website=Amnesty International |date=20 December 2023 |access-date=21 December 2023}}</ref>
+
+In February 2024, the ''BBC'' published a report detailing documented instances of Israeli soldiers abusing and humiliating Palestinian detainees, which [[Mark Ellis (lawyer)|Mark Ellis]], an expert on international criminal tribunals, said showed possible violations of laws regarding prisoners of war.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Thomas |first1=Merlyn |title=Israeli soldier videos from Gaza could breach international law, experts say |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-68249962 |website=BBC |access-date=15 February 2024}}</ref> After the IDF dismissed one of the reservists shown in the video, Sir [[Geoffrey Nice]], an expert on war crimes, stated a wider investigation was needed beyond the dismissal.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Thomas |first1=Merlyn |title=Israel to act on soldier misconduct after BBC investigation |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-68277124 |website=BBC |access-date=15 February 2024}}</ref>

|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/6/israels-war-on-gaza-live-staggering-destruction-in-north-gaza-unrwa?update=2682494 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=7 February 2024}}</ref> [[UNOCHA]] stated it was the fifth report of Israeli firing upon people waiting for humanitarian aid.<ref>{{cite web |title=People shot at while waiting for humanitarian aid in Gaza City: Report |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/6/israels-war-on-gaza-live-staggering-destruction-in-north-gaza-unrwa?update=2680957 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=8 February 2024}}</ref> ''Al Jazeera'' journalist Abubaker Abed stated, "Families eat strategically, just to stay alive."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Abed |first1=Abubaker |title=‘Families eat strategically, just to stay alive’ |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/5/israels-war-on-gaza-live-israeli-strikes-level-homes-in-deir-el-balah?update=2679706 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=6 February 2024}}</ref>
+
+While speaking to ''[[CNN]]'' reporters in February 2024, some Palestinians have alleged that the humanitarian aid that is allowed into Gaza is often poorly regulated and can be concentrated in areas, which has helped create a flourishing black market. Humanitarian parcels received by Palestinians have reportedly already been opened with contents removed. Israeli airstrikes around certain areas have also caused prices to spike with a 25-kilogram bag of flour jumping from $20 in Kahn Younis to $34 after intensified airstrikes.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rahimi |first=Sana Noor Haq, Rosa |date=2024-01-30 |title=‘We are dying slowly.’ Children go to bed hungry and parents scavenge for food as famine looms in Gaza |url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/01/30/middleeast/famine-looms-in-gaza-israel-war-intl/index.html |access-date=2024-02-09 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref>

@@ -1,5 +1,11 @@
+'''Donna Hylton''' (born October 29, 1964 in Jamaica, now a naturalized American citizen) is a women's rights activist and criminal justice reform advocate. She speaks publicly about the issues facing incarcerated and formerly incarcerated women and girls 
+  
+Hylton, a survivor of childhood gender-based violence and sexual abuse, is currently focusing her activism on highlighting the pervasiveness of gender-based violence and sexual abuse in the lived experience of women and girls as a direct link to the choices, circumstances and psychological factors that result in their incarceration. It is estimated that among incarcerated women 90% have experienced violence throughout their lifetimes; 80% experienced serious physical and/or sexual abuse as children and 75% experienced intimate partner violence.<ref>2016 U.S. Correctional Association</ref> Her goal is to be a driving force in creating the public awareness of these narratives and the opportunities for women to tell their full stories in their own words. Most recently, Hylton was a featured speaker at the [[2017 Women's March|Women's March on Washington]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Speakers|url=https://www.womensmarch.com/speakers/|accessdate=23 January 2017}} 
 
+In the past she has also advocated for the 'compassionated release' of aging prisoners based on humanitarian principles.</ref><ref name="Quartz">{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/634453/keeping-elderly-inmates-behind-bars-makes-a-mockery-of-our-so-called-justice-system/|title=Keeping rehabilitated inmates behind bars makes a mockery of America’s so-called justice system|first=Keri|last=Blakinger|date=9 March 2016}}</ref> 
 
-In 1985, at the age of 19, Hylton was convicted and sentenced to 25 years to life, ultimately serving 27 years for the murder of the 62-year-old real-estate broker Thomas Vigliarole. She drugged, kidnapped, beat, raped, burned, sodomized with a 3 foot steel pole, clamped his testicles with a pair of pliers before ultimately shoving him in a trunk to suffocate to death. She is a sick piece of garbage and was a prominent speaker at the women's march on Washington. Needless to say they didnt mention her tourturing and murder of a gay, white man during her speech about racial and gender inequality against women of color. How nice! Hopefully she will die a slow and painful death one day here soon. Until then she continues to walk amongst us as another lefty liberal hypocrite social justice warrior. Awesome!
+In 1985, at the age of 19, Hylton was convicted and sentenced to 25 years to life, ultimately serving 27 years for the murder of the 62-year-old real-estate broker Thomas Vigliarole. During her rehabilitation, Hylton earned both a bachelor's and a master's degree from [[Mercy College (New York)|Mercy College]]. Her involvement in the high-profile case was the subject of a 1995 article in ''Psychology Today'' magazine.<ref name="Psych">{{cite web|title=Crime and Punishment|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/articles/199507/crime-and-punishment|last=Neimark|first=Jill|date=July 1, 1995 |accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref> A spate of highly charged and public attacks through social media followed Hylton's appearance at the Women's March{{Citation needed|reason=I'm not sure how to source something this diffuse = anyone got a good article?|date=January 2017}}.
+
+In 2016 it was announced that [[Rosario Dawson]] was attached to a movie version of Hylton's life story entitled ''A Little Piece of Light''. The film is in development, in search of a screenwriter and director.<ref name="Film">{{cite web|first=Anita|last=Busch|title=Rosario Dawson Attached To Play Activist Donna Hylton In ‘A Little Piece Of Light’|url=http://deadline.com/2016/11/rosario-dawson-activist-donna-hylton-a-little-piece-of-light-movie-1201852430/|accessdate=23 January 2017}}</ref>
