 === 4 November ===
 {{Main|Al-Fakhoora school airstrike}}
-On 4 November, [[Al-Fakhoora school airstrike|Israeli forces bombed the UN-run al-Fakhoora school]] in [[Jabalia refugee camp]], which had been sheltering displaced people, killing at least 15 people and wounding 54, mostly women and children. Israel had also targeted solar panels and generators, including solar panels on top of hospitals. These were the only source of electricity in Gaza since [[October 2023 Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip|Israel imposed a total blockade on the Gaza Strip]] on 9 October. The Israeli army had bombed the Ali bin Abi Talib and Al-Istijabah mosques in al-Sabra neighborhood.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=Pietromarchi |first=Mersiha Gadzo,Virginia |title='Last nail in the coffin': Israel bombs Gaza schools, mosques, solar panels |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |access-date=2023-11-04 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en |archive-date=4 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231104093821/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |url-status=live }}</ref> Hamas' Al-Qassam Brigades said that their fighters have killed 5 more Israeli soldiers in a building northwest of Gaza City, after attacking the force with machine guns and bombs.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |last=Pietromarchi |first=Mersiha Gadzo,Virginia |title=New Israeli attack on Gaza school sheltering families kills 15 |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |access-date=2023-11-04 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en |archive-date=4 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231104093821/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |url-status=live }}</ref> Al-Qassam Brigades have stated that they are fighting on multiple fronts, including northwest of Gaza City, south of Gaza City, in [[Beit Hanoun]] and northeastern Gaza Strip. Hamas fighters have destroyed 24 Israeli military vehicles, including a tank, an armoured personnel carrier, and a bulldozer with anti-armour weapons, notably Al Yassin 105 shells in the past two days.<ref name=":4" />
+On 4 November, [[Al-Fakhoora school airstrike|Israeli forces bombed the UN-run al-Fakhoora school]] in [[Jabalia refugee camp]], which had been sheltering displaced people, killing at least 15 people and wounding 54, mostly women and children. Israel had also targeted solar panels and generators, including solar panels on top of hospitals. These were the only source of electricity in Gaza since [[October 2023 Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip|Israel imposed a total blockade on the Gaza Strip]] on 9 October. The Israeli army had bombed the Ali bin Abi Talib and Al-Istijabah mosques in al-Sabra neighborhood.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=Pietromarchi |first=Mersiha Gadzo,Virginia |title='Last nail in the coffin': Israel bombs Gaza schools, mosques, solar panels |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |access-date=2023-11-04 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en |archive-date=4 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231104093821/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |url-status=live }}</ref> Hamas' Al-Qassam Brigades said that their fighters have killed 5 more Israeli soldiers in a building northwest of Gaza City, after attacking the force with machine guns and bombs.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |last=Pietromarchi |first=Mersiha Gadzo,Virginia |title=New Israeli attack on Gaza school sheltering families kills 15 |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |access-date=2023-11-04 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en |archive-date=4 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231104093821/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/4/israel-hamas-war-live-20-dead-in-israeli-attack-on-school-ministry |url-status=live }}</ref> Al-Qassam Brigades have stated that they are fighting on multiple fronts, including northwest of Gaza City, south of Gaza City, in [[Beit Hanoun]] and northeastern Gaza Strip. Hamas fighters have destroyed 24 Israeli military vehicles, including a tank, an armoured personnel carrier, and a bulldozer with anti-armour weapons, notably 105 [[Al-Yassin]] rocket-propelled grenades in the past two days.<ref name=":4" />

@@ -218,5 +218,5 @@
 The IDF shelled [[Meiss Ej Jabal Hospital]], injuring a doctor on 10 November. The missiles did not explode but caused damage to the emergency department and a number of cars. The Lebanese health ministry condemned the attack, saying that "Israeli authorities were fully responsible for this unjustifiable act, which would have led to catastrophic results", and called for an investigation.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-11 |title=Israeli missile strike hits hospital in southern Lebanon |url=https://arab.news/55y9j |access-date=2023-11-11 |website=Arab News |language=en}}</ref> Days before, four people were reportedly injured after an Israeli bombing that hit two ambulances. The Lebanese [[The National News Agency|National News Agency]] said that an Israeli drone strike hit two ambulances belonging to the Risala Scout association which is affiliated with the Amal Movement<ref>{{Cite web |date=5 November 2023 |title=Four wounded in Israel strike on Lebanon ambulances: rescuers |url=https://www.macaubusiness.com/four-wounded-in-israel-strike-on-lebanon-ambulances-rescuers/ |access-date=5 November 2023 |website=Macau Business |language=en-GB}}</ref>

diffText:
@@ -55,5 +55,5 @@
 The Israeli–Palestinian conflict has its roots in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with the birth of major nationalist movements [[Zionism|among the Jews]] and [[Arab nationalism|among the Arabs]], both geared towards attaining sovereignty for their people in the Middle East.<ref name="SelaConflict" /> The [[Balfour Declaration]] was a public statement issued by the British government in 1917 during the First World War announcing support for the establishment of a "national home for the Jewish people" in Palestine.<ref>{{Cite book |first=James |last=Gelvin |author-link=James L. Gelvin |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=wfIFVze1MqQC&pg=PA81 |title=The Israel-Palestine Conflict: One Hundred Years of War |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |orig-year=2002 |edition=3 |year=2014|isbn= 978-0-521-85289-0}}</ref> The collision between those two movements in southern [[Levant]] upon the emergence of [[Palestinian nationalism]] after the [[Franco-Syrian War]] in the 1920s escalated into the [[Sectarian conflict in Mandatory Palestine]] in 1930s and 1940s, and expanded into the wider [[Arab–Israeli conflict]] later on.<ref name="HistoryPBS">{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/pov/pdf/promiese/promises-timeline.pdf |title=History of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict |publisher=PBS |date=December 2001 |access-date=14 March 2013 |archive-date=2 December 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121202230446/http://www.pbs.org/pov/pdf/promiese/promises-timeline.pdf |url-status=dead }}</ref>
 
-The return of several hard-line Palestinian Arab nationalists, under the emerging leadership of [[Haj Amin al-Husseini]], from Damascus to [[Mandatory Palestine]] marked the beginning of [[Palestinian nationalism|Palestinian Arab nationalist struggle]] towards establishment of a national home for Arabs of [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]].<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Sela |editor-first=Avraham |editor-link=Avraham Sela |chapter=Palestine Arabs |title=The Continuum Political Encyclopedia of the Middle East |location=New York |year=2002 |publisher=Continuum |isbn=978-0-8264-1413-7 |pages=664–673 }}</ref> Amin al-Husseini, the architect of the Palestinian Arab national movement, immediately marked [[Zionism|Jewish national movement]] and [[Aliyah|Jewish immigration to Palestine]] as the sole enemy to his cause,<ref name="al-Husseini">{{harvnb|Sela|2002|p=361|loc="al-Husseini, Hajj (Muhammad) Amin"}}<blockquote>He [Husseini] incited and headed anti-Jewish riots in April 1920. ... He promoted the Muslim character of Jerusalem and ... injected a religious character into the struggle against [[Zionism]]. This was the backdrop to his agitation concerning Jewish rights at the Western (Wailing) Wall that led to the bloody riots of August 1929...[H]e was the chief organizer of the riots of 1936 and the rebellion from 1937, as well as of the mounting internal terror against Arab opponents.</blockquote></ref> initiating large-scale riots against the Jews as early as 1920 [[1920 Nebi Musa riots|in Jerusalem]] and in 1921 [[Jaffa riots|in Jaffa]]. Among the results of the violence was the establishment of the Jewish paramilitary force [[Haganah]]. In 1929, a series of violent [[1929 Palestine riots|riots]] resulted in the deaths of 133 Jews and 116 Arabs, with significant Jewish casualties in [[1929 Hebron massacre|Hebron]] and [[Safed]], and the evacuation of Jews from Hebron and Gaza.<ref name="SelaConflict" />
+The return of several hard-line Palestinian Arab nationalists, under the emerging leadership of [[Haj Amin al-Husseini]], from Damascus to [[Mandatory Palestine]] marked the beginning of [[Palestinian nationalism|Palestinian Arab nationalist struggle]] towards establishment of a national home for Arabs of [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]].<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Sela |editor-first=Avraham |editor-link=Avraham Sela |chapter=Palestine Arabs |title=The Continuum Political Encyclopedia of the Middle East |location=New York |year=2002 |publisher=Continuum |isbn=978-0-8264-1413-7 |pages=664–673 }}</ref> Amin al-Husseini, the architect of the Palestinian Arab national movement, immediately marked [[Zionism|Jewish national movement]] and [[Aliyah|Jewish immigration to Palestine]] as the sole enemy to his cause,<ref name="al-Husseini">{{harvnb|Sela|2002|p=361|loc="al-Husseini, Hajj (Muhammad) Amin"}}<blockquote>He [Husseini] incited and headed anti-Jewish riots in April 1920. ... He promoted the Muslim character of Jerusalem and ... injected a religious character into the struggle against [[Zionism]]. This was the backdrop to his agitation concerning Jewish rights at the Western (Wailing) Wall that led to the bloody riots of August 1929...[H]e was the chief organizer of the riots of 1936 and the rebellion from 1937, as well as of the mounting internal terror against Arab opponents.</blockquote></ref> initiating large-scale riots against the Jews as early as 1920 [[1920 Nebi Musa riots|in Jerusalem]] and in 1921 [[Jaffa riots|in Jaffa]]. Among the results of the violence was the establishment of the Jewish paramilitary force [[Haganah]]. In 1929, a series of violent [[1929 Palestine riots|riots]] resulted in the deaths of 133 Jews and 116 Arabs, with significant Jewish casualties in [[1929 Hebron massacre|Hebron]] and [[1929_Palestine_riots#Safed_massacre,_29_August|Safed]], and the evacuation of Jews from Hebron and Gaza.<ref name="SelaConflict" />
 [[File:Palest against british.gif|right|thumb|The [[1936–39 Arab revolt in Palestine|Arab revolt of 1936–1939]] in Palestine, motivated by opposition to mass [[Aliyah|Jewish immigration]].]]

@@ -231,5 +231,5 @@
 On 31 October, Paris police shot and critically injured a woman wearing a [[hijab]] shouted "[[Takbir|Allahu Akbar]]" and "You're all going to die" in a [[Paris Metro|metro station]]. France had been on the highest alert following the [[Arras school stabbing|killing of a teacher]] in [[Arras]] by a suspected Islamist sympathizer believed have been done in response to the war.<ref>{{cite news |title=Woman shouting 'You're all going to die' shot by police in Paris metro |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/hijab-wearing-woman-shot-by-police-paris-metro-condition-critical-2023-10-31/ |website=reuters |date=31 October 2023 |access-date=7 November 2023 |archive-date=7 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231107063930/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/hijab-wearing-woman-shot-by-police-paris-metro-condition-critical-2023-10-31/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
-On 12 November, over 100,000 people [[March for the Republic and Against Antisemitism|marched against antisemitism]] in Paris. Prime Minister [[Élisabeth Borne]], the heads of France's upper and lower houses of parliament, former presidents [[François Hollande]] and [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], and several leading politicians joined the demonstrators. However, the presence of the far-right [[National Rally]] leader [[Marine Le Pen]], whose party has had a history of antisemitism, caused criticism from some participants such as Borne, who is the daughter of [[Holocaust]] survivors.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-12 |title=More than 100,000 people march in Paris against soaring antisemitism amid Israel-Hamas war |url=https://apnews.com/article/france-paris-antisemitism-march-macron-1083d79342ce7a27ccd4f5f63e2abc57 |access-date=2023-11-12 |website=AP News |language=en |archive-date=12 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231112190332/https://apnews.com/article/france-paris-antisemitism-march-macron-1083d79342ce7a27ccd4f5f63e2abc57 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 21 January 2024, Paris police stopped and dispersed an automobile parade waving Palestinian flags.<ref>{{cite web |title=French police stop convoy carrying Palestinian flags in solidarity with Gaza |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/21/israels-war-on-gaza-live-deadly-israeli-attacks-across-gaza?update=2637324 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=22 January 2024}}</ref>
+On 12 November, over 100,000 people [[March for the Republic and Against Antisemitism|marched against antisemitism]] in Paris. Prime Minister [[Élisabeth Borne]], the heads of France's upper and lower houses of parliament, former presidents [[François Hollande]] and [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], and several leading politicians joined the demonstrators. However, the presence of the far-right [[National Rally]] leader [[Marine Le Pen]], whose party has had a history of antisemitism, caused criticism from some participants such as Borne, who is the daughter of [[Holocaust]] survivors.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-12 |title=More than 100,000 people march in Paris against soaring antisemitism amid Israel-Hamas war |url=https://apnews.com/article/france-paris-antisemitism-march-macron-1083d79342ce7a27ccd4f5f63e2abc57 |access-date=2023-11-12 |website=AP News |language=en |archive-date=12 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231112190332/https://apnews.com/article/france-paris-antisemitism-march-macron-1083d79342ce7a27ccd4f5f63e2abc57 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 21 January 2024, Paris police stopped and dispersed an automobile parade waving Palestinian flags.<ref>{{cite web |title=French police stop convoy carrying Palestinian flags in solidarity with Gaza |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/21/israels-war-on-gaza-live-deadly-israeli-attacks-across-gaza?update=2637324 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=22 January 2024}}</ref> On 22 January, MP [[Louis Boyard]] was verbally assaulted and threatened by a pro-Israeli activist.<ref>{{cite web |title=French MP confrontation prompts call for protection of Palestine supporters |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/22/israels-war-on-gaza-live-bombing-all-around-hospital-in-khan-younis?update=2639046 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=22 January 2024}}</ref>

@@ -200,8 +200,8 @@
 ===Films===
 *While writing the screenplay of the mystery thriller film ''[[The Conversation (film)|The Conversation]]'' (1974) – similar in the plot in some way but about sound recording rather than photography – [[Francis Ford Coppola]] explained in the DVD commentary to that film that he was inspired by ''Blowup''.
-*In the [[comedy film]] ''[[High Anxiety]]'' (1977), directed by [[Mel Brooks]], a minor plot line involves a bumbling chauffeur who takes a picture showing the evil assassin (wearing a latex mask of Brooks' character's face) firing a gun at point-blank range at someone; he makes blow-ups until he can see the ''real'' character, standing in the elevator in the background. (Technically, the chauffeur does not make blow-ups; the joke is that he simply makes bigger and bigger enlargements until he has one the size of a wall.)
+*In the satirical [[comedy film]] ''[[High Anxiety]]'' (1977), starring, written, produced and directed by [[Mel Brooks]], a minor plot line involves a bumbling chauffeur who takes a picture showing the evil assassin (wearing a latex mask of [[Mel Brooks]]' character's face) firing a gun at point-blank range at someone; he makes blow-ups until he can see the real character, standing in the elevator in the background. (Technically, the chauffeur does not make blow-ups; the joke is that he simply makes bigger and bigger enlargements until he has one the size of a wall.)
 * [[Michelangelo Antonioni]]'s film also inspired the Egyptian film ''[[Darbet shams]]'' (1980), directed by [[Mohamed Khan]], in which photographer inadvertently capture the murder while doing his job at wedding.
 *''[[Blow Out]]'' (1981), directed and written by [[Brian De Palma]] and starring [[John Travolta]], [[Nancy Allen (actress)|Nancy Allen]], [[John Lithgow]] and [[Dennis Franz]], alludes to ''Blow-Up'' and used sound recording rather than photography as its motif.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kael|first=Pauline|authorlink=Pauline Kael|title=Taking It All In|year=1984|publisher=Holt, Rinehart and Winston|location=New York City|isbn=0-03-069361-6|pages=227|chapter=Portrait of the Artist as a Young Gadgeteer|quote=''Blow Out'' is a variation on Antonioni's ''Blow-Up''}}</ref>
-*Antonioni's film also inspired the [[Bollywood]] film ''[[Jaane Bhi Do Yaaron]]'' (1983), directed by [[Kundan Shah]], in which two photographers inadvertently capture the murder of a Bombay Municipal Commissioner on their cameras and later discover this when the images are enlarged. The park in which the murder occurs is named "Antonioni Park".<ref>Sudip, Geetika (7 December 2007). [http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/fr/2007/12/07/stories/2007120750810200.htm "Of Naseeruddin Shah and Michelangelo Antonioni …"]. ''[[The Hindu]]''. Retrieved 21 February 2011.</ref>
+*[[Michelangelo Antonioni]]'s film also inspired the Indian comedy film ''[[Jaane Bhi Do Yaaron]]'' (1983), directed and co-written by [[Kundan Shah]], in which two photographers inadvertently capture the murder of a Bombay Municipal Commissioner on their cameras and later discover this when the images are enlarged. The park in which the murder occurs is named "Antonioni Park".<ref>Sudip, Geetika (7 December 2007). [http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/fr/2007/12/07/stories/2007120750810200.htm "Of Naseeruddin Shah and Michelangelo Antonioni …"]. ''[[The Hindu]]''. Retrieved 21 February 2011.</ref>
 *Both the spy action comedy film ''[[Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery]]'' (1997) and its sequel ''[[Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me]]'' (1999) feature a parody and homage to [[Veruschka von Lehndorff]]'s photo shoot in ''Blowup''.
 *The [[romantic comedy]] film ''[[I Could Never Be Your Woman]]'' (2007) pays homage to the scene from ''Blowup'' in which [[David Hemmings]]' character Thomas straddles German model [[Veruschka von Lehndorff]] from above while taking her photograph – this time with [[Paul Rudd]] and [[Michelle Pfeiffer]].

@@ -71,5 +71,5 @@
 
 ===National movements===
-The roots of the modern Arab–Israeli conflict lie in the rise of [[Zionism]] and the [[Palestinian nationalism]] that arose in response to [[Zionism]] towards the end of the 19th century. Territory regarded by the [[Jewish people]] as their [[Homeland for the Jewish people|historical homeland]] is also regarded by the [[Pan-Arab]] movement as historically and presently belonging to the [[Palestinians|Palestinian Arabs]]. Before World War I, the Middle East, including Palestine (later [[Mandatory Palestine]]), had been under the control of the [[Ottoman Empire]] for nearly 400 years. During the closing years of their empire, the Ottomans began to espouse their Turkish ethnic identity, asserting the primacy of Turks within the empire, leading to discrimination against the Arabs.<ref>Fraser, T.G. ''The Middle East: 1914–1979''. St. Martin's Press, New York. (1980) Pg. 2</ref> The promise of liberation from the Ottomans led many Jews and Arabs to support the allied powers during World War I, leading to the emergence of widespread Arab nationalism. Both Arab nationalism and Zionism had their formulative beginning in Europe. The Zionist Congress was established in Basel in 1897, while the "Arab Club" was established in Paris in 1906.
+The roots of the modern Arab–Israeli conflict lie in the rise of [[Zionism]] and [[Palestinian nationalism]] that arose in response to [[Zionism]] towards the end of the 19th century. Territory regarded by the [[Jewish people]] as their [[Homeland for the Jewish people|historical homeland]] is also regarded by the [[Pan-Arab]] movement as historically and presently belonging to the [[Palestinians|Palestinian Arabs]]. Before World War I, the Middle East, including Palestine (later [[Mandatory Palestine]]), had been under the control of the [[Ottoman Empire]] for nearly 400 years. During the closing years of their empire, the Ottomans began to espouse their Turkish ethnic identity, asserting the primacy of Turks within the empire, leading to discrimination against the Arabs.<ref>Fraser, T.G. ''The Middle East: 1914–1979''. St. Martin's Press, New York. (1980) Pg. 2</ref> The promise of liberation from the Ottomans led many Jews and Arabs to support the allied powers during World War I, leading to the emergence of widespread Arab nationalism. Both Arab nationalism and Zionism had their formulative beginning in Europe. The Zionist Congress was established in Basel in 1897, while the "Arab Club" was established in Paris in 1906.
 
 In the late 19th century European and Middle Eastern Jewish communities began to increasingly immigrate to Palestine and purchase land from the local Ottoman landlords. The population of the late 19th century in Palestine reached 600,000 – mostly Muslim Arabs, but also significant minorities of Jews, Christians, Druze and some [[Samaritans]] and [[Baháʼí Faith|Baháʼís]]. At that time, Jerusalem did not extend beyond the walled area and had a population of only a few tens of thousands. Collective farms, known as [[kibbutz]]im, were established, as was the first entirely Jewish city in modern times, [[Tel Aviv]].

@@ -31,5 +31,5 @@
 Diplomatic cables subsequently published by [[WikiLeaks]] revealed that Israel had informed the United States in 2008 that, while it would take measures to prevent a humanitarian crisis, it intended to keep Gaza's economy on the "brink of collapse".<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE7041GH/ 'Israel said would keep Gaza near collapse: WikiLeaks,'] [[Reuters]] January 5, 2011</ref> Precise calculations were made to determine the minimum  calorific requirement (2,279 calories per person a day) to avoid malnutrition in the Gaza Strip, and these formed the basis for Israel's determination of the truck numbers for food supplies from 2007 to 2010.<ref>The French historian of Gaza [[Jean-Pierre Filiu]] commented:'The fact that Israel could feel empowered to decide how much a Palestinian could eat on a daily basis shows how perverse and degrading the post-2005 occupation of the Gaza Strip had become.'Filiu 2014 p.57.</ref><ref name="Reuters2012" >[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSBRE89G0NM/ 'Israel Gaza blockade study calculated Palestinians' calories,'] [[Reuters]] 17 October 2012</ref><ref>[[Associated Press]], [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/17/israeli-military-calorie-limit-gaza 'Israel used 'calorie count' to limit Gaza food during blockade, critics claim,'] [[The Guardian]] 12 October 2012</ref> The calculation excluded factors such as the collapse of agriculture due to the blockade which dried up access to seed markets.<ref>Howard-Hassmann, ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 p.127.</ref>{{efn|The complicated procedures for obtaining clearances from Israel at the transit points also caused notable spoilage further reducing the food allowed in. Prospective import goods had to arrive in Israeli trucks, which were unloaded as the goods were transferred to 'neutral' trucks that then were allowed transit to the Gaza side. Once there, the consignments had to be unloaded from the neutral trucks and reloaded on Gazan trucks.<ref name="State Food Crimes">{{cite book |title=State Food Crimes |url= https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/State_Food_Crimes/3LTDDAAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1  |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |access-date=18 January 2024|year=2016 |page =127}}</ref>}} Restrictions on foodstuffs included basic commodities like pasta, -that particular item was reintroduced after [[John Kerry]] protested at its inclusion in the list of banned imports- and any delicacies, such as honey, sesame snack [[halvah]], [[Bamba (snack)|bamba]] {{efn|A peanut-butter flavoured corn snack, prohibited because, according to one Israeli official, 'We don't want [[Gilad Shalit]]'s captors to be munching Bamba right over his head".'<ref>Alex Renton, [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2009/jun/16/gaza-blockade-israel-food 'No gourmets in Gaza,'] [[The Guardian]] 16 June 2009}} </ref>}}, tea, coffee, sausages, semolina, milk products in large packages, most baking products and limitations on meat and domestic cooking gas. <ref>Renton, 2009</ref>
 
-The [[Goldstone Report]] discovered that during the [[Gaza War (2008–2009)|2008-2009 Gaza War]], Israel’s invasion had caused  deliberate and massive destruction of Gaza’s agricultural sector.{{efn|The agricultural sector, including crop farming, fisheries, livestock farming and poultry farming, suffered direct losses worth some US$ 170 million. Indirect losses have still to be definitively calculated. One business organization estimates that 60 per cent of all agricultural land had been destroyed, 40 per cent directly during the military operations.  Moreover, 17 per cent of all orchards, 8.3 per cent of livestock, 2.6 per cent of poultry, 18.1 per cent of hatcheries, 25.6 per cent of beehives, 9.2 per cent of open fields and 13 per cent of groundwater wells were destroyed. Agriculture had already lost a third of its capacity since the start of the second intifada and the frequent Israeli incursions, according to NGO estimates used by UNDP-Gaza . . Some 250 agricultural wells were reportedly destroyed or severely damaged.<ref>Howard-Hassmann , ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 p.127 </ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Human Rights in Palestine and Other Occupied Arab Territories: Report of the United Nations Fact-Finding Mission on the Gaza Conflict |last=Goldstone |first =Richard|author-link= Richard Goldstone|url= https://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/docs/12session/a-hrc-12-48.pdf |website=[[United Nations Human Rights Council]] | pages =261-262 |access-date=18 January 2024|date=25 September 2009 }}</ref>}}   Israel also declared 30% of the most arable land in the Strip [[No-go areas|no-go zones]]. After 2012, the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] secured an agreement to allow Gazan farmers to cultivate crops of various heights, in areas respectively at 300 metres to 1 kilometre from Israel's [[Gaza–Israel barrier|fortified border fence]]. Both cultivators and their rudimentary irrigation devices nonetheless were often exposed to sniping and automated machinegun fire, and crops along the armistice line were, without warning, sprayed by [[Monsanto]]'s [[Roundup (herbicide)|roundup herbicide]].<ref>Ron Smith, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/45406228 'Israel's Permanent Siege of Gaza,'] [[Middle East Report]], No. 290, Spring 2019 pp.38-42 pp.39-40.</ref> Likewise, Israel placed severe restrictions on fishing within Gaza's waters — the 20 nautical miles agreed to under the [[Oslo Accords]] were unilaterally reduced to nine — with fishable areas demarcated with buoys.<ref>[[Jean-Pierre Filiu]], [https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1525/jps.2014.44.1.52 'The Twelve Wars on Gaza,'] [[Journal of Palestine Studies]] Vol. 44, No. 1, SP Autumn 2014  pp.52-60 p.56.</ref>In 2009 Israel further reduced this to a 3 nautical mile limit with the result that 85% of Gaza's fishing water was blocked by Israeli warships.<ref>Howard-Hassmann, ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 pp.125-127.</ref> Israel gunships reportedly fired on local fishermen even within these areas.<ref>Ron Smith, 2019 p.40</ref>
+The [[Goldstone Report]] discovered that during the [[Gaza War (2008–2009)|2008-2009 Gaza War]], Israel’s invasion had caused  deliberate and massive destruction of Gaza’s agricultural sector.{{efn|The agricultural sector, including crop farming, fisheries, livestock farming and poultry farming, suffered direct losses worth some US$ 170 million. Indirect losses have still to be definitively calculated. One business organization estimates that 60 per cent of all agricultural land had been destroyed, 40 per cent directly during the military operations.  Moreover, 17 per cent of all orchards, 8.3 per cent of livestock, 2.6 per cent of poultry, 18.1 per cent of hatcheries, 25.6 per cent of beehives, 9.2 per cent of open fields and 13 per cent of groundwater wells were destroyed. Agriculture had already lost a third of its capacity since the start of the second intifada and the frequent Israeli incursions, according to NGO estimates used by UNDP-Gaza . . Some 250 agricultural wells were reportedly destroyed or severely damaged.<ref>Howard-Hassmann , ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 p.127 </ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Human Rights in Palestine and Other Occupied Arab Territories: Report of the United Nations Fact-Finding Mission on the Gaza Conflict |last=Goldstone |first =Richard|author-link= Richard Goldstone|url= https://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/docs/12session/a-hrc-12-48.pdf |website=[[United Nations Human Rights Council]] | pages =261-262 |access-date=18 January 2024|date=25 September 2009 }}</ref>}}   Israel also declared 30% of the most arable land in the Strip [[No-go areas|no-go zones]]. After 2012, the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] secured an agreement to allow Gazan farmers to cultivate crops of various heights, in areas respectively at 300 metres to 1 kilometre from Israel's [[Gaza–Israel barrier|fortified border fence]]. Both cultivators and their rudimentary irrigation devices nonetheless were often exposed to sniping and automated machinegun fire, and crops along the armistice line were, without warning, sprayed by [[Monsanto]]'s [[Roundup (herbicide)|Roundup herbicide]].<ref>Ron Smith, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/45406228 'Israel's Permanent Siege of Gaza,'] [[Middle East Report]], No. 290, Spring 2019 pp.38-42 pp.39-40.</ref> Likewise, Israel placed severe restrictions on fishing within Gaza's waters — the 20 nautical miles agreed to under the [[Oslo Accords]] were unilaterally reduced to nine — with fishable areas demarcated with buoys.<ref>[[Jean-Pierre Filiu]], [https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1525/jps.2014.44.1.52 'The Twelve Wars on Gaza,'] [[Journal of Palestine Studies]] Vol. 44, No. 1, SP Autumn 2014  pp.52-60 p.56.</ref>In 2009 Israel further reduced this to a 3 nautical mile limit with the result that 85% of Gaza's fishing water was blocked by Israeli warships.<ref>Howard-Hassmann, ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 pp.125-127.</ref> Israel gunships reportedly fired on local fishermen even within these areas.<ref>Ron Smith, 2019 p.40</ref>
 
 ==Start of crisis==

 == Misconduct ==
-During the Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip, numerous viral videos showed Israeli soldiers' misconduct. A series of videos in mid-December 2023 showed IDF troops burning food, vandalizing a shop, and ransacking private homes.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kottasová |first1=Ivana |last2=Alkhaldi |first2=Celine |title=Videos show Israeli soldiers in Gaza burning food, vandalizing a shop and ransacking private homes |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/12/15/middleeast/israeli-soldiers-burningfood-gaza-intl/index.html |website=CNN |access-date=31 December 2023}}</ref> The [[Euro-Med Monitor]] recorded instances where soldiers deliberately stole civilians' assets, including laptops, gold, and large quantities of cash.<ref>{{cite web |title=Amid ongoing genocide in Gaza, systematic Israeli theft occurring in Palestinian civilian homes |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/amid-ongoing-genocide-gaza-systematic-israeli-theft-occurring-palestinian-civilian-homes-enar |website=ReliefWeb |publisher=Euro-Med Monitor |access-date=31 December 2023}}</ref> Euro-Med Monitor also reported on soldiers recorded harassing corpses, dragging them, urinating on them, and amputating them.<ref>{{cite web |title=Shock, outrage expressed by Euro-Med Monitor over Israel’s ongoing mutilation and filming of dead Palestinian bodies |url=https://euromedmonitor.org/en/article/5935/Shock,-outrage-expressed-by-Euro-Med-Monitor-over-Israel’s-ongoing-mutilation-and-filming-of-dead-Palestinian-bodies |website=Euro-Med Human Rights Monitor |access-date=31 December 2023}}</ref> In a social media post, the [[Council on American–Islamic Relations]] condemned a video of an Israeli solider stating, "Maybe I killed a girl, she was 12, but I'm looking for a baby."<ref>{{Cite tweet |user=CAIRNational |number=1740761515605827982 |title=In a leaked video call, an #Israeli soldier nonchalantly says, ‘maybe I killed a girl, she was 12, but I'm looking for a baby.’ #Gaza #GenocideinPalestine #ceasefireNowPermanently}}</ref>

@@ -100,5 +100,5 @@
 
 ==Government and politics==
-In 2006, Hamas won the [[2006 Palestinian legislative election]]s and assumed administrative control of Gaza Strip and West Bank. In 2007, Hamas led a [[Battle of Gaza (2007)|military victory]] over Fatah, the secular Palestinian nationalist party, which had dominated the [[Palestinian National Authority]]. As a result, [[President of the Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian President]] Mahmoud Abbas declared [[state of emergency]] and released Hamas Prime Minister Haniye - a move not recognized by the Hamas party, which ''de facto'' continued administration and military control of the Gaza Strip, while in the PNA controlled West Bank another government was established with Fatah domination.<ref name=telegraph_dissolve>{{cite news|first=Charles |last=Levinson |author2=Matthew Moore |title=Abbas declares state of emergency in Gaza |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/06/14/wgaza614.xml |date=June 14, 2007 |access-date=June 14, 2007 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618102009/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2007%2F06%2F14%2Fwgaza614.xml |archive-date=June 18, 2007 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=bbc_dissolve>{{cite news |title=Abbas sacks Hamas-led government |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6754499.stm |date= June 14, 2007 |access-date=June 14, 2007  |work=BBC News| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714200614/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6754499.stm| archive-date= July 14, 2007}}</ref>
+In 2006, Hamas won the [[2006 Palestinian legislative election]]s and assumed administrative control of Gaza Strip and West Bank. In 2007, Hamas led a [[Battle of Gaza (2007)|military victory]] over Fatah, the secular Palestinian nationalist party, which had dominated the [[Palestinian National Authority]]. As a result, [[President of the Palestinian National Authority|Palestinian President]] Mahmoud Abbas declared [[state of emergency]] and released Hamas Prime Minister Haniye - a move not recognized by the Hamas party, which ''de facto'' continued administration and military control of the Gaza Strip, while in the PNA controlled West Bank another government was established with Fatah domination.<ref name=telegraph_dissolve>{{cite news|first=Charles |last=Levinson |author2=Matthew Moore |title=Abbas declares state of emergency in Gaza |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/06/14/wgaza614.xml |date=June 14, 2007 |access-date=June 14, 2007 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618102009/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fnews%2F2007%2F06%2F14%2Fwgaza614.xml |archive-date=June 18, 2007 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name=bbc_dissolve>{{cite news |title=Abbas sacks Hamas-led government |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6754499.stm |date= June 14, 2007 |access-date=June 14, 2007  |work=BBC News| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714200614/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6754499.stm| archive-date= July 14, 2007}}</ref>
 
 Both regimes - the Ramallah and Gaza government regard themselves as the sole legitimate government of the Palestinian National Authority. Egyptian-mediated negotiations toward reconciliation between the Fatah and the Hamas government produced a preliminary agreement, planned to be implemented by May 2012 in joint elections. To date, the Hamas government is only economically bonded with the Ramallah-based Palestinian National Authority, performing the governing over the Gaza Strip independently.
@@ -139,5 +139,5 @@
 In mid-February, as the crisis escalated, Hamas rejected an [[Egypt]]ian proposal to bring in fuel via the Kerem Shalom Crossing between Israel and Gaza to reactivate Gaza's only power plant.  Ahmed Abu Al-Amreen of the Hamas-run Energy Authority refused it on the grounds that the crossing is operated by Israel and Hamas' fierce opposition to the existence of Israel. Egypt cannot ship [[diesel fuel]] to Gaza directly through the Rafah crossing point, because it is limited to the movement of individuals.<ref name="bloomberg.com"/>
 
-In early March, the head of Gaza's energy authority stated that Egypt wanted to transfer energy via the [[Kerem Shalom Crossing]], but he personally refused it to go through the "Zionist entity" (Israel) and insisted that Egypt transfer the fuel through the Rafah Crossing, although this crossing is not equipped to handle the half-million liters needed each day.<ref>{{cite web|author=محمد عنان |url=http://paltimes.net/details/news/11794.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140806015309/http://paltimes.net/details/news/11794.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-08-06 |title=فلسطين الآن : مصر ستزود غزة بالوقود لشهر والطاقة تبحث البدائل |publisher=Paltimes.net |date=2012-03-04 |access-date=2014-08-14 }}</ref>
+In early March, the head of Gaza's energy authority stated that Egypt wanted to transfer energy via the [[Kerem Shalom Crossing]], but he personally refused it to go through the "Zionist entity" (Israel) and insisted that Egypt transfer the fuel through the Rafah Crossing, although this crossing is not equipped to handle the half-million liters needed each day.<ref>{{cite web|author=محمد عنان |url=http://paltimes.net/details/news/11794.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140806015309/http://paltimes.net/details/news/11794.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-08-06 |title=فلسطين الآن : مصر ستزود غزة بالوقود لشهر والطاقة تبحث البدائل |publisher=Paltimes.net |date=2012-03-04 |access-date=2014-08-14 }}</ref>
 
 In late March, Hamas began offering carpools of Hamas state vehicles for people to get to work.  Many Gazans began to wonder how these vehicles have fuel themselves, as diesel was completely unavailable in Gaza, ambulances could no longer be used, but Hamas government officials still had fuel for their own cars. Many Gazans said that Hamas confiscated the fuel it needed from petrol stations and used it exclusively for their own purposes.<ref name="translate.google.com">{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&ie=CP1256&langpair=auto%7Cen&rurl=translate.google.com&tbb=1&twu=1&u=http://www.palpress.co.uk/arabic/%3Faction%3Ddetail%26id%3D43625|title=Google Translate|work=google.com}}</ref>
@@ -145,5 +145,5 @@
 <blockquote>Responded with another citizen of Rafah: 'Nude talk more about health crisis in Rafah and more exploited in the Drivers' Rafah ', while the other response more sharply, he said:' I wish, Lord, tells the story of Sheikh Eid any of these buses come from? , Is the bus power was to change the color and print the names and fake companies, good company, company Ailia, Islamic Society, as well as be confiscated diesel fuel from the stations and tunnels and traders, and is then to organize a campaign on behalf of Hamas to relieve citizens, but everyone knows ...... ., the story of diesel buses and the story of a failed attempt to improve the image of Hamas'</blockquote>
 
-Egypt agreed to provide 600,000 liters of fuel to Gaza daily, but it had no way of delivering it that Hamas would agree to.<ref>{{cite web|author=(1) undefined السبت, 18 فبراير, 2012 |url=http://paltimes.net/details/news/11090.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140806015311/http://paltimes.net/details/news/11090.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-08-06 |title=فلسطين الآن : نجيدة لـ"فلسطين الآن": مصر ستزود غزة بـ600 ألف لتر وقود يوميا |publisher=Paltimes.net |date=2012-02-18 |access-date=2014-08-14 }}</ref>
+Egypt agreed to provide 600,000 liters of fuel to Gaza daily, but it had no way of delivering it that Hamas would agree to.<ref>{{cite web|author=(1) undefined السبت, 18 فبراير, 2012 |url=http://paltimes.net/details/news/11090.html |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140806015311/http://paltimes.net/details/news/11090.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2014-08-06 |title=فلسطين الآن : نجيدة لـ"فلسطين الآن": مصر ستزود غزة بـ600 ألف لتر وقود يوميا |publisher=Paltimes.net |date=2012-02-18 |access-date=2014-08-14 }}</ref>
 
 In addition, Israel introduced a number of goods and vehicles into the Gaza Strip via the Kerem Shalom Crossing, as well as the normal diesel for hospitals. Israel also shipped 150,000 liters of diesel through the crossing, which was paid for by the [[Red Cross]].<ref name="translate.google.com"/>

@@ -44,5 +44,5 @@
 In addition, the militants took hostages from the kibbutz;<ref name="reuters" /><ref>{{Cite news |last=Logan |first=Nick |date=10 October 2023 |title=Why Hamas took so many people hostage — and how that complicates Israel's response |work=[[CBC News]]|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/israel-gaza-hamas-hostages-1.6991077 |access-date=10 October 2023 |archive-date=10 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231010190517/https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/israel-gaza-hamas-hostages-1.6991077 |url-status=live }}</ref> with the [[Associated Press]] visually confirming four hostages that were abducted on 7 October.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Federman |first=Josef |last2=Adwan |first2=Issam |date=7 October 2023 |title=Hamas surprise attack out of Gaza stuns Israel and leaves hundreds dead in fighting, retaliation |work=[[Associated Press]]|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-gaza-hamas-rockets-airstrikes-tel-aviv-11fb98655c256d54ecb5329284fc37d2 |access-date=11 October 2023 |archive-date=7 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231007073124/https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-gaza-hamas-rockets-airstrikes-tel-aviv-11fb98655c256d54ecb5329284fc37d2 |url-status=live }}</ref> Israeli Major General [[Itai Veruv]] described the massacre as a [[Terrorism|terror attack]].<ref name="reuters">{{Cite news |last=Lubell |first=Maayan |date=10 October 2023 |title=Bodies of residents and militants lie in the grounds of ravaged Israeli kibbutz|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/bodies-residents-militants-lie-grounds-ravaged-israeli-kibbutz-2023-10-10/ |access-date=10 October 2023 |archive-date=10 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231010155605/https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/bodies-residents-militants-lie-grounds-ravaged-israeli-kibbutz-2023-10-10/ |url-status=live }}</ref>
 
-Prior to the massacre, the community had 400 residents. It took the [[Israel Defense Forces]] two-and-a-half days to regain full control of the community after the initial attack.<ref name=":2" /> The paratroopers of Unit 71 led the assault to retake the community.<ref name="BBCOct1023Inside" /> 
+Prior to the massacre, the community had 400 residents. It took the [[Israel Defense Forces]] two-and-a-half days to regain full control of the community after the initial attack.<ref name=":2" /> The paratroopers of Unit 71 led the assault to retake the community,<ref name="BBCOct1023Inside" /> and the [[Duvdevan Unit]] had also responded to the attack.<ref name=":4" /> 
 
 Journalists were granted access to the site on 10 October 2023.<ref name="timesofisrael" /><ref name="reuters" /> Hamas has also released video footage of the attack.<ref>{{Cite news |date=10 October 2023 |title=Israel-Hamas War: Video shows Hamas militants attack on Kfar Aza kibbutz |work=[[Sky News]]|url=https://news.sky.com/video/israel-hamas-war-video-shows-hamas-militants-attack-on-kfar-aza-kibbutz-12982020 |access-date=11 October 2023 |archive-date=12 October 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231012193700/https://news.sky.com/video/israel-hamas-war-video-shows-hamas-militants-attack-on-kfar-aza-kibbutz-12982020 |url-status=live }}</ref>

@@ -7,6 +7,5 @@
 {{context|date=December 2023}}
 {{pp|small=yes}}
-
-'''Hamas genocide against Israelis''' refers to the accusation by some experts in the fields of [[international law]] and [[genocide studies]] that [[Hamas]], a [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] [[Islamism|Islamist]] group widely designated [[List of designated terrorist groups|a terrorist organization]], has committed [[genocide]] against [[Israelis]] in [[2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel|its surprise attack on Israel]] on 7 October 2023. In the course of the assault, Hamas militants raided communities in southern Israel, killing, torturing, and mutilating men, women, and children. The death toll reached 1,200, the majority of them [[Civilian casualty|civilians]]. 240 men, women and children of all ages were kidnapped and taken to the [[Gaza Strip]]. Some legal and genocide experts condemned the attack as a serious violation of international law, asserting that Hamas carried out these acts with the intent to destroy the Israeli national group. Commentators point to Hamas' [[1988 Hamas charter|founding charter]], which [[Calls for the destruction of Israel|advocated for the destruction of Israel]], features [[Antisemitism|antisemitic]] language, and, according to some researchers, also called for the genocide of Jews, suggesting that the attacks of October 7 were an attempt to fulfill this agenda.
+'''Hamas genocide against Israelis''' refers to the accusation by some experts in the fields of [[international law]] and [[genocide studies]] that [[Hamas]], a [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] [[Islamism|Islamist]] group widely designated [[List of designated terrorist groups|a terrorist organization]], committed [[genocide]] against [[Israelis]] in [[2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel|the attack it led on Israel]] on 7 October 2023. In the course of the Hamas-led assault, Palestinian militants attacked communities, a music festival, and military bases in the region of [[southern Israel]] known as the [[Gaza envelope]]. The attack, which has been described as a rampage of atrocities,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-05 |title=New signs emerge of 'widespread' sexual crimes by Hamas, as Netanyahu alleges global indifference |url=https://apnews.com/article/sexual-assault-hamas-oct-7-attack-rape-bb06b950bb6794affb8d468cd283bc51 |access-date=2023-12-19 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref> resulted in the deaths of nearly 1,200 people, two thirds of whom were [[Civilian casualty|civilians]]. 240 men, women and children of all ages were kidnapped and taken as hostages to the [[Gaza Strip]] in a clear violation of international law. Some commentators have suggested the attacks were carried out with genocidal intent, pointing to Hamas' [[1988 Hamas charter|founding charter]], which [[Calls for the destruction of Israel|advocated for the destruction of Israel]] and featured [[Antisemitism|antisemitic]] language.

@@ -620,5 +620,5 @@
 The [[Middle East Media Research Institute]] (MEMRI), a pro-Israel US based press monitoring organization<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2023/09/15/palestinian-authority-mahmoud-abbas-oslo-accords/|title=Mahmoud Abbas Holocaust Controversy Spotlights Deep Disillusion With Palestinian Authority|first=Alice|last=Speri|date=15 September 2023|website=The Intercept}}</ref>, published with English subtitles, part of an 24 August 2023 speech given by Palestinian President Mahmood Abbas to senior Fatah officials in Arabic. Abbas presented the fringe [[Khazar hypothesis of Ashkenazi ancestry]] as fact, [[Genocide_justification#The_Holocaust|justified]] the [[Nazi Holocaust]], and claimed that Israel forced [[Arab Jews|Jews from the Arab world]] to migrate to Israel during the [[Jewish exodus from the Muslim world]] against their will. This speech was condemned as [[anti-Semitic]] by Israel, the United States, France, and the European Union. It was unclear why diplomats issued statements only after MEMRI translated and published the claims that Abbas made, two weeks after Abbas made them.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/us-eu-slam-palestinian-presidents-remarks-holocaust-2023-09-07/|title=US and EU slam Palestinian president's remarks on Holocaust|date=7 September 2023|via=www.reuters.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Kingsley |first1=Patrick |title=Antisemitic Comments by Palestinian Leader Cause Uproar |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/09/07/world/middleeast/mahmoud-abbas-video-antisemitic.html |access-date=10 September 2023 |agency=New York Times |date=7 September 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Abbas: Ashkenazi Jews ‘are not Semites,’ Hitler killed them for their ‘social role’ |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/abbas-ashkenazi-jews-are-not-semites-hitler-killed-them-for-their-social-role/ |access-date=10 September 2023 |agency=Times of Israel |date=6 September 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Berman |first1=Lazar |last2=Magid |first2=Jacob |title=US antisemitism envoy and EU denounce Mahmoud Abbas’s speech: Distorts the Holocaust |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/eu-abbass-holocaust-speech-fuels-antisemitism-insults-holocaust-victims/ |agency=The Times of Israel |date=7 September 2023 |access-date=10 September 2023}}</ref>
 
-Reports by [[Haaretz]] and [[B’Tselem]] described the strip searching of five female members of a Palestinian family by two masked Israeli women soldiers in the West Bank city of Hebron in July. +Reports by [[Haaretz]] and [[B’Tselem]] described the strip searching of five female members of a Palestinian family by two masked Israeli women soldiers in the West Bank city of Hebron in July. The incident drew criticism from the UN and a call for a thorough investigation.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Soldiers enter homes of extended ‘Ajlouni family with dogs, separate children from their parents and steal items. Female soldiers strip search women |url=@https://www.btselem.org/routine_founded_on_violence/20230905_soldiers_enter_homes_of_extended_ajlouni_family_with_dogs_and_female_soldiers_strip_search_women|publisher= B'tselem}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/report-of-idf-strip-searching-palestinian-women-causes-uproar-draws-un-criticism/|title=Report of IDF strip-searching Palestinian women causes uproar, draws UN criticism|first=Gianluca|last=Pacchiani|website=www.timesofisrael.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-09-05/ty-article-magazine/.premium/in-hebron-raid-female-israeli-soldiers-forced-palestinian-women-to-undress/0000018a-6187-d895-ab8b-6fe7b7860000|title=Using an Attack Dog, Israeli Women Soldiers Forced Palestinian Women to Undress|via=Haaretz}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=UN calls on Israel to investigate forced strip-search of 5 Palestinian women|url=https://english.wafa.ps/Pages/Details/137487|publisher= WAFA}}</ref>

@@ -649,5 +649,5 @@
 
 ===24 September===
-Israeli forces killed two Palestinians during a raid on the [[Nur Shams]] refugee camp to destroy what the military said was a "a militant command center and bomb-storage facility in a building." The army said they were fired on and returned fire. <ref>https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-west-bank-military-gaza-yom-kippur-ba539fdd4b36b786cf55ba6a420a12cc</ref><ref>https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-09-24/ty-article/.premium/21-year-old-palestinian-reportedly-killed-in-exchange-of-fire-with-idf-in-west-bank/0000018a-c52f-da14-a1eb-dd2fd0cf0000</ref><ref>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/24/israel-kills-two-palestinians-amid-surge-in-military-raids?traffic_source=rss</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-760297|title=Israeli forces destroy war room, explosives in West Bank refugee camp|website=Jerusalem Post}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Israel kills two Palestinians amid surge in military raids |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/24/israel-kills-two-palestinians-amid-surge-in-military-raids |access-date=2023-09-24 |website=www.aljazeera.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Two Palestinians killed by Israeli occupation forces in Tulkarm |url=https://english.wafa.ps/Pages/Details/137736|access-date=2023-09-24 |website=WAFA Agency |language=en}}</ref>
+Israeli forces killed two Palestinians during a raid on the [[Nur Shams]] refugee camp to destroy what the military said was a "a militant command center and bomb-storage facility in a building." The army said they were fired on and returned fire. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-west-bank-military-gaza-yom-kippur-ba539fdd4b36b786cf55ba6a420a12cc|title=Israeli military raid kills 2 Palestinians in West Bank. Israel says its troops came under fire|date=24 September 2023|website=AP News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-09-24/ty-article/.premium/21-year-old-palestinian-reportedly-killed-in-exchange-of-fire-with-idf-in-west-bank/0000018a-c52f-da14-a1eb-dd2fd0cf0000|title=Two Palestinians Killed, Israeli Soldier Moderately Wounded in Exchange of Fire in West Bank|via=Haaretz}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/24/israel-kills-two-palestinians-amid-surge-in-military-raids|title=Israel kills two Palestinians amid surge in military raids|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-760297|title=Israeli forces destroy war room, explosives in West Bank refugee camp|website=Jerusalem Post}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Israel kills two Palestinians amid surge in military raids |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/9/24/israel-kills-two-palestinians-amid-surge-in-military-raids |access-date=2023-09-24 |website=www.aljazeera.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Two Palestinians killed by Israeli occupation forces in Tulkarm |url=https://english.wafa.ps/Pages/Details/137736|access-date=2023-09-24 |website=WAFA Agency |language=en}}</ref>

|url=https://apnews.com/article/gaza-humanitarian-un-bread-water-unrwa-fuel-90fcfc40d63f8604d0effa861e793c89 |access-date=4 November 2023 |work=[[AP News]] |language=en |archive-date=4 November 2023 |website=UNICEF |access-date=21 December 2023}}</ref>
 
 As of December 6, the sole water desalination facility in northern Gaza was inoperative, while the pipeline that delivers water from Israel to the north remained shut, thereby heightening the likelihood of dehydration and waterborne illnesses due to the consumption of unsafe water sources. The impact on hospitals has been severe, as only one out of the 24 hospitals in northern Gaza is operational and capable of accepting new patients, albeit with limited services, as of December 14.<ref name="HRW-2023-12-18"/>
@@ -58,9 +58,9 @@
 On 6 November, [[OCHA]] stated [[Disability|individuals with disabilities]] were suffering disproportionately due to the lack of accommodations in most shelters.<ref>{{cite news |title=Disabled in Gaza suffering disproportionate harm, aid groups warn |url=https://aje.io/91bdr3?update=2466477 |work=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=6 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121104157/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/6/israel-hamas-live-news-communications-blackout-across-gaza?update=2466477 |archive-date=21 November 2023}}</ref> UNRWA announced cases of respiratory infections, diarrhoea and chicken pox had been reported at its shelters.<ref>{{cite news |title=Diseases reported in crowded Gaza shelters |url=https://aje.io/91bdr3?update=2466385 |work=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=6 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231215223755/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/6/israel-hamas-live-news-communications-blackout-across-gaza?update=2466385 |archive-date=15 December 2023}}</ref> On 10 November, WHO stated infectious diseases, including diarrhea and chickenpox, were soaring across the Gaza Strip.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lodhi |first1=Areesha |title=How bad is Gaza's disease outbreak amid the Israel war? |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/11/10/how-bad-is-gazas-disease-outbreak-amid-the-israel-war |work=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=10 November 2023 |archive-date=10 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231110111932/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/11/10/how-bad-is-gazas-disease-outbreak-amid-the-israel-war |url-status=live}}</ref> OCHA stated [[waste management|accumulated waste]] in the streets risked the spread of airborne diseases and infestations of [[insect]]s and [[rat]]s.<ref>{{cite news |title=Accumulation of waste leading to insect infestation: UN |url=https://aje.io/jmh2l8?update=2479805 |work=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=11 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121140614/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/11/israel-hamas-war-live-pleas-for-help-as-israel-bombards-gaza-hospitals?update=2479805 |archive-date=21 November 2023}}</ref> Doctors reported that due to a lack of fresh water and [[iodine]], patients wounds were often infested with [[maggot]]s.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Harouda |first1=Ameera |last2=Abi-Habib |first2=Maria |last3=Abu Bakr |first3=Bashir |title=As Gaza Hospitals Collapse, Medical Workers Face the Hardest Choices |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=6 November 2023 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/06/world/middleeast/gaza-hospitals-israel-war.html |access-date=12 November 2023 |archive-date=11 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231111201344/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/06/world/middleeast/gaza-hospitals-israel-war.html |url-status=live}}</ref>
 
-Raw sewage overflowed in the streets, creating a health and [[environmental disaster]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Sewage Is Flowing into the Streets because Pumps Don't Have Electricity |url=https://calgaryherald.com/news/israel-middle-east-israel-hamas-war-day-38 |work=[[Calgary Herald]] |access-date=14 November 2023 |archive-date=18 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231118052853/https://calgaryherald.com/news/israel-middle-east-israel-hamas-war-day-38 |url-status=live}}</ref> On 8 November, the World Health Organization stated that since the start of the conflict, 33,551 cases of diarrhea had been reported, 8,944 cases of [[scabies]] and [[lice]], 1,005 cases of chickenpox, 12,635 cases of [[skin rash]] and 54,866 cases of [[upper respiratory infection]]s.<ref>{{cite web |title=Risk of disease spread soars in Gaza as health facilities, water and sanitation systems disrupted |url=https://www.emro.who.int/media/news/risk-of-disease-spread-soars-in-gaza-as-health-facilities-water-and-sanitation-systems-disrupted.html |website=[[World Health Organization]] |access-date=15 November 2023 |archive-date=15 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231115035156/https://www.emro.who.int/media/news/risk-of-disease-spread-soars-in-gaza-as-health-facilities-water-and-sanitation-systems-disrupted.html |url-status=live}}</ref> On 17 November, WHO updated these numbers, stating there were 70,000 cases of acute respiratory infections and over 44,000 cases of diarrhea, which were significantly higher than expected.<ref>{{cite news |title=WHO voices concern over spread of disease in Gaza |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/who-voices-concern-over-spread-disease-gaza-2023-11-17/ |work=[[Reuters]] |access-date=17 November 2023 |archive-date=17 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231117110354/https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/who-voices-concern-over-spread-disease-gaza-2023-11-17/ |url-status=live}}</ref> [[UNICEF]] warned the worsening sanitation situation threatened a mass disease outbreak.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gaza Sanitation 'Perfect Storm For Tragedy': UN |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/gaza-sanitation-perfect-storm-for-tragedy-un-01c8acfe |website=[[Barron's]] |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |access-date=21 November 2023  On 28 November, WHO stated more Palestinians risked dying from disease than bombings.<ref>{{cite news |title=More Palestinians at risk of death from disease than bombings: WHO's warning |url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/more-palestinians-at-risk-of-death-from-disease-than-bombings-whos-warning-101701167334463.html |work=[[The Hindustan Times]] |date=28 November 2023  In his address to the UN Security Council on 31 January 2024, Martin Griffiths, the UN under-secretary general for humanitarian affairs and emergency relief coordination, provided a comprehensive overview of the challenges currently confronting numerous individuals in Gaza. According to our latest estimates, approximately 75 percent of the entire population has been displaced. The living conditions they endure are deplorable and deteriorating with each passing day. The makeshift tent camps, established by refugees and displaced people, are being inundated by heavy rains, compelling children, parents, and the elderly to seek shelter in the mud. The issue of food insecurity continues to escalate, while access to clean water remains almost entirely unattainable. Given the limited availability of public health support, preventable diseases are rampant and will persistently propagate.<ref>[https://lordslibrary.parliament.uk/humanitarian-situation-in-gaza/ Humanitarian impact of the conflict] Retrieved 13 February 2024</ref>

 On 1 December, Israel labelled [[Khan Younis]] a "dangerous combat zone."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ayyoub |first1=Loay |title=Leaflets dropped in south Gaza declare Khan Younis a 'dangerous combat zone' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/11/30/israel-hamas-war-news-gaza-hostages-update-palestine/#link-6YZ2QKUC4NDOLHZUIOEPOGV2ZY |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=1 December 2023}}</ref> It issued a map of numbered zones, dividing the Gaza Strip into hundreds of different districts.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sulliman |first1=Adela |title=IDF issues civilian 'evacuation zone map' for first time, it says |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/11/30/israel-hamas-war-news-gaza-hostages-update-palestine/#link-AZR2NLHJ3VHJTN3XFBP335G7NY |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=1 December 2023}}</ref> It also issued an [[2023 Gaza Strip evacuations#Southern Gaza evacuations|evacuation order in southern Gaza]] for residents to |url=https://www.cnn.com/middleeast/live-news/israel-hamas-war-gaza-news-12-1-23/h_77680d2ed2b85a0990d9b86e0f619d5d |work=[[CNN]] |access-date=1 December 2023}}</ref> At the same time it issued the |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/11/30/israel-hamas-war-news-gaza-hostages-update-palestine/#link-M7XOCRHICJBBVKQQ3XCITPB7HM |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=1 December |title=UNRWA Situation Report #47 on the situation in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, including East Jerusalem |url=https://www.un.org/unispal/document/unrwa-situation-report-47-dec8-2023/ |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/gaza-faces-public-health-disaster-un-humanitarian-office-says-2023-12-13/#:~:text=Hasting%20said%20that%20almost%20half,health%20crisis%2C%22%20she%20said. |website=Reuters |access-date=14 December 2023}}</ref> On 21 December, a ''[[Financial Times]]'' analysis found Israel had left northern Gaza virtually uninhabitable.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Srivastava |first1=Mehul |last2=Smith |first2=Alan |title=Visual analysis: the wastelands in Gaza's two biggest cities |url=https://www.ft.com/content/4c66a9fd-b444-4aa2-8a63-b8f043c3e4a5?shareType=nongift |website=Financial Times |access-date=22 December 2023}}</ref> On 6 January 2024, UN humanitarian chief Martin Griffiths stated that Gaza had "simply become uninhabitable".<ref>{{cite web |title=Gaza Bombardments Intensify, 'There Is No Safe Place in Gaza', Humanitarian Affairs Chief Warns Security Council |url=https://press.un.org/en/2024/sc15564.doc.htm |work=United Nations |date=12 January  == Communications ==
 {{See also|Communications in the State of Palestine}}
-On 27 October, Gaza underwent a near total [[communications blackout]] after [[Paltel Group|Paltel]]'s [[Radio masts and towers|communication towers]] were destroyed in an Israeli attack.<ref name="The Destruction of Gaza’s Internet">{{cite magazine |last1=Burgess |first1=Matt |title=The Destruction of Gaza's Internet Is Complete |url=https://www.wired.com/story/gaza-internet-blackout-israel/ |magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |access-date=28 October 2023 |archive-date=27 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231027234505/https://www.wired.com/story/gaza-internet-blackout-israel/ |url-status=live}}</ref> This cut off Gaza from any phone or internet service.<ref>{{cite news |title=Near-total internet and cellular blackout hits Gaza as Israel ramps up strikes |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/internet-blackout-hits-gaza-israel-ramps-strikes-rcna122531 |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=27 October 2023 |access-date=28 October 2023 |archive-date=27  The plight of Gaza's premature babies gained global attention.<ref>{{cite news |title=Premature babies evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital, health officials say |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/israel-hamas-war-gaza-day-44-1.7033192 |work=[[CBC]] |access-date=19 November 2023 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> In late October, Gaza's premature babies faced a critical situation as [[Medical Aid for Palestinians]] and [[UNICEF]] warned that 130 infants were at risk of death due to a hospital fuel shortage caused by Israel's siege.<ref name="Medical Aid for Palestinians"/><ref name="aljazeera.com"/> The lack of fuel led to power outages, endangering premature babies in neonatal intensive care units (NICUs).<ref name="abcnews.go.com"/><ref name="ABC News"/> Despite assurances from the IDF to assist in evacuations, the [[Gaza Health Ministry]] reported a lack of evacuation mechanisms, resulting in the deaths of several infants.<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/><ref name="aje.io"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Yee |first1=Vivian |title=Premature Babies Are Evacuated From Embattled Hospital in Gaza |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=19 November 2023 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/19/world/middleeast/premature-babies-al-shifa-hospital-gaza-evacuation.html#:~:text=Since%20Nov.%2011%2C%20at%20least,for%20more%20than%20a%20week. |access-date=19 November 2023 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref>

 On 7 January, UN chief Antonio Guterres stated "widespread famine looms" in Gaza,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Andres |first1=Paula |title=Israeli strikes kill 7 civilians in West Bank, 2 journalists in Gaza |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/israel-west-bank-journalists-gaza-hamas/#:~:text=Adding%20to%20a%20growing%20death,Security%20Council%20members%20Friday%20evening. |work=[[Politico]] |date=7 January 2024 |access-date=8 January 2024}}</ref> to which the UN special rapporteur for health [[Tlaleng Mofokeng]] stated Gaza was experiencing "deliberate starvation not famine".<ref>{{cite news |title='Deliberate starvation not famine': UN human rights expert |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/7/israel-war-on-gaza-live-signs-of-starvation-everywhere-in-southern-gaza?update=2601737 |work=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=8 January 2024}}</ref> Speaking at the [[United Nations Security Council]] on 12 January, Martin Griffiths stated colleagues who had made it into northern Gaza in recent days had described "scenes of utter horror: Corpses left lying in the road. Britain has a plan to help that happen |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2024/jan/11/israel-aid-gaza-britain-crossings-water-united-nations-food |website=The Guardian |date=11 January 2024 |access-date=13 January 2024}}</ref> [[United Nations General Assembly|UNGA]] president [[Dennis Francis (diplomat)|Dennis Francis]] asked, "How much is enough?"<ref>{{cite web |title=Carnage in Gaza: 'How much is enough?' asks UN Assembly President |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2024/01/1145712 |website=UN News |date=19 January 2024 |publisher=[[United Nations]] |access-date=20 January 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref>
 
-On 20 January, Antonio Guterres stated, "People in Gaza are dying not only from bombs and bullets, but from lack of food & clean water, and hospitals without power & medicine."<ref>{{cite news |title=Guterres cataloga de "inaceptable" la negativa israelí de admitir un Estado palestino |language=es |trans-title=Guterres calls Israel's refusal to admit a Palestinian state "unacceptable" |url=https://www.france24.com/es/medio-oriente/20240120-guterres-cataloga-de-inaceptable-la-negativa-israelí-de-admitir-un-estado-palestino |work=[[France24]] |date=20 January 2024 |access-date=21 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240219080902/https://www.france24.com/es/medio-oriente/20240120-guterres-cataloga-de-inaceptable-la-negativa-israel%C3%AD-de-admitir-un-estado-palestino |archive-date=19 February 2024}}</ref> On 27 January, Martin Griffiths stated, "The people of Gaza have been enduring unthinkable horrors and deprivation for close to four months. Their needs have never been higher."<ref>{{cite news |title=UN humanitarian chief says it is 'not the time' to deprive people in Gaza of assistance |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/27/israels-war-on-gaza-live-hospital-blackout-amid-khan-younis-assault?update=2653822 |work=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=28 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240128015258/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/27/israels-war-on-gaza-live-hospital-blackout-amid-khan-younis-assault?update=2653822 |archive-date=28 January 2024}}</ref> On 30 January, the [[UN Security Council]] issued a statement saying it was worried about the "dire and rapidly deteriorating humanitarian situation".<ref>{{cite news |title=UN Security Council says worried by 'dire and rapidly deteriorating' conditions in Gaza |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/un-security-council-says-worried-by-dire-and-rapidly-deteriorating-conditions-in-gaza/ |work=[[Times of Israel]] |agency=[[Reuters]] |access-date=31 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240131042929/https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/un-security-council-says-worried-by-dire-and-rapidly-deteriorating-conditions-in-gaza/ |archive-date=31 January 2024}}</ref> On 7 February, Martin Griffiths stated, "More than half of Gaza’s population is now crammed in Rafah, a town of originally 250,000 people right on Egypt’s doorstep. Their living conditions are abysmal – they lack the basic necessities to survive, stalked by hunger, disease and death."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Griffith |first1=Martin |title=UN relief chief: As crisis enters fifth month, further fighting in Rafah risks claiming more lives and exacerbating humanitarian needs |url=https://www.unocha.org/news/un-relief-chief-crisis-enters-fifth-month-further-fighting-rafah-risks-claiming-more-lives-and#:~:text=More%20than%20half%20of%20Gaza%27s,by%20hunger%2C%20disease%20and%20death. |website=[[OCHA]] |publisher=[[United Nations]] |access-date=8 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240221221146/https://www.unocha.org/news/un-relief-chief-crisis-enters-fifth-month-further-fighting-rafah-risks-claiming-more-lives-and |archive-date=21 February 2024}}</ref> On 10 February, António Guterres stated an Israeli assault on [[Rafah]] would "exponentially increase what is already a humanitarian nightmare".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Zaanoun |first1=Adel |title=Strikes On Gaza's Rafah As US Warns Of Potential 'Disaster' |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/strikes-on-gaza-s-rafah-as-us-warns-of-potential-disaster-077b447d |website=[[Barron's]] |access-date=11 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240219080903/https://www.barrons.com/news/strikes-on-gaza-s-rafah-as-us-warns-of-potential-disaster-077b447d |archive-date=19 February 2024}}</ref> On 21 February, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated the situation in Gaza was inhumane and described it as a death zone.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gaza Humanitarian Situation 'Inhumane': WHO |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/gaza-humanitarian-situation-inhumane-who-2c97d982 |website=[[Barron's]] |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |access-date=22 February 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref>

 Israeli Major General (ret.)  The United States UN representative [[Linda Thomas-Greenfield]] vetoed a [[UN Security Council]] resolution that would have urged humanitarian aid to Gaza, saying it was too early to craft a resolution and criticising the one proposed for failing to support Israel's right to self-defence.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lederer |first1=Edith |title=US vetoes UN resolution condemning Hamas' attacks on Israel and all violence against civilians |url=https://apnews.com/article/un-security-council-resolution-gaza-hamas-1c23913f8552f5379b2c158a83493835 |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=18 October 2023 |access-date=18 October 2023}}</ref> In a ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' op-ed, conservative American commentator [[Daniel Henninger]] speculated Hamas wanted to create a humanitarian crisis for publicity purposes.<ref>{{cite news |last=Henninger |first=Daniel |date=15 November 2023 |title=Gaza Is the First Humanitarian-Crisis War |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-first-humanitarian-crisis-war-israel-al-shifa-hospital-hamas-6c108eee |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |access-date=20 November 2023}}</ref> US Senator [[Chris Van Hollen]] stated "political decisions by the Netanyahu coalition" were delaying the delivery of aid into Gaza.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nazarro |first1=Miranda |title=Van Hollen agrees Israel should face 'consequences' over Gaza aid, civilian deaths |url=https://thehill.com/policy/international/4394248-van-hollen-agrees-israel-should-face-consequences-over-gaza-aid-civilian-deaths/#:~:text=“There%20are%20two%20big%20things,Netanyahu%20coalition%2C”%20he%20said. |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=7 January 2024 |access-date=8 January 2024}}</ref>
