-On 9 January 2024, British Foreign Secretary [[David Cameron]] admitted he is "worried" that Israel has "taken action that might be in breach of international law", saying he wanted Israel to restore water supplies to Gaza.<ref>{{cite news |title=David Cameron squirms as he's confronted over Israeli 'war crimes' |url=https://www.thenational.scot/news/24038357.david-cameron-squirms-confronted-israeli-war-crimes/ |work=The National |date=9 January 2024}}</ref> Cameron stated on 26 January, "The scale of suffering in Gaza is unimaginable".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Landler |first1=Mark |title=Britain's Foreign Secretary Pressures Netanyahu on More Aid for Gaza |work=The New York Times |date=24 January 2024 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/25/world/middleeast/cameron-israel-gaza-netanyahu.html |access-date=26 January 2024}}</ref> [[Sarah Champion]], a Labor MP, stated, "I find it utterly wicked and immoral that international conventions [in Gaza] are not being respected, particularly when it comes to medical facilities".<ref>{{cite web |title=UK parliament select committee holds hearing on healthcare situation in Gaza |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/10/israels-war-on-gaza-us-laments-gaza-deaths-but-opposes-ceasefire?update=2607446 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=11 January 2024}}</ref> Chinese foreign minister [[Wang Yi (politician)|Wang Yi]] stated, "We cannot allow this humanitarian disaster to continue".<ref>{{cite web |title=China’s top diplomat: Fighting in Gaza root cause of Red Sea tensions |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/17/israels-war-on-gaza-live-icj-warns-of-perilous-situation-in-rafah?update=2713821 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=18 February 2024}}</ref> [[Yousef Al Otaiba]], the UAE ambassador to the United States, called for a ceasefire, writing, "Half of the people are [[Gaza Strip famine|starving]]. The medical system has [[Timeline of the Gaza Strip healthcare collapse|collapsed]]. Safe water is scarce. An impending [[Rafah offensive|Israeli offensive]] will displace millions."<ref>{{cite web |title=UAE calls for immediate ceasefire and aid to Gaza |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/18/israels-war-on-gaza-live-palestinians-fleeing-rafah-face-israeli-strikes?update=2716642 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=19 February 2024}}</ref> Speaking about [[Rafah]], a German government spokesperson stated on 19 February 2024 that although the full scope of the crisis was difficult to assess, "Everyone recognizes that it is catastrophic."<ref>{{cite web |title=German government deeply concerned about planned Rafah offensive |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/german-government-deeply-concerned-about-planned-rafah-offensive/ |website=The Times of Israel |publisher=Reuters |access-date=21 February 2024}}</ref> [[William, Prince of Wales]] stated, "There is a desperate need for increased humanitarian support to Gaza."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Syed |first1=Armani |title=Prince William Calls for End to Fighting in Gaza ‘as Soon as Possible’ in Rare Statement |url=https://time.com/6696660/prince-william-gaza/ |website=Time Magazine |access-date=21 February 2024}}</ref>
+On 9 January 2024, British Foreign Secretary [[David Cameron]] admitted he is "worried" that Israel has "taken action that might be in breach of international law", saying he wanted Israel to restore water supplies to Gaza.<ref>{{cite news |title=David Cameron squirms as he's confronted over Israeli 'war crimes' |url=https://www.thenational.scot/news/24038357.david-cameron-squirms-confronted-israeli-war-crimes/ |work=The National |date=9 January 2024}}</ref> Cameron stated on 26 January, "The scale of suffering in Gaza is unimaginable".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Landler |first1=Mark |title=Britain's Foreign Secretary Pressures Netanyahu on More Aid for Gaza |work=The New York Times |date=24 January 2024 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/25/world/middleeast/cameron-israel-gaza-netanyahu.html |access-date=26 January 2024}}</ref> [[Sarah Champion]], a Labor MP, stated, "I find it utterly wicked and immoral that international conventions [in Gaza] are not being respected, particularly when it comes to medical facilities".<ref>{{cite web |title=UK parliament select committee holds hearing on healthcare situation in Gaza |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/10/israels-war-on-gaza-us-laments-gaza-deaths-but-opposes-ceasefire?update=2607446 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=11 January 2024}}</ref> Chinese foreign minister [[Wang Yi (politician)|Wang Yi]] stated, "We cannot allow this humanitarian disaster to continue".<ref>{{cite news |title=China’s top diplomat: Fighting in Gaza root cause of Red Sea tensions |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/17/israels-war-on-gaza-live-icj-warns-of-perilous-situation-in-rafah?update=2713821 |work=[[Al Jazeera Englsih|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=18 February 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> [[Yousef Al Otaiba]], the UAE ambassador to the United States, called for a ceasefire, writing, "Half of the people are [[Gaza Strip famine|starving]]. The medical system has [[Timeline of the Gaza Strip healthcare collapse|collapsed]]. Safe water is scarce. An impending [[Rafah offensive|Israeli offensive]] will displace millions."<ref>{{cite news |title=UAE calls for immediate ceasefire and aid to Gaza |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/18/israels-war-on-gaza-live-palestinians-fleeing-rafah-face-israeli-strikes?update=2716642 |work=[[Al Jazeera Englsih|Al Jazeera]] |access-date=19 February 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> Speaking about [[Rafah]], a German government spokesperson stated on 19 February 2024 that although the full scope of the crisis was difficult to assess, "Everyone recognizes that it is catastrophic."<ref>{{cite news |title=German government deeply concerned about planned Rafah offensive |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/german-government-deeply-concerned-about-planned-rafah-offensive/ |work=[[Times of Israel]] |agency=[[Reuters]] |access-date=21 February 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> [[William, Prince of Wales]] stated, "There is a desperate need for increased humanitarian support to Gaza."<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Syed |first1=Armani |title=Prince William Calls for End to Fighting in Gaza 'as Soon as Possible' in Rare Statement |url=https://time.com/6696660/prince-william-gaza/ |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |access-date=21 February 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref>
 
 ===Resolution efforts===
-In a call on 20 November, Chinese President [[Xi Jinping]] and French President [[Emmanuel Macron]] discussed measures to avoid the humanitarian crisis from getting worse.<ref>{{cite web |title=Xi, Macron Discuss Israel-Hamas War In Call: State Media |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/xi-macron-discuss-israel-hamas-war-in-call-state-media-f50d4375 |website=Barron's |publisher=Agence France Presse |access-date=20 November 2023}}</ref> In Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on November 11, 2023, the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]] and the [[Arab League]] held an [[Arab Islamic extraordinary summit 2023|emergency meeting on the Gaza humanitarian crisis]] created by the war.<ref>Al Arabiya reporters. (11 November 2023). "Arab, Muslim leaders slam Israel at Saudi-hosted summit on Gaza
-". [https://english.alarabiya.net/News/saudi-arabia/2023/11/11/Extraordinary-joint-Islamic-Arab-summit-on-Gaza-conflict-kicks-off-in-Saudi-Arabia Al Arabiya English] Retrieved 24 November 2023.</ref> On 5 December, Cyprus President [[Nikos Christodoulides]] visited Egypt and Jordan in attempt to establish a humanitarian aid corridor to Gaza.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-12-04 |title=Cyprus pushes Gaza corridor idea; leader to visit Egypt, Jordan |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/cyprus-pushes-gaza-corridor-idea-leader-visit-egypt-jordan-2023-12-04/ |access-date=2023-12-05}}</ref> The UN appointed [[Sigrid Kaag]] in the newly created position of senior humanitarian and reconstruction coordinator for Gaza.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dutch diplomat Sigrid Kaag takes up post as UN Gaza humanitarian, reconstruction coordinator |url=https://global.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202401/09/WS659ca546a3105f21a507b461.html |website=China Daily |publisher=Xinhua |access-date=10 January 2024}}</ref>
+In a call on 20 November, Chinese President [[Xi Jinping]] and French President [[Emmanuel Macron]] discussed measures to avoid the humanitarian crisis from getting worse.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Xi, Macron Discuss Israel-Hamas War In Call: State Media |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/xi-macron-discuss-israel-hamas-war-in-call-state-media-f50d4375 |magazine=[[Barron's]] |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |access-date=20 November 2023 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> In Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on November 11, 2023, the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation]] and the [[Arab League]] held an [[Arab Islamic extraordinary summit 2023|emergency meeting on the Gaza humanitarian crisis]] created by the war.<ref>{{cite news |date=11 November 2023 |title=Arab, Muslim leaders slam Israel at Saudi-hosted summit on Gaza
+|url=https://english.alarabiya.net/News/saudi-arabia/2023/11/11/Extraordinary-joint-Islamic-Arab-summit-on-Gaza-conflict-kicks-off-in-Saudi-Arabia |work=[[Al Arabiya English]] |access-date=24 November 2023 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> On 5 December, Cyprus President [[Nikos Christodoulides]] visited Egypt and Jordan in attempt to establish a humanitarian aid corridor to Gaza.<ref>{{Cite news |date=4 December 2023 |title=Cyprus pushes Gaza corridor idea; leader to visit Egypt, Jordan |language=en |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/cyprus-pushes-gaza-corridor-idea-leader-visit-egypt-jordan-2023-12-04/ |access-date=5 December 2023 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> The UN appointed [[Sigrid Kaag]] in the newly created position of senior humanitarian and reconstruction coordinator for Gaza.<ref>{{cite news |title=Dutch diplomat Sigrid Kaag takes up post as UN Gaza humanitarian, reconstruction coordinator |url=https://global.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202401/09/WS659ca546a3105f21a507b461.html |work=[[China Daily]] |publisher=[[Xinhua]] |access-date=10 January 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref>
 
 On December 6, [[United Nations]] [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|secretary-general]] [[António Guterres]] invoked Article 99 of the [[Charter of the United Nations|UN Charter]], that is: "The Secretary-General may bring to the attention of the Security Council any matter which in his opinion may threaten the maintenance of international peace and security."<ref>{{Cite web |title=Repertory of Practice of United Nations Organs — Codification Division Publications |url=https://legal.un.org/repertory/art99.shtml |access-date=2023-12-08 |website=legal.un.org |language=EN}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Nichols |first=Michelle |date=2023-12-07 |title=UN chief rings alarm bell on global security threat from Gaza war |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/un-chief-rings-alarm-bell-global-security-threat-gaza-war-2023-12-06/ |access-date=2023-12-08}}</ref> Guterres cited the situation as a threat to "international peace and security" and “a severe risk of collapse of the humanitarian system" which he argued have irreversible impacts for Palestinians.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-06 |title=Gaza: Guterres invokes 'most powerful tool' Article 99, in bid for humanitarian ceasefire {{!}} UN News |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/12/1144447 |access-date=2023-12-08 |website=news.un.org |language=en}}</ref> By invoking Article 99, Guterres is pushing the [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]] to call for a cease fire.<ref>{{Cite web |title=UN secretary-general invokes Article 99 on Gaza in rare, powerful move |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/12/7/un-secretary-general-invokes-article-99-on-gaza |access-date=2023-12-08 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

[https://today.lorientlejour.com/article/1357811/what-we-know-about-hezbollahs-elite-al-radwan-unit.html Here's what we know about Hezbollah's elite al-Radwan unit] today.lorientlejour.com</ref><br />{{flagicon image|Flag_of_the_Muslim_Brotherhood_(2).png}} [[Fajr Forces]]<ref name = national>{{cite web|url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2023/10/30/fajr-forces-hezbollah-lebanon-israel/|access-date=2023-11-12|title='We're with the resistance': Hezbollah allies the Fajr Forces join Lebanon-Israel front|website=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|date=2023-10-31|author=Nada Homsi}}</ref><br />{{flagicon image|Flag_of_the_Syrian_Social_Nationalist_Party.svg}} [[Eagles of the Whirlwind]]<ref>{{Cite web |title=الوكالة الوطنية للإعلام - القومي أعلن استشهاد أحد مقاتليه وسام محمد سليم |url=https://www.nna-leb.gov.lb/ar/%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A9/662898 |access-date=2023-12-16 |website=الوكالة الوطنية للإعلام |language=ar}}</ref><br />{{flagicon image|Flag_of_the_Army_of_the_Guardians_of_the_Islamic_Revolution.svg}} [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]]<ref>{{cite news |title=Two Revolutionary Guards members killed by Israeli strike in Syria, says Iran |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/dec/02/iran-revolutionary-guards-members-killed-israeli-strike-syria |access-date=25 December 2023 |work=The Guardian |date=2 December 2023}}</ref><br>{{flagicon image|Flag_of_the_Syrian_Arab_Army.svg}} [[Syrian Army]]<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/iran-update-october-25-2023 | title=Institute for the Study of War }}</ref><hr>{{flagicon image|Flag_of_the_Islamic_Jihad_Movement_in_Palestine.svg}} [[Al-Quds Brigades]]<br />{{flagicon image|Flag of Hamas.svg}} [[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades]]

@@ -95,5 +95,5 @@
 Lebanese state media reported that Dhayra and other areas along the western section of the border came under "continuous" bombardment overnight.<ref>{{cite news |date=17 October 2023 |title=Israel thwarts infiltration bid from Lebanon, killing four: army |work=[[France 24]] |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231017-israel-thwarts-infiltration-bid-from-lebanon-killing-four-army |url-status=live |access-date=17 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017163043/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231017-israel-thwarts-infiltration-bid-from-lebanon-killing-four-army |archive-date=17 October 2023}}</ref> In the early morning it was reported that multiple people were suffering from symptoms of suffocation after the IDF allegedly fired white phosphorus shells on the village.<ref>{{Cite web |date=17 October 2023 |title=At least four killed in Lebanon near Israel border, Red Cross says |url=https://efe.com/en/latest-news/2023-10-17/at-least-four-killed-in-lebanon-near-israel-border-red-cross-says/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231018003609/https://efe.com/en/latest-news/2023-10-17/at-least-four-killed-in-lebanon-near-israel-border-red-cross-says/ |archive-date=18 October 2023 |access-date=17 October 2023 |website=EFE Noticias |language=en-US}}</ref> Three people were injured after an anti-tank missile from Lebanon landed in the Israeli town of [[Metula]].<ref>{{cite news |date=17 October 2023 |title=Clashes erupt again on the Lebanon-Israel border after an anti-tank missile is fired from Lebanon |work=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://apnews.com/article/lebanon-israel-hezbollah-clashes-cadccde8c6ce5400ee36fd12d3bfea52 |url-status=live |access-date=17 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017102326/https://apnews.com/article/lebanon-israel-hezbollah-clashes-cadccde8c6ce5400ee36fd12d3bfea52 |archive-date=17 October 2023}}</ref> The IDF said it had killed four would-be infiltrators along the Lebanese border as they attempted to plant bombs on the border wall.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Israeli army says 4 killed trying to infiltrate into Israel from Lebanon |url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/israeli-army-says-4-killed-trying-to-infiltrate-into-israel-from-lebanon/3022690 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017131045/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/israeli-army-says-4-killed-trying-to-infiltrate-into-israel-from-lebanon/3022690 |archive-date=17 October 2023 |access-date=17 October 2023 |website=[[Anadolu Agency]]}}</ref> Hezbollah announced that five of its members were killed on the same day but it was unclear if any had involvement in the border infiltration.<ref>{{Cite news |date=17 October 2023 |title=Lebanon-Israel border clashes escalate, 5 Hezbollah fighters killed |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-military-says-killed-four-people-who-tried-infiltrate-lebanon-plant-2023-10-17/ |url-status=live |access-date=17 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231017164644/https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-military-says-killed-four-people-who-tried-infiltrate-lebanon-plant-2023-10-17/ |archive-date=17 October 2023}}</ref>
 
-On 19 October, the [[Lebanese army]] said that one was killed and another injured after a group of seven Iranian journalists were targeted with machine guns by Israel, although Iranian state media denied the claim and said that all its journalists were "alive and healthy".<ref>{{Cite web |date=20 October 2023 |title=Lebanese army says Israel killed member of 'journalist team' |url=https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231021183736/https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |archive-date=21 October 2023 |access-date=20 October 2023 |work=The New Arab |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":32">{{Cite web |date=20 October 2023 |title=Second journalist killed by Israel fire in Lebanon |url=https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231021183736/https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |archive-date=21 October 2023 |access-date=20 October 2023 |work=The New Arab |language=en}}</ref> UNIFIL peacekeepers said that one person was killed after civilians were caught in a cross-fire at the border in which the Lebanese Army requested assistance by UNIFIL to deescalate the situation. It was requested to Israel to suspend fire "to facilitate the rescue operation".<ref>{{Cite web |date=19 October 2023 |title=Lebanon army says Israel killed member of 'journalist team' |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231019-un-says-one-killed-in-cross-border-fire-in-south-lebanon |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231020011313/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231019-un-says-one-killed-in-cross-border-fire-in-south-lebanon |archive-date=20 October 2023 |access-date=20 October 2023 |website=France 24 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":32" />
+On 19 October, the [[Lebanese army]] said that one was killed and another injured after a group of seven Iranian journalists were targeted with machine guns by Israel, although Iranian state media denied the claim and said that all its journalists were "alive and healthy".<ref>{{Cite web |date=20 October 2023 |title=Lebanese army says Israel killed member of 'journalist team' |url=https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231021183736/https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |archive-date=21 October 2023 |access-date=20 October 2023 |work=The New Arab |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":322">{{Cite web |date=20 October 2023 |title=Second journalist killed by Israel fire in Lebanon |url=https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231021183736/https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |archive-date=21 October 2023 |access-date=20 October 2023 |work=The New Arab |language=en}}</ref> UNIFIL peacekeepers said that one person was killed after civilians were caught in a cross-fire at the border in which the Lebanese Army requested assistance by UNIFIL to deescalate the situation. It was requested to Israel to suspend fire "to facilitate the rescue operation".<ref>{{Cite web |date=19 October 2023 |title=Lebanon army says Israel killed member of 'journalist team' |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231019-un-says-one-killed-in-cross-border-fire-in-south-lebanon |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231020011313/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231019-un-says-one-killed-in-cross-border-fire-in-south-lebanon |archive-date=20 October 2023 |access-date=20 October 2023 |website=France 24 |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":322"/>
 
 In the early afternoon of 21 October, several rockets were fired from Lebanon toward the Shebaa Farms; there were no injuries. The IDF conducted a drone strike on the team of militants that launched the rockets.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fabian |first=Emanuel |title=Anti-tank missile fired at Israeli village on Lebanese border; drone strike hits launchers |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/anti-tank-missile-fired-at-israeli-village-on-lebanese-border-drone-strike-hits-launchers/ |access-date=24 October 2023 |website=The Times of Israel |language=en-US}}</ref> A short while later, anti-tank guided missiles were fired from Lebanon toward Margaliot and [[Hanita]]; two foreign workers were injured. The IDF conducted airstrikes against the missile teams.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fabian |first=Emanuel |title=IDF video shows airstrike against missile squad on Lebanese border |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/idf-video-shows-airstrike-against-missile-squad-on-lebanese-border/ |access-date=24 October 2023 |work=The Times of Israel |language=en-US}}</ref> In the evening, another anti-tank guided missile was fired from Lebanon toward [[Bar'am]]. One IDF soldier was seriously injured and two others were lightly injured. The IDF responded with several airstrikes in southern Lebanon, some of which targeted other missile teams preparing attacks.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fabian |first=Emanuel |date=22 October 2023 |title=IDF hits Hezbollah posts in south Lebanon, says soldier seriously hurt in missile attack |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/idf-hits-hezbollah-posts-in-south-lebanon-says-soldier-seriously-hurt-in-missile-attack/ |access-date=24 October 2023 |work=The Times of Israel |language=en-US}}</ref>
@@ -116,5 +116,5 @@
 The [[Amal Movement]], an ally of Hezbollah, announced that a fighter was killed in a missile attack in the village of [[Rab El Thalathine]] which also wounded two other members in November 11.<ref>{{Cite web |title='أمل' تنعى أحد عناصرها... قضى بقصف إسرائيليّ على بلدة رب ثلاثين |url=https://www.annahar.com/arabic/section/76-%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A9/288534/%D8%A3%D9%85%D9%84-%D8%AA%D9%86%D8%B9%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D8%AD%D8%AF-%D8%B9%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%87%D8%A7-%D9%82%D8%B6%D9%89-%D8%A8%D9%82%D8%B5%D9%81-%D8%A5%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%8A%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%A8%D9%84%D8%AF%D8%A9-%D8%B1%D8%A8-%D8%AB%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AB%D9%8A%D9%86 |access-date=2023-11-11 |website=annahar.com |language=en}}</ref> These were the first casualties from the group since it joined the fighting.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-11 |title=Second Shia militia group joins clashes on Lebanese border |url=https://en.royanews.tv/news/46367/2023-11-11 |website=en.royanews.tv |language=en}}</ref>
 
-On 12 November, Hezbollah anti-tank missile and mortar attacks killed an employee of the [[Israel Electric Corporation]] who was conducting repair work and injured 21 other Israelis, including seven IDF soldiers and six of the fatality's colleagues.<ref name=":142">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-12 |title=IDF hits targets in Lebanon after 21 Israelis wounded by Hezbollah |url=https://jpost.com/breaking-news/article-772861 |access-date=2023-11-12 |website=The Jerusalem Post |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":152">{{Cite web |last=Presse |first=AFP-Agence France |title=Israel Power Company Says Worker Killed By Strike From Lebanon |url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/israel-power-company-says-worker-killed-by-strike-from-lebanon-23baace5 |access-date=2023-11-13 |website=www.barrons.com |language=en-US}}</ref> Hezbollah also claimed to have struck an IDF bulldozer in a separate attack. The IDF said it had launched a drone strike at a militant cell that tried to launch antitank missiles near Metula.<ref name="apnov12">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-12 |title=Missile fire from Lebanon wounds a utility work crew in northern Israel as the front heats up |url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-lebanon-hezbollah-antitank-missile-hamas-gaza-88266c7dbbdf80adfe9157909a39dccb |website=Associated Press |language=en}}</ref> Further clashes also killed one Hezbollah member.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web |title=Hezbollah says it attacked 5 Israeli outposts in disputed Shebaa Farms area |url=https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/mena/hezbollah-says-it-attacked-5-israeli-outposts-in-disputed-shebaa-farms-area |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231014151703/https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/mena/hezbollah-says-it-attacked-5-israeli-outposts-in-disputed-shebaa-farms-area |archive-date=14 October 2023 |access-date=14 October 2023 |website=Khaleej Times |language=en}}</ref>
+On 12 November, Hezbollah anti-tank missile and mortar attacks killed an employee of the [[Israel Electric Corporation]] who was conducting repair work and injured 21 other Israelis, including seven IDF soldiers and six of the fatality's colleagues.<ref name=":142">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-12 |title=IDF hits targets in Lebanon after 21 Israelis wounded by Hezbollah |url=https://jpost.com/breaking-news/article-772861 |access-date=2023-11-12 |website=The Jerusalem Post |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":152">{{Cite web |last=Presse |first=AFP-Agence France |title=Israel Power Company Says Worker Killed By Strike From Lebanon |url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/israel-power-company-says-worker-killed-by-strike-from-lebanon-23baace5 |access-date=2023-11-13 |website=www.barrons.com |language=en-US}}</ref> Hezbollah also claimed to have struck an IDF bulldozer in a separate attack. The IDF said it had launched a drone strike at a militant cell that tried to launch antitank missiles near Metula.<ref name="apnov12">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-12 |title=Missile fire from Lebanon wounds a utility work crew in northern Israel as the front heats up |url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-lebanon-hezbollah-antitank-missile-hamas-gaza-88266c7dbbdf80adfe9157909a39dccb |website=Associated Press |language=en}}</ref> Further clashes also killed one Hezbollah member.<ref name=":122"/>
 
 Following a Hezbollah strike on 13 November, the IDF responded with heavy shelling across southern Lebanon which reportedly killed two civilians.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-11-13 |title=Lebanon front with Israel heats up, stoking fears of wider war |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/lebanon-front-with-israel-heats-up-stoking-fears-wider-war-2023-11-13/ |access-date=2023-11-13}}</ref> Unidentified fighters fired anti-tank guided missiles that injured two Israelis near [[Netu'a]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=IRAN UPDATE, NOVEMBER 13, 2023 |url=https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/iran-update-november-13-2023}}</ref> An Israeli rocket struck near journalists in [[Yaroun]], Lebanon, no casualties were reported.<ref>{{Citation |title=Lebanese journalists came under Israeli air strike while on duty |url=https://www.youtube.com/shorts/Z1eyq-o1POY |access-date=2023-11-14 |language=en}}</ref> Hezbollah condemned the attack, which happened while the journalists were on a public tour in the town.<ref>https://www.terrorism-info.org.il/en/operation-iron-swords-updated-to-1-p-m-november-14-2023/</ref> Foreign minister [[Abdallah Bou Habib]] said that the Lebanese government filed a complaint with the [[UN Security Council]] in response to the incident.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Lebanon files UN complaint over Israel's targeting of journalists |url=https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/lebanon-files-un-complaint-over-israel-s-targeting-of-journalists-/3053759 |access-date=2023-11-15 |website=Anadolu Ajansi}}</ref>

 On 21 November, an IDF airstrike in [[Kafr Kila, Lebanon|Kafr Kila]] killed an elderly woman and injured her granddaughter.<ref>[https://english.alarabiya.net/News/middle-east/2023/11/21/Israel-strikes-south-Lebanon-elderly-woman-killed- Israel strikes south Lebanon, elderly woman killed] 21 November 2023 via english.alarabiya.net</ref> Another team of journalists were targeted in an IDF strike near [[Tayr Harfa]] which killed three people, including two [[Al Mayadeen]] journalists, a reporter and a photojournalist, and a guide.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-11-21 |title=Israeli strike kills two reporters, third person in south Lebanon - state media, PM |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/two-reporters-killed-near-lebanese-border-with-israel-lebanon-state-news-agency-2023-11-21/ |access-date=2023-11-21}}</ref> On the same day, four members of the [[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades|Al-Qassam Brigades]] were killed after an IDF strike on a car near [[Chaaitiyeh]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=AP |title=Israeli airstrikes on Lebanon kill 2 journalists of a pan-Arab TV station, 4 Palestinian militants |url=https://www.khaleejtimes.com/world/mena/israeli-airstrikes-on-lebanon-kill-2-journalists-of-a-pan-arab-tv-station-4-palestinian-militants |access-date=2023-11-21 |website=Khaleej Times |language=en}}</ref> A Hezbollah member was also killed in a separate attack in [[Khiam]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Israeli airstrikes in S.  One Lebanese soldier was killed and three others were injured by an Israeli attack on a Lebanese Army base in [[Odaisseh]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Atallah |first=Nada Maucourant |date=2023-12-05 |title=Israeli shelling kills Lebanese soldier and wounds three others in south Lebanon |url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2023/12/05/israeli-shelling-kills-lebanese-soldier-and-wounds-three-others-in-south-lebanon/ |access-date=2023-12-05 |website=The National |language=en}}</ref> The IDF later apologized for the incident, saying that it would investigate.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-06 |title=IDF issues rare apology after strike kills Lebanese soldier |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/idf-issues-rare-apology-after-strike-kills-lebanese-soldier/ |access-date=2023-12-06 |website=Times of Israel |language=en}}</ref> A farm worker from Syria, was killed in an Israeli artillery attack on a poultry farm near [[Arnoun]] that also injured two of his relatives.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Atallah |first1=Nada Maucourant |last2=Homsi |first2=Nada |date=2023-12-05 |title=Two killed by Israeli shelling in south Lebanon, including soldier |url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2023/12/05/israeli-shelling-kills-lebanese-soldier-and-wounds-three-others-in-south-lebanon/ |access-date=2023-12-05 |website=The National |language=en}}</ref> Israeli [[Ministry of Defense (Israel)|defense minister]] Yoav Gallant met with mayors and local council heads in [[Nahariya]], northern Israel to discuss the threat of Hezbollah to northern residents. Gallant said that if diplomacy fails, Israel will use its military to force Hezbollah north of the [[Litani River]].<ref name=":26">{{Cite web |title=IRAN UPDATE, DECEMBER 6, 2023 |url=https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/iran-update-december-6-2023}}</ref>
 
-On 11 December, the mayor of the southern Lebanese village of [[Taybeh (Marjaayoun)|Taybeh]] was killed in an Israeli airstrike.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-11 |title=Mayor of south Lebanon village killed in Israeli strike - report |url=https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-777552 |access-date=2023-12-11 |website=The Jerusalem Post |language=en-US}}</ref> Two other Hezbollah fighters were killed by Israeli airstrikes and artillery shelling in Aitaroun, and three civilians were injured. Other airstrikes were carried out by the IAF, destroying five houses and damaging 17 others.<ref name=":322">{{Cite web |date=20 October 2023 |title=Second journalist killed by Israel fire in Lebanon |url=https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231021183736/https://www.newarab.com/news/second-journalist-killed-israel-fire-lebanon |archive-date=21 October 2023 |access-date=20 October 2023 |work=The New Arab |language=en}}</ref> Four batches of missiles fired from Lebanon towards northern Israel were intercepted by the [[Iron Dome]] defense system, while the Islamic Resistance claimed it attacked several Israeli sites. According to Israeli media, three soldiers were injured.<ref name=":322" /> Hezbollah and other Iranian-backed militias attacked nine Israeli towns and military positions.<ref name=":323">{{Cite web |title=IRAN UPDATE, DECEMBER 11, 2023 |url=https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/iran-update-december-11-2023}}</ref> Israeli war cabinet minister and former defense minister [[Benny Gantz]] discussed security in northern Israel in a phone call with US Secretary of State [[Antony Blinken]]. Gantz said he conveyed that Hezbollah's heightened aggression and attacks mean that Israel must "remove" the threat from northern Israel. Gantz's statement singled out the Lebanese state, not just Hezbollah, and called for international pressure on Lebanon to stop attacks on its southern border.<ref name=":322" />
+On 11 December, the mayor of the southern Lebanese village of [[Taybeh (Marjaayoun)|Taybeh]] was killed in an Israeli airstrike.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-11 |title=Mayor of south Lebanon village killed in Israeli strike - report |url=https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-777552 |access-date=2023-12-11 |website=The Jerusalem Post |language=en-US}}</ref> Two other Hezbollah fighters were killed by Israeli airstrikes and artillery shelling in Aitaroun, and three civilians were injured. Other airstrikes were carried out by the IAF, destroying five houses and damaging 17 others.<ref name=":322"/> Four batches of missiles fired from Lebanon towards northern Israel were intercepted by the [[Iron Dome]] defense system, while the Islamic Resistance claimed it attacked several Israeli sites. According to Israeli media, three soldiers were injured.<ref name=":322" /> Hezbollah and other Iranian-backed militias attacked nine Israeli towns and military positions.<ref name=":323">{{Cite web |title=IRAN UPDATE, DECEMBER 11, 2023 |url=https://www.understandingwar.org/backgrounder/iran-update-december-11-2023}}</ref> Israeli war cabinet minister and former defense minister [[Benny Gantz]] discussed security in northern Israel in a phone call with US Secretary of State [[Antony Blinken]]. Gantz said he conveyed that Hezbollah's heightened aggression and attacks mean that Israel must "remove" the threat from northern Israel. Gantz's statement singled out the Lebanese state, not just Hezbollah, and called for international pressure on Lebanon to stop attacks on its southern border.<ref name=":322" />
 
 The [[Syrian Social Nationalist Party in Lebanon]] announced the death of one member of their military wing, the [[Eagles of the Whirlwind]], on 15 December.<ref>{{Cite web |title=الوكالة الوطنية للإعلام - القومي أعلن استشهاد أحد مقاتليه وسام محمد سليم |url=https://www.nna-leb.gov.lb/ar/%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%A9/662898 |access-date=2023-12-16 |website=الوكالة الوطنية للإعلام |language=ar}}</ref> The IDF said that one in five rockets launched by Hezbollah had landed in Lebanese territory and published an infographic showing failed rocket launches into Israel.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-12-15 |title=IDF: One in five Hezbollah rockets fired at Israel land in Lebanon |url=https://www.jpost.com/middle-east/article-778119 |access-date=2023-12-17 |website=The Jerusalem Post |language=en-US}}</ref>
@@ -166,5 +166,5 @@
 On 8 January, Israel assassinated [[Wissam al-Tawil]], the deputy commander of Hezbollah's [[Redwan Force]]. According to Israel, al-Tawil was responsible for carrying out the attack on Meron airbase two days earlier.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hezbollah says Israel kills top commander amid fears of Gaza war escalation |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/1/8/hezbollah-says-israel-kills-top-commander-amid-fears-of-gaza-war-escalation |access-date=8 January 2024 |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=8 January 2024}}</ref> In response to al-Tawil's killing, Hezbollah launched a drone attack on Israel's [[Northern Command (Israel)|Northern Command]] headquarters in [[Safed]] on the following day, situated approximately {{convert|20|km|mi}} from the border.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hezbollah launches drone attack on Israel in response to top commander's killing |url=https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20240109-hezbollah-launches-drone-attack-on-israel-in-response-to-top-commanders-killing/ |access-date=9 January 2024 |publisher=Middle East Monitor |date=9 January 2024}}</ref> [[Ali Hussein Barji]], the commander of Hezbollah's aerial forces in southern Lebanon who was reportedly responsible for the attack, was killed by an airstrike, according to Israel, alongside three other Hezbollah members, in [[Khirbet Selm]] shortly before al-Tawil's funeral began.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2024-01-09 |title=Hezbollah's drone chief in southern Lebanon killed in reported Israeli strike |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog_entry/hezbollahs-drone-chief-in-southern-lebanon-killed-in-reported-israeli-strike/ |access-date=2024-01-09 |work=The Times of Israel}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Presse |first=AFP-Agence France |title=Hezbollah Source Says Local Chief Among 4 Killed In South Lebanon |url=https://www.barrons.com/news/hezbollah-source-says-local-chief-among-4-killed-in-south-lebanon-33f6402c |access-date=2024-01-09 |website=www.barrons.com |language=en-US}}</ref> However, Hezbollah denied that Barji was killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/lebanons-hezbollah-denies-israels-claim-killing-senior-hezbollah-commander-2024-01-09/|title=Lebanon's Hezbollah denies Israel's claim for killing senior Hezbollah commander|work=Reuters|date=9 January 2023}}</ref>

 === Israel ===

One was killed when anti-tank missiles hit the [[Yiftah]] kibbutz and another in [[Kiryat Shmona]].<ref name=":10">{{Cite web |date=5 November 2023 |title=Escalation in the north: Israeli civilian killed by Hezbollah, rockets hit Kiryat Shmona |url=https://allisrael.com/brief/escalation-in-the-north-israeli-civilian-killed-by-hezbollah-rockets-hit-kiryat-shmona |access-date=5 November 2023 |website=All Israel News |language=en-US}}</ref> On 23 November, in Hezbollah's deadliest attack since the start of the clashes, Hezbollah anti-tank missile and mortar attacks killed an employee of the [[Israel Electric Corporation]] who was conducting repair work and injured 21 other Israelis, including seven IDF soldiers and six of the fatality's colleagues.<ref name=":14">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-12 |title=IDF hits targets in Lebanon after 21 Israelis wounded by Hezbollah |url=https://jpost.com/breaking-news/article-772861 |access-date=2023-11-12 |website=The Jerusalem Post |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":15">{{Cite web |last=Presse |first=AFP-Agence France |title=Israel Power Company Says Worker Killed By Strike From Lebanon |url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/israel-power-company-says-worker-killed-by-strike-from-lebanon-23baace5 |access-date=2023-11-13 |website=www.barrons.com |language=en-US}}</ref>

One was killed when anti-tank missiles hit the [[Yiftah]] kibbutz and another in [[Kiryat Shmona]].<ref name=":102"/> On 23 November, in Hezbollah's deadliest attack since the start of the clashes, Hezbollah anti-tank missile and mortar attacks killed an employee of the [[Israel Electric Corporation]] who was conducting repair work and injured 21 other Israelis, including seven IDF soldiers and six of the fatality's colleagues.<ref name=":142"/><ref name=":152"/>

@@ -48,5 +48,5 @@
 
 === Israeli policy ===
-[[Benjamin Netanyahu]] has been Israel's prime minister for the one and half decade preceding the war, with the exception of the period from June 2021 to January 2023 when [[Naftali Bennett]] and later [[Yair Lapid]] took office.<ref>{{#invoke:cite news||date=12 August 2022 |title=Israel's Yair Lapid and Benny Gantz: Dynamic duo or natural rivals? |url=https://www.jpost.com/israel-news/politics-and-diplomacy/article-714538 |access-date=31 December 2023 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]}}</ref> Both governments have been criticized for having championed a policy of empowering the Hamas government in Gaza by, for instance, granting [[Israeli permit regime in the Gaza Strip|work permits to Gazan residents]], facilitating the transfer of funds to Hamas and maintaining relative calm.<ref name="TOI123" /><ref name=":2">{{#invoke:cite news||url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/06/15/israels-big-new-shift-in-hamas-policy/ |title=Israel's Big New Shift in Hamas Policy |work=[[Foreign Policy]] |access-date=28 October 2023 |date=15 June 2021 |archive-date=27 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231027132032/https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/06/15/israels-big-new-shift-in-hamas-policy/ |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{#invoke:cite news||url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/29/world/middleeast/israel-intelligence-hamas-attack.html |title=How Years of Israeli Failures on Hamas Led to a Devastating Attack |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=30 October 2023 |access-date=30 October 2023 |archive-date=30 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231030000459/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/29/world/middleeast/israel-intelligence-hamas-attack.html |url-status=live}}</ref> By the conclusion of Netanyahu's fifth government in 2021, the issuance of work permits to Gazans reached approximately 2,000-3,000. Later, under the Bennett-Lapid government, this number significantly increased to 10,000,<ref name="TOI123" /> and since Netanyahu's return to power in 2023 the number rose again to 20,000.<ref name="TOI123" /> These workers were accused of spying on Israel and complicit of the October 7 attack.<ref name="WT1711">{{#invoke:cite web||last=Pipes |first=Daniel |date=17 November 2023 |title=Appeasement not victory: Israel has quickly reverted to its bad policies |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2023/nov/17/appeasement-not-victory-israel-has-quickly-reverte/ |access-date=31 December 2023 |website=[[The Washington Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{#invoke:cite news||date=10 October 2023 |title=How Hamas duped Israel as it planned devastating attack |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/how-israel-was-duped-hamas-planned-devastating-assault-2023-10-08/ |url-status=live |access-date=7 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231009020650/https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/how-israel-was-duped-hamas-planned-devastating-assault-2023-10-08/ |archive-date=9 October 2023}}</ref><ref>{{#invoke:cite news||title=What went wrong? Questions emerge over Israel's intelligence prowess after Hamas attack |work=[[AP News]] |url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-hamas-gaza-attack-intel-a5287a18773232f26ca171233be01721 |url-status=live |access-date=7 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231107033735/https://apnews.com/article/israel-hamas-gaza-attack-intel-a5287a18773232f26ca171233be01721 |archive-date=7 November 2023}}</ref> After the attack, the [[Israeli war cabinet]] granted additional 8,000 permits for agricultural works to West Bank residents, despite concerns about their vetting and potential security risks.<ref name="WT1711" />
+[[Benjamin Netanyahu]] has been Israel's prime minister for nearly the entire 15 year period preceding the war, with the exception of the 18 months from June 2021 to January 2023 when [[Naftali Bennett]] and later [[Yair Lapid]] took office.<ref>{{#invoke:cite news||date=12 August 2022 |title=Israel's Yair Lapid and Benny Gantz: Dynamic duo or natural rivals? |url=https://www.jpost.com/israel-news/politics-and-diplomacy/article-714538 |access-date=31 December 2023 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]}}</ref> Both governments have been criticized for having championed a policy of empowering the Hamas government in Gaza by, for instance, granting [[Israeli permit regime in the Gaza Strip|work permits to Gazan residents]], facilitating the transfer of funds to Hamas and maintaining relative calm.<ref name="TOI123" /><ref name=":2">{{#invoke:cite news||url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/06/15/israels-big-new-shift-in-hamas-policy/ |title=Israel's Big New Shift in Hamas Policy |work=[[Foreign Policy]] |access-date=28 October 2023 |date=15 June 2021 |archive-date=27 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231027132032/https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/06/15/israels-big-new-shift-in-hamas-policy/ |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{#invoke:cite news||url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/29/world/middleeast/israel-intelligence-hamas-attack.html |title=How Years of Israeli Failures on Hamas Led to a Devastating Attack |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=30 October 2023 |access-date=30 October 2023 |archive-date=30 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231030000459/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/29/world/middleeast/israel-intelligence-hamas-attack.html |url-status=live}}</ref> By the conclusion of Netanyahu's fifth government in 2021, the issuance of work permits to Gazans reached approximately 2,000-3,000. Later, under the Bennett-Lapid government, this number significantly increased to 10,000,<ref name="TOI123" /> and since Netanyahu's return to power in 2023 the number rose again to 20,000.<ref name="TOI123" /> These workers were accused of spying on Israel and complicit of the October 7 attack.<ref name="WT1711">{{#invoke:cite web||last=Pipes |first=Daniel |date=17 November 2023 |title=Appeasement not victory: Israel has quickly reverted to its bad policies |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2023/nov/17/appeasement-not-victory-israel-has-quickly-reverte/ |access-date=31 December 2023 |website=[[The Washington Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{#invoke:cite news||date=10 October 2023 |title=How Hamas duped Israel as it planned devastating attack |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/how-israel-was-duped-hamas-planned-devastating-assault-2023-10-08/ |url-status=live |access-date=7 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231009020650/https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/how-israel-was-duped-hamas-planned-devastating-assault-2023-10-08/ |archive-date=9 October 2023}}</ref><ref>{{#invoke:cite news||title=What went wrong? Questions emerge over Israel's intelligence prowess after Hamas attack |work=[[AP News]] |url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-hamas-gaza-attack-intel-a5287a18773232f26ca171233be01721 |url-status=live |access-date=7 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231107033735/https://apnews.com/article/israel-hamas-gaza-attack-intel-a5287a18773232f26ca171233be01721 |archive-date=7 November 2023}}</ref> After the attack, the [[Israeli war cabinet]] granted additional 8,000 permits for agricultural works to West Bank residents, despite concerns about their vetting and potential security risks.<ref name="WT1711" />
 
 In addition to granting workers permits, millions of dollars from Qatar have been transported into Gaza, escorted by [[Mossad]], Israel's intelligence agency, intended for Gaza's power plant, infrastructure projects and monthly stipends for impoverished Palestinian families, while Israeli officials were aware that Hamas might divert the funds to acquire weapons and rockets.<ref name="Schneider 2023" /><ref name=":2" />

 The situation in the Gaza Strip reached dire levels of starvation and food insecurity by late 2023 and early 2024. Reports from various sources including the [[World Food Programme]] and [[United Nations]] officials highlighted a devastating situation where food stocks were nearly exhausted, bakeries were being -By early 2024, the Gaza Strip faced one of the worst instances of man-made starvation in a century.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nolen |first1=Stephanie |title=Looming Starvation in Gaza Shows Resurgence of Civilian Sieges in Warfare |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=11 January 2024 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/11/health/gaza-israel-hunger-starvation.html |access-date=14 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240301042147/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/11/health/gaza-israel-hunger-starvation.html |archive-date=1 March 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Stack |first1=Liam |last2=Gupta |first2=Gaya |last3=Abu Bakr |first3=Bashir |title=Half of Gazans Are at Risk of Starving, U.N. 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Statement by UNICEF on the risk of famine in the Gaza Strip |url=https://www.unicef.org/mena/press-releases/statement-unicef-risk-famine-gaza-strip +The total blockade of Gaza was announced on 9 October 2023 by the [[Defence Minister of Israel]], [[Yoav Gallant]]. “We are putting a complete siege on Gaza … No electricity, no food, no water, no gas – it’s all closed,” he announced.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Israel Gaza live news: Israel orders 'siege' of Gaza with 'no electricity, food, or fuel' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/world-middle-east-67050350 |access-date=2023-10-09 |website=BBC News |language=en-gb}}</ref> The spokesman for the [[Ministry of Energy (Israel)|Minister of Energy of Israel]], [[Israel Katz]], said that Katz had ordered the water supply to Gaza to be cut, effective immediately.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Mohamed |first=Ted Regencia,Virginia Pietromarchi,Umut Uras,Edna |title=Israel to impose ‘total Gaza blockade’, dozens killed in refugee camp hit |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/10/9/israel-hamas-war-live-news-gaza-under-non-stop-bombardment |access-date=2023-10-09 |website=www.aljazeera.com |language=en}}</ref> Israeli tanks and drones have been tasked with guarding openings in the Gaza–Israel border fence and enforcing the blockade.<ref name=":0" />

@@ -96,5 +96,5 @@
 [[File:Israel and Palestine Peace.svg|thumb|left|A [[peace movement]] poster: [[Flag of Israel|Israeli]] and [[Palestinian flag]]s and the word ''peace'' in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]].]]
 
-In 1993, Israeli officials led by [[Yitzhak Rabin]] and Palestinian leaders from the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] led by [[Yasser Arafat]] strove to find a peaceful solution through what became known as the Oslo peace process. A crucial milestone in this process was Arafat's letter of recognition of Israel's right to exist. In 1993, the Oslo Accords were finalized as a framework for future Israeli–Palestinian relations. The crux of the Oslo agreement was that Israel would gradually cede control of the Palestinian territories over to the Palestinians in exchange for peace. The Oslo process was delicate and progressed in fits and starts, the process took a turning point at the [[assassination of Yitzhak Rabin]] and finally unraveled when Arafat and [[Ehud Barak]] failed to reach agreement at Camp David in July 2000. [[Robert Malley]], special assistant to US President [[Bill Clinton]] for Arab–Israeli Affairs, has confirmed that while Barak made no formal written offer to Arafat, the US did present concepts for peace which were considered by the Israeli side yet left unanswered by Arafat "the Palestinians' principal failing is that from the beginning of the Camp David summit onward they were unable either to say yes to the American ideas or to present a cogent and specific counterproposal of their own".<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Agha|first1=Hussein|last2=Malley|first2=Robert|title=Camp David: The Tragedy of Errors|journal=New York Review of Books|language=en|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2001/08/09/camp-david-the-tragedy-of-errors/|access-date=2022-03-05|issn=0028-7504|archive-date=6 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180906052533/https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2001/08/09/camp-david-the-tragedy-of-errors/|url-status=live}}</ref> Consequently, there are different accounts of the proposals considered.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2001-09-01|title=Propositions israéliennes, de Camp David (2000) à Taba (2001)|url=https://www.monde-diplomatique.fr/cartes/taba2001|access-date=2022-03-05|website=Le Monde diplomatique|language=fr|archive-date=5 March 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220305205555/https://www.monde-diplomatique.fr/cartes/taba2001|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Agha|first1=Hussein|last2=Malley|first2=Robert|title=Camp David and After: An Exchange (2. A Reply to Ehud Barak)|journal=New York Review of Books|language=en|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/13/camp-david-and-after-an-exchange-2-a-reply-to-ehud/|access-date=2022-03-05|issn=0028-7504|archive-date=5 March 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220305205555/https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/13/camp-david-and-after-an-exchange-2-a-reply-to-ehud/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Barak|first1=Ehud|last2=Morris|first2=Benny|last3=Agha|first3=Hussein|last4=Malley|first4=Robert|title=Camp David and After—Continued|journal=New York Review of Books|language=en|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/27/camp-david-and-aftercontinued/|access-date=2022-03-05|issn=0028-7504|archive-date=5 March 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220305205557/https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/27/camp-david-and-aftercontinued/|url-status=live}}</ref>
+In 1993, Israeli officials led by [[Yitzhak Rabin]] and Palestinian leaders from the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] led by [[Yasser Arafat]] strove to find a peaceful solution through what became known as the Oslo peace process. A crucial milestone in this process was Arafat's letter of recognition of Israel's right to exist. In 1993, the Oslo Accords were finalized as a framework for future Israeli–Palestinian relations. The crux of the Oslo agreement was that Israel would gradually cede control of the Palestinian territories over to the Palestinians in exchange for peace. The Oslo process was delicate and progressed in fits and starts. The process took a turning point at the [[assassination of Yitzhak Rabin]] in November 1995 and finally unraveled when Arafat and [[Ehud Barak]] failed to reach agreement at Camp David in July 2000. [[Robert Malley]], special assistant to US President [[Bill Clinton]] for Arab–Israeli Affairs, has confirmed that while Barak made no formal written offer to Arafat, the US did present concepts for peace which were considered by the Israeli side yet left unanswered by Arafat: "the Palestinians' principal failing is that from the beginning of the Camp David summit onward they were unable either to say yes to the American ideas or to present a cogent and specific counterproposal of their own".<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Agha|first1=Hussein|last2=Malley|first2=Robert|title=Camp David: The Tragedy of Errors|journal=New York Review of Books|language=en|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2001/08/09/camp-david-the-tragedy-of-errors/|access-date=2022-03-05|issn=0028-7504|archive-date=6 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180906052533/https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2001/08/09/camp-david-the-tragedy-of-errors/|url-status=live}}</ref> Consequently, there are different accounts of the proposals considered.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2001-09-01|title=Propositions israéliennes, de Camp David (2000) à Taba (2001)|url=https://www.monde-diplomatique.fr/cartes/taba2001|access-date=2022-03-05|website=Le Monde diplomatique|language=fr|archive-date=5 March 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220305205555/https://www.monde-diplomatique.fr/cartes/taba2001|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Agha|first1=Hussein|last2=Malley|first2=Robert|title=Camp David and After: An Exchange (2. A Reply to Ehud Barak)|journal=New York Review of Books|language=en|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/13/camp-david-and-after-an-exchange-2-a-reply-to-ehud/|access-date=2022-03-05|issn=0028-7504|archive-date=5 March 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220305205555/https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/13/camp-david-and-after-an-exchange-2-a-reply-to-ehud/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Barak|first1=Ehud|last2=Morris|first2=Benny|last3=Agha|first3=Hussein|last4=Malley|first4=Robert|title=Camp David and After—Continued|journal=New York Review of Books|language=en|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/27/camp-david-and-aftercontinued/|access-date=2022-03-05|issn=0028-7504|archive-date=5 March 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220305205557/https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2002/06/27/camp-david-and-aftercontinued/|url-status=live}}</ref>

@@ -6,5 +6,7 @@
 {{Campaignbox Gaza–Israel conflict}}
 
-The '''blockade of the Gaza Strip''' is the ongoing land, air, and sea [[blockade]] of the [[Gaza Strip]] imposed by [[Israel]] and [[Egypt]] since 2007. One year after the 2005 [[Israeli disengagement from Gaza|disengagement from the Gaza Strip]] by Israel, [[Hamas]] won the [[Palestinian legislative election, 2006|Palestinian legislative election]], and Israel and the [[Quartet on the Middle East]] ceased providing aid to the [[Palestinian Authority]] and imposed  [[2006–07 economic sanctions against the Palestinian National Authority|sanctions against the PA]], because Hamas would not agree to the conditions for continued aid: namely, the recognition of Israel, disavowal violent actions, and acceptance the previous agreements between Israel and the PA.<ref name="John Pike">{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/hamas.htm|title=Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement)|publisher=Globalsecurity.org|accessdate=May 27, 2010}}</ref>
+The '''blockade of the Gaza Strip''' is the ongoing land, air, and sea [[blockade]] of the [[Gaza Strip]] imposed by [[Israel]] and [[Egypt]] since 2007. The system of control imposed by Israel is sometimes know as the '''indirect occupation of the Gaza Strip''';<ref>Jerome Slater, [https://www.belfercenter.org/sites/default/files/legacy/files/IS3702_Slater.pdf Just War Moral Philosophy and the 2008–09 Israeli Campaign in Gaza], International Security 37(2):44-80 · October 2012</ref>
+
+One year after the 2005 [[Israeli disengagement from Gaza|disengagement from the Gaza Strip]] by Israel, [[Hamas]] won the [[Palestinian legislative election, 2006|Palestinian legislative election]], and Israel and the [[Quartet on the Middle East]] ceased providing aid to the [[Palestinian Authority]] and imposed  [[2006–07 economic sanctions against the Palestinian National Authority|sanctions against the PA]], because Hamas would not agree to the conditions for continued aid: namely, the recognition of Israel, disavowal violent actions, and acceptance the previous agreements between Israel and the PA.<ref name="John Pike">{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/para/hamas.htm|title=Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement)|publisher=Globalsecurity.org|accessdate=May 27, 2010}}</ref>
 
 In March 2007, Hamas and [[Fatah]] formed a [[Palestinian authority national unity government|unity government]] headed by [[Ismail Haniya]]. Shortly after, in June, Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the [[Battle of Gaza (2007)|Battle of Gaza]].<ref name=Guardian/> Hamas seized government institutions and replaced Fatah and other government officials with Hamas members.<ref name="intern_fight_p14-15">{{cite book | title= Internal fight: Palestinian abuses in Gaza and the West Bank | pages= 14–15 | author2= [[Human Rights Watch]] | first1= Fred | last1= Abrahams | publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] | year= 2008 }}</ref> Following the takeover, Egypt and Israel largely [[Rafah Border Crossing#Closures of the border|closed their border crossings]] with Gaza, on the grounds that Fatah had fled the Strip and was no longer able to provide security on the Palestinian side.<ref name="nytimes.com">Isabel Kershner. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/14/world/middleeast/14mideast.html Abbas’s Premier Tells Israel to Reopen Gaza]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. 14 December 2007.</ref> Egypt was worried that Hamas control over Gaza would increase Iranian influence. [[Aboul Gheit]] explained that opening the [[Rafah border crossing]] would undermine the legitimacy of the Palestinian Authority.<ref name="egypt"/>

@@ -294,4 +294,6 @@
 
 On 6 December, UN chief António Guterres invoked Article 99 of the [[Charter of the United Nations]], stating “We are facing a severe risk of collapse of the humanitarian system."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shotter |first1=James |last2=Saleh |first2=Heba |title=Humanitarian system in Gaza on verge of collapse, says UN chief |url=https://www.ft.com/content/752eb5a0-3d75-4340-ad0d-b6554d9e4f61 |website=Financial Times |access-date=7 December 2023}}</ref> A joint statement by more than 20 UN and humanitarian organizations described the crisis as "amongst the worst we have witnessed".<ref>{{cite web |title=Aqaba Process Joint Statement on Gaza’s Humanitarian Situation |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/aqaba-process-joint-statement-gazas-humanitarian-situation |website=ReliefWeb |publisher=UNOCHA |access-date=8 December 2023}}</ref> On 8 December, [[UNICEF]] spokesperson Thomas White stated, "Civil order is breaking down in Gaza... Society is on the brink of full-blown collapse."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Masoud |first1=Bassam |title=Israel sharply ramps up Gaza strikes, U.S. alarmed |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/us-criticizes-israel-gaza-civilian-toll-un-hear-ceasefire-demand-2023-12-08/ |website=Reuters |access-date=8 December 2023}}</ref> On 10 December, Bushra Khalidi, an expert with [[Oxfam]], stated the situation was no longer "just a catastrophe, it's apocalyptic."<ref>{{cite web |title=Israeli forces battle Palestinian militants in south Gaza |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231210-israeli-forces-push-into-southern-gaza |website=France 24 |access-date=10 December 2023}}</ref> Philippe Lazzarini stated, "By any description, it is definitely the worst situation I have ever seen."<ref>{{cite web |title=Israel steps up southern Gaza offensive as U.S. approves arms sales |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/live-blog/israel-hamas-war-live-updates-rcna128910 |website=NBC News |access-date=10 December 2023}}</ref> On 11 December, a UN envoy toured Gaza, leading [[Ecuador]]'s representative to state, "The reality is even worse than what words can speak."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cromwell |first1=Alexander |title=U.N. envoys say 'enough' to war on trip to Gaza border |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/uae-takes-un-council-envoys-rafah-amid-dire-aid-warnings-2023-12-11/#:~:text=%22The%20reality%20is%20even%20worse,reporters%20after%20the%20UNRWA%20briefing. |website=Reuters |access-date=11 December 2023}}</ref> On 13 December, UN human rights chief [[Volker Türk]] stated the crisis was "well beyond breakdown."<ref>{{cite web |title=Gaza 'well beyond breakdown' -UN human rights chief |url=https://www.reuters.com/video/watch/idsINL?now=true# |website=Reuters |access-date=13 December 2023}}</ref>
+

 ==Plot==
-The plot is a day in the life of a glamorous fashion photographer, Thomas (Hemmings), inspired by the life of an actual "[[Swinging London]]" photographer, [[David Bailey (photographer)|David Bailey]].<ref>[http://pdngallery.com/legends/bailey/intro.shtml PDN Legends Online: David Bailey.] Retrieved 28 July 2012.</ref> After spending the night at a [[flophouse|doss house]] where he has taken pictures for a book of art photos, Thomas is late for a photo shoot with Veruschka at his studio, which in turn makes him late for a shoot with other models later in the morning. He grows bored and walks off, leaving the models and production staff in the lurch. As he leaves the studio, two teenage girls who are aspiring models (Birkin and Hills) ask to speak with him, but the photographer drives off to look at an antiques shop. Wandering into [[Maryon Park]], he takes photos of two lovers. The woman ([[Vanessa Redgrave]]) is furious at being photographed, pursues Thomas, demands his film and ultimately tries to snatch his camera.  He refuses and photographs her as she runs off.
+The plot is a day in the life of a glamorous fashion photographer, Thomas (Hemmings), inspired by the life of an actual "[[Swinging London]]" photographer, [[David Bailey (photographer)|David Bailey]].<ref>[http://pdngallery.com/legends/bailey/intro.shtml PDN Legends Online: David Bailey.] Retrieved 28 July 2012.</ref> After spending the night at a [[flophouse|doss house]] where he has taken pictures for a book of art photos, Thomas is late for a photo shoot with Veruschka at his studio, which in turn makes him late for a shoot with other models later in the morning. He grows bored and walks off, leaving the models and production staff in the lurch. As he leaves the studio, two teenage girls who are aspiring models (Birkin and Hills) ask to speak with him, but the photographer drives off to look at an antique shop. Wandering into [[Maryon Park]], he takes photos of two lovers. The woman ([[Vanessa Redgrave]]) is furious at being photographed, pursues Thomas, demands his film and ultimately tries to snatch his camera.  He refuses and photographs her as she runs off.
 
 Thomas then meets his agent Ron ([[Peter Bowles]]) for lunch and notices a man following him and looking into his car. Back at his studio, the woman from the park arrives asking desperately for the film.  They have a conversation and flirt, but he deliberately hands her a different film roll. She in turn writes down a false telephone number and gives it to him.  He curiously makes many enlargements of the black and white film of the two lovers.  They reveal the woman worriedly looking at a third person lurking in the trees with a pistol.  Thomas excitedly calls Ron, claiming his impromptu photo session may have saved a man's life.  Thomas is disturbed by a knock on the door, and it is the two girls again, with whom he has a romp in his studio and falls asleep. Awakening, he finds they hope he will photograph them, but he realizes there may be more to the photographs in the park. He tells them to leave, saying, "Tomorrow! Tomorrow!"  Further examination of a blurred figure under a bush makes Thomas suspect the man in the park may have been murdered after all, during the time Thomas was arguing with the woman around the bend.

@@ -14,5 +14,5 @@
 Saudi Arabia played an active role in attempting to bring the Palestinians towards a self-governing condition which would permit negotiations with Israel. It has done so primarily by trying to mend the schism between Fatah and Hamas, most notably when King Abdullah invited the two factions to negotiations in Mecca resulting in the Mecca Agreement of February 7, 2007. The agreement soon failed, but Saudi Arabia has continued to support a national unity government for the Palestinians, and strongly opposed the war in Gaza in early 2009.

@@ -432,5 +432,5 @@
 Activists used social media, such as [[Twitter|X]] and [[TikTok]], to share information about the war.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tenbarge |first1=Kat |last2=Ede-Osifo |first2=Uwa |title=Israel-Hamas war discourse shows the increasingly fraught nature of online speech |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/israel-hamas-war-discourse-fraught-nature-online-speech-rcna119589 |website=NBC News |date=11 October 2023 |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref> Pro-Palestinian activists adopted the watermelon emoji{{efn|🍉}} as a symbol to represent solidarity with the people of Gaza.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hassan |first1=Jennifer |last2=Berger |first2=Miriam |title=Why the watermelon is a symbol for the Palestinian cause |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/11/16/watermelon-emoji-palestine-meaning-symbol/ |newspaper=The Washington Post |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref> [[TikTok]] was a source of ire for some, with individuals such as former-US president [[Barack Obama]] criticizing "TikTok activism" for obscuring context.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Graef |first1=Aileen |title=Obama says people need to acknowledge complexity of Israel-Palestinian conflict to move forward |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/11/04/politics/obama-comments-israel-palestinian-conflict/index.html |website=CNN |date=4 November 2023 |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref> Celebrities, including [[Sacha Baron Cohen]] and [[Amy Schumer]], held a private meeting with TikTok executives accusing them of spreading antisemitism.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Guynn |first1=Jessica |title=Sacha Baron Cohen, Jewish celebrities rip TikTok for rising antisemitism in private meeting |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2023/11/17/jewish-celebrities-tiktok-antisemitism-meeting/71621035007/ |website=USA Today |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref> TikTok stated it was not biased, but that young people were organically more supportive of Palestine.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Titcomb |first1=James |title=We're not biased – millennials are more pro-Palestine, says TikTok |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2023/11/14/millennials-are-more-pro-palestine-says-tiktok/ |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=14 November 2023 |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref> 
 
-On 18 November, [[Elon Musk]] announced any user who used the phrases "[[decolonization]]" or "[[from the river to the sea]]" would be suspended from X.<ref>{{cite web |title=Elon Musk signals clamp down on Palestinian free speech on X |url=https://aje.io/vx4bwb?update=2495291 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref>{{efn|The announcement came after [[Disney]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Paramount Global|Paramount]] and [[Lionsgate]] pulled advertisements from X following Musk's endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory, which US president [[Joe Biden]] called "abhorrent."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mac |first1=Ryan |title=Advertisers Flee X as Outcry Over Musk's Endorsement of Antisemitic Post Grows |work=The New York Times |date=17 November 2023 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/17/technology/elon-musk-twitter-x-advertisers.html |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Montgomery |first1=Blake |title=White House condemns Elon Musk's 'abhorrent' antisemitic tweets |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/17/white-house-biden-elon-musk-antisemitic-tweet-hate |website=The Guardian |date=17 November 2023 |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref>}} 
+On 18 November, [[Elon Musk]] announced any user who used the phrases "[[decolonization]]" or "[[from the river to the sea]]" would be suspended from X.<ref>{{cite web |title=Elon Musk signals clamp down on Palestinian free speech on X |url=https://aje.io/vx4bwb?update=2495291 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref>{{efn|The announcement came after [[Disney]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Paramount Global|Paramount]] and [[Lionsgate]] pulled advertisements from X following Musk's endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory, which US president [[Joe Biden]] called "abhorrent."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mac |first1=Ryan |title=Advertisers Flee X as Outcry Over Musk's Endorsement of Antisemitic Post Grows |work=The New York Times |date=17 November 2023 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/17/technology/elon-musk-twitter-x-advertisers.html |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Montgomery |first1=Blake |title=White House condemns Elon Musk's 'abhorrent' antisemitic tweets |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/17/white-house-biden-elon-musk-antisemitic-tweet-hate |website=The Guardian |date=17 November 2023 |access-date=18 November 2023}}</ref>}} Pro-Palestinian content creators reported widespread [[shadowbanning]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jamal |first1=Urooba |title=‘Consistent’ shadow banning of Palestinian supporters on social media |url=https://aje.io/nm7bul?update=2547213 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=10 December 2023}}</ref>
 
 [[Misinformation in the 2023 Israel–Hamas war|Disinformation]] generated by [[machine learning]] models were used by activists to solicit support, as well as to create the artificial impression of broader support.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bedingfield |first1=Will |title=Generative AI Is Playing a Surprising Role in Israel-Hamas Disinformation |url=https://www.wired.com/story/israel-hamas-war-generative-artificial-intelligence-disinformation/ |website=Wired |access-date=26 November 2023}}</ref> AI-generated images and [[deepfake]]s went viral online, though they were simultaneously fact-checked.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Eisele |first1=Ines |title=Fact check: AI fakes in Israel's war against Hamas |url=https://www.dw.com/en/fact-check-ai-fakes-in-israels-war-against-hamas/a-67367744 |website=DW |access-date=26 November 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Fact Check: Photo of cheering crowds waving Israeli flags at soldiers is AI-generated |url=https://www.reuters.com/fact-check/photo-cheering-crowds-waving-israeli-flags-soldiers-is-ai-generated-2023-10-30/ |website=Reuters |access-date=26 November 2023}}</ref> Technology companies were accused of profiting from AI-generated images related to the war,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hindy |first1=Joe |title=Adobe's Stock Photo Service Selling AI-Generated Images of Israel-Hamas War |url=https://www.pcmag.com/news/adobes-stock-photo-service-selling-ai-generated-images-of-israel-hamas |website=PC Magazine |access-date=26 November 2023}}</ref> as well as for building models that generated content reflecting [[Anti-Palestinianism|anti-Palestinian]] biases.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bhuiyan |first1=Johana |title=WhatsApp’s AI shows gun-wielding children when prompted with ‘Palestine’ |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/02/whatsapps-ai-palestine-kids-gun-gaza-bias-israel |website=The Guardian |access-date=26 November 2023}}</ref>

@@ -28,5 +28,5 @@
 In January 1991, the [[New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division]] rejected Hylton's challenges relating to duress and found her other arguments "unpersuasive and meritless," noting that she had made an "elaborate confession, which was corroborated by ample evidence."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://casetext.com/case/people-v-hylton-14|title=''People v. Hylton'', 169 A.D.2d 593 (N.Y. App. Div. 1991)|date=January 29, 1991|website=casetext.com|publisher=Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York|access-date=October 27, 2018}}</ref>
 
-In April 2007, Hylton appealed to federal court to vacate her conviction because (1) her Sixth Amendment right to confrontation was violated, (2) she received ineffective assistance of counsel in both the trial and state appellate proceedings, and (3) judicial impropriety and bias deprived her of her constitutional right to a fair trial. In November, the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] ruled that Hylton's petition for habeas corpus was untimely on its face, since under the [[Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996]] it fell beyond the one-year statute of limitations. Consequently, the court dismissed her case without addressing Hylton's claims of judicial impropriety and bias and ineffectiveness of trial and appellate counsel.<ref name=SDNY/>
+In April 2007, Hylton appealed to federal court to vacate her conviction because (1) her Sixth Amendment right to confrontation was violated, (2) she received ineffective assistance of counsel in both the trial and state appellate proceedings, and (3) judicial impropriety and bias deprived her of her constitutional right to a fair trial. In November, the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] ruled that Hylton's petition for habeas corpus was untimely on its face, having been filed ten years after the effective date of the [[Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996]] imposing a one-year statute of limitations. Consequently, the court dismissed her case without addressing Hylton's claims of judicial impropriety and bias and ineffectiveness of trial and appellate counsel.<ref name=SDNY/>
 
 ===Prison===

@@ -54,5 +54,8 @@
 IDF spokesperson [[Daniel Hagari]] confirmed that Israeli fighter jets attacked the refugee camp.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Israel Gaza live news: Dozens reported killed in Gaza refugee camp blast |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/world-middle-east-67258466 |access-date=31 October 2023 |website=BBC News |language=en-gb}}</ref> Asked about civilian deaths by CNN host [[Wolf Blitzer]], IDF spokesman Richard Hecht said, "This is the tragedy of war, Wolf"; accusing Hamas of "hiding, as they do, behind civilians" and saying that civilians had been asked to move south.<ref name="CNN1031">{{Cite news |last=Raine |first=Andrew |date=31 October 2023 |title='Children were carrying other injured children.' Witness describes aftermath of Israeli strike on Gaza refugee camp |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/10/31/middleeast/jabalya-blast-gaza-intl/index.html |access-date=1 November 2023 |work=CNN}}</ref>
 
-===Reactions===
+=== 1 November ===
+Less than a day after the 31 October airstrike which killed at least 50 people, Jabalia was bombed again.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2023/11/1/israel-hamas-war-live-anger-grows-over-israeli-attack-on-gaza-refugee-camp | title= Israel-Hamas war live: Jabalia hit again a day after deadly Israeli attack =1 November 2023|work=AlJazeera}}</ref> The IDF said the strike killed "the head of [Hamas's] anti-tank missile unit, Muhammad A'sar".<ref>{{Cite news |last=Al-Mughrabi |first=Nidal |last2=Williams |first2=Dan |last3=Al-Mughrabi |first3=Nidal |date=2023-11-01 |title=Israel says new strike on Gaza refugee camp kills second Hamas leader, first evacuees reach Egypt |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-military-jets-strike-gaza-camp-says-hamas-commander-killed-2023-11-01/ |access-date=2023-11-02}}</ref>
+
+== Reactions == 
 Norwegian doctor [[Mads Gilbert]] stated, "There is absolutely no doubt that this is a mass murder."<ref>{{cite web |title='Stop this mass killing': Doctor says US and Europe need to step in |url=https://aje.io/93du7y?update=2451919|website=Al Jazeera |access-date=31 October 2023}}</ref> Melanie Ward, the chief executive of the UK-nonprofit [[Medical Aid for Palestinians]], stated, "This attack marks a new low and should serve as a wake-up call to world leaders and politicians everywhere. Their meek requests for compliance with international law are being ignored entirely; Israel has instead increased the ferocity of its indiscriminate and disproportionate attacks."<ref>{{cite web|title=Jabalia attack ‘should be wake-up call’ to world leaders, non-profit group says |url=https://aje.io/93du7y?update=2452831 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=31 October 2023}}</ref> [[Doctors Without Borders]] condemned the airstrike, stating "Enough is enough!"<ref>{{cite web |title=MSF says ‘horrified’ by Jabalia refugee camp strike |url=https://aje.io/93du7y?update=2452781 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=31 October 2023}}</ref>
