@@ -84,5 +84,5 @@
 At the time of the attack, Israel and Saudi Arabia were conducting [[Arab–Israeli normalization|negotiations to normalize relations]]. Saudi Arabian crown prince [[Mohammed bin Salman]] said normalization was "for the first time real".<ref name="nyt7oct">{{#invoke:cite news||last1=Kingsley |first1=Patrick |last2=Kershner |first2=Isabel |date=7 October 2023 |title=Israel-Gaza Conflict: Gaza and Israel on War Footing After Militants Launch Surprise Assaults |url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/10/07/world/israel-gaza-attack |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231007075901/https://www.nytimes.com/live/2023/10/07/world/israel-gaza-attack |archive-date=7 October 2023 |access-date=7 October 2023 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> According to US President [[Joe Biden]] and Secretary of State [[Antony Blinken]], the aim of the 7 October attacks was to disrupt the normalization talks.<ref>{{#invoke:cite news||title=Hamas attack aimed to disrupt Saudi-Israel normalization, Biden says |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/hamas-attack-aimed-disrupt-saudi-israel-normalization-biden-2023-10-20/ |access-date=15 January 2024 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=21 October 2023}}</ref>
 
-As of 7 February 2024, Saudi Arabia confirmed that diplomatic relations with Israel requires an independent Palestinian state on 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/saudi-arabia-says-there-will-be-no-diplomatic-relations-with-israel-without-an-2024-02-07/|title=Saudi Arabia: no Israel ties without recognition of Palestinian state &#124; Reuters}}</ref>
+As of 7 February 2024, Saudi Arabia confirmed that diplomatic relations with Israel requires an independent Palestinian state on 1967 borders with East Jerusalem as its capital.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/saudi-arabia-says-there-will-be-no-diplomatic-relations-with-israel-without-an-2024-02-07/|title=Saudi Arabia: no Israel ties without recognition of Palestinian state &#124; Reuters|website=[[Reuters]] }}</ref>

-On 1 January 2024, Israeli forces withdrew from neighbourhoods in North Gaza, including Sheikh Radwan, al-Mina district and parts of Tel al-Hawa.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bassam |first1=Laila|last2=Al-Mughrabi|first2=Nidal |last3=Barbakh |first3=Arafat |title=Israeli drone kills Hamas deputy leader in Beirut -Lebanese, Palestinian sources|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/fighting-rages-gaza-israel-looks-new-phase-war-2024-01-01/|work=[[Reuters]]|date=3 January 2024}}</ref> On 6 January, the Israeli government claimed that Hamas control over the northern part of the Gaza Strip had been dismantled.<ref>{{#invoke:cite news||url=https://www.scmp.com/news/world/middle-east/article/3247544/israel-army-says-hamas-command-structure-dismantled-north-gaza |title=Israel army says Hamas command structure 'dismantled' in north Gaza |work=[[South China Morning Post]] |date=7 January 2024}}</ref> On 15 January, Israeli Defense Minister [[Yoav Gallant]] stated that the most intense fighting in the northern part of the Gaza Strip had ended, and a new phase of low intensity fighting was about to begin.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/world/middle-east/palestinian-attack-in-central-israel-kills-one-woman-injures-16-israeli-police-say-c39f4e10?siteid=yhoof2&yptr=yahoo|title="Israeli Military Near End of Most Intense Phase of Gaza Fighting, Defense Minister Says" ''Wall Street Journal'', Jan. 15, 2024}}</ref>

 Even before the war, 2023 was the deadliest year for Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank in 20 years. From 7 to 31 October, B'Tselem said that Israeli forces had killed more than 100 Palestinians while Israeli settlers had killed at least seven, leading to fears that the situation would escalate out of control.<ref name="Tharoor-2023"/> About 1,000 Palestinians have been forcibly displaced by settlers since 7 October and almost half of clashes have included "Israeli forces accompanying or actively supporting Israeli settlers while carrying out the attacks" according to a U.N. report.<ref>{{#invoke:cite news||last1=Abi-Habib |first1=Maria |last2=Nazzal |first2=Rami |date=30 October 2023 |title=Settler Violence Against Palestinians in the West Bank Is Rising |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/30/world/middleeast/west-bank-settlers-palestinians-violence.html}}</ref> According to the West Bank Protection Consortium, which is funded by the European Union, since the 7 October attacks six Palestinian communities have been abandoned due to the violence.<ref>{{#invoke:cite news||last=Loveluck |first=Louisa |date=9 November 2023 |title=Settler violence is erasing Palestinian communities in the West Bank |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2023/11/09/west-bank-israel-settlers-violence/ |access-date=10 November 2023 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref>

@@ -21,15 +21,14 @@
 |causes=[[2023 Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip|Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip]], airstrikes, and limitation of aid}}
 
-The [[Gaza Strip]] is experiencing a severe [[famine]] as a result of the [[Israel–Hamas war]]. The famine has resulted from Israeli airstrikes that have destroyed food infrastructure, such as bakeries and flour mills, and a widespread scarcity of essential supplies.{{efn|The Israeli NGO [[Btselem]] has stated the famine is a direct outcome of Israeli policy: "This reality is not a byproduct of war, but a direct result of Israel’s declared policy. Residents now depend entirely on food supplies from outside Gaza, as they can no longer produce almost any food themselves. Most cultivated fields have been destroyed, and accessing open areas during the war is dangerous in any case. Bakeries, factories and food warehouses have been bombed or shut down due to lack of basic supplies, fuel and electricity."<ref name="Israel is starving">{{cite web |title=Israel is starving Gaza |url=https://www.btselem.org/gaza_strip/20240108_israel_is_starving_gaza |website=[[B'Tselem]] |access-date=17 January 2024|date=8 January 2024}}</ref>}} This has left over half a million Gazans on the brink of starvation and is part of a broader [[Gaza humanitarian crisis (2023–present)|humanitarian crisis]] in the Strip.
+The [[Gaza Strip]] is experiencing a severe [[famine]] as a result of the [[Israel–Hamas war]]. The famine has resulted from Israeli airstrikes that have destroyed food infrastructure, such as bakeries and flour mills, and a widespread scarcity of essential supplies.{{efn|The Israeli NGO [[Btselem]] has stated the famine is a direct outcome of Israeli policy: "This reality is not a byproduct of war, but a direct result of Israel's declared policy. Residents now depend entirely on food supplies from outside Gaza, as they can no longer produce almost any food themselves. Most cultivated fields have been destroyed, and accessing open areas during the war is dangerous in any case. Bakeries, factories and food warehouses have been bombed or shut down due to lack of basic supplies, fuel and electricity."<ref name="Israel is starving">{{cite web |title=Israel is starving Gaza |url=https://www.btselem.org/gaza_strip/20240108_israel_is_starving_gaza |website=[[B'Tselem]] |access-date=17 January 2024 |date=8 January 2024 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref>}} This has left over half a million Gazans on the brink of starvation and is part of a broader [[Gaza humanitarian crisis (2023–present)|humanitarian crisis]] in the Strip.
 
-Human rights groups have accused Israel of using [[starvation]] as a method of warfare. The limited entry of aid trucks has exacerbated the famine, prompting experts to label it as one of the worst instances of man-made starvation in nearly a century.<ref name="Looming Starvation in Gaza">{{cite news |last1=Nolen |first1=Stephanie |title=Looming Starvation in Gaza Shows Resurgence of Civilian Sieges in Warfare |work=The New York Times |date=11 January 2024 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/11/health/gaza-israel-hunger-starvation.html |access-date=14 January 2024 |archive-date=13 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240113173728/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/11/health/gaza-israel-hunger-starvation.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
+Human rights groups have accused Israel of using [[starvation]] as a method of warfare. The limited entry of aid trucks has exacerbated the famine, prompting experts to label it as one of the worst instances of man-made starvation in nearly a century.<ref name="Looming Starvation in Gaza">{{cite news |last1=Nolen |first1=Stephanie |title=Looming Starvation in Gaza Shows Resurgence of Civilian Sieges in Warfare |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=11 January 2024 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/11/health/gaza-israel-hunger-starvation.html |access-date=14 January 2024 |archive-date=13 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240113173728/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/11/health/gaza-israel-hunger-starvation.html |url-status=live}}</ref>
 
 ==Background==
-It has been argued that 'thoroughly planned impoverishment' had been a longterm policy of Israel for the Gaza Strip.<ref name="Howard-Hassmann, p.127">Howard-Hassmann, ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 p.127.</ref> {{efn|According to [[Sara Roy]], a leading expert on the Gazan economy, ‘The current desecration of Gaza is the latest stage in a process that has taken increasingly violent forms over time. In the fifty-six years since it occupied the Strip in 1967, Israel has transformed Gaza from a territory politically and economically integrated with Israel and the West Bank into an isolated enclave, from a functional economy to a dysfunctional one, from a productive society to an impoverished one. It has likewise removed Gaza’s residents from the sphere of politics, transforming them from a people with a nationalist claim to a population whose majority requires some form of humanitarian aid to sustain themselves.’<ref name="Roy">{{cite web|title= The Long War on Gaza |last =Roy| first =Sara|author-link =Sara Roy |url=https://www.nybooks.com/online/2023/12/19/the-long-war-on-gaza/ |publisher=[[The New York Review of Books]] |access-date=18 January 2024|date=19 December 2023}}</ref>}} As early as 2000 Israel had banned imports of cooking fuel and gas.<ref>Howard-Hassmann, ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 p.126.</ref>   8,000 settlers spread over 25% of the Strip had exclusive use of 40% of Gaza’s arable land and most of its water.<ref>Rhoda E Howard-Hassmann, [https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/State_Food_Crimes/3LTDDAAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1 ''State Food Crimes,''] [[Cambridge University Press]] 2016 {{isbn|978-1-107-13352-5}} p.125.</ref> After [[Israeli disengagement from Gaza|Israel withdrew its colonies]] from the [[Gaza Strip]] in 2005,  [[2006 Palestinian legislative election|Palestinian elections]] were held in 2006, which Hamas won. Israel, declaring both the political party Hamas and Gaza itself a "hostile entity",<ref>Ron Smith, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/45406228 'Israel's Permanent Siege of Gaza,']
- [[Middle East Report]], No. 290, Spring 2019, pp.38-42, p.39.</ref> moved to set in place a [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip|blockade]], [[2006–2007 economic sanctions against the Palestinian National Authority|economic sanctions and restrictions]] which aimed to weaken Hamas's rule in the Gaza Strip. [[Dov Weissglas]] explained, "We have to make them much thinner, but not enough to die,"<ref>Trude Strand, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1525/jps.2014.43.2.6 ''Tightening the Noose: The Institutionalized Impoverishment of Gaza, 2005–2010,''] [[Journal of Palestine Studies]], Vol. 43, No. 2 (Winter 2014), pp. 6-23 p.10.</ref> the idea being "to put the Palestinians on a diet, but not to make them die of hunger."<ref>Conal Urquhart, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/apr/16/israel 'Gaza on brink of implosion as aid cut-off starts to bite,']  [[The Guardian]] 16 April 2006.</ref> Prior to the blockade, Gaza's population stood at 1,6 million, serviced by 400 trucks carrying goods into the Strip every day. Under the new policy, according to the Israeli [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]]  [[Gisha (human rights organization)|Gisha]], Israel permitted only 106 trucks entry to deliver goods.<ref name="Reuters2012" /> To obtain permission to import any commodity into the Strip, proof had to be supplied that they were indispensable.<ref>Filiu, 2014 p.57.</ref>
+It has been argued that 'thoroughly planned impoverishment' had been a longterm policy of Israel for the Gaza Strip.{{sfn|Howard-Hassmann|2016|p=127}}{{efn|According to [[Sara Roy]], a leading expert on the Gazan economy, 'The current desecration of Gaza is the latest stage in a process that has taken increasingly violent forms over time. In the fifty-six years since it occupied the Strip in 1967, Israel has transformed Gaza from a territory politically and economically integrated with Israel and the West Bank into an isolated enclave, from a functional economy to a dysfunctional one, from a productive society to an impoverished one. It has likewise removed Gaza's residents from the sphere of politics, transforming them from a people with a nationalist claim to a population whose majority requires some form of humanitarian aid to sustain themselves.'<ref name="Roy">{{cite web |title=The Long War on Gaza |last=Roy |first=Sara |author-link=Sara Roy |url=https://www.nybooks.com/online/2023/12/19/the-long-war-on-gaza/ |publisher=[[The New York Review of Books]] |access-date=18 January 2024 |date=19 December 2023}}</ref>}} As early as 2000 Israel had banned imports of cooking fuel and gas.{{sfn|Howard-Hassmann|2016|p=126}} 8,000 settlers spread over 25% of the Strip had exclusive use of 40% of Gaza’s arable land and most of its water.{{sfn|Howard-Hassmann|2016|p=125}} After [[Israeli disengagement from Gaza|Israel withdrew its colonies]] from the [[Gaza Strip]] in 2005, [[2006 Palestinian legislative election|Palestinian elections]] were held in 2006, which Hamas won. Israel, declaring both the political party Hamas and Gaza itself a "hostile entity",{{sfn|Smith|2019|p=39}} moved to set in place a [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip|blockade]], [[2006–2007 economic sanctions against the Palestinian National Authority|economic sanctions and restrictions]] which aimed to weaken Hamas's rule in the Gaza Strip. [[Dov Weissglas]] explained, "We have to make them much thinner, but not enough to die,"<ref>Trude Strand, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1525/jps.2014.43.2.6 ''Tightening the Noose: The Institutionalized Impoverishment of Gaza, 2005–2010,''] [[Journal of Palestine Studies]], Vol. 43, No. 2 (Winter 2014), pp. 6-23 p.10.</ref> the idea being "to put the Palestinians on a diet, but not to make them die of hunger."<ref>Conal Urquhart, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/apr/16/israel 'Gaza on brink of implosion as aid cut-off starts to bite,'] [[The Guardian]] 16 April 2006.</ref> Prior to the blockade, Gaza's population stood at 1,6 million, serviced by 400 trucks carrying goods into the Strip every day. Under the new policy, according to the Israeli [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] [[Gisha (human rights organization)|Gisha]], Israel permitted only 106 trucks entry to deliver goods.<ref name="Reuters2012" /> To obtain permission to import any commodity into the Strip, proof had to be supplied that they were indispensable.{{sfn|Filiu|2014|p=57}}
 
-Diplomatic cables subsequently published by [[WikiLeaks]] revealed that Israel had informed the United States in 2008 that, while it would take measures to prevent a humanitarian crisis, it intended to keep Gaza's economy on the "brink of collapse".<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE7041GH/ 'Israel said would keep Gaza near collapse: WikiLeaks,'] [[Reuters]] January 5, 2011</ref> Precise calculations were made to determine the minimum  calorific requirement (2,279 calories per person a day) to avoid malnutrition in the Gaza Strip, and these formed the basis for Israel's determination of the truck numbers for food supplies from 2007 to 2010.<ref>The French historian of Gaza [[Jean-Pierre Filiu]] commented:'The fact that Israel could feel empowered to decide how much a Palestinian could eat on a daily basis shows how perverse and degrading the post-2005 occupation of the Gaza Strip had become.'Filiu 2014 p.57.</ref><ref name="Reuters2012" >[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSBRE89G0NM/ 'Israel Gaza blockade study calculated Palestinians' calories,'] [[Reuters]] 17 October 2012</ref><ref>[[Associated Press]], [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/17/israeli-military-calorie-limit-gaza 'Israel used 'calorie count' to limit Gaza food during blockade, critics claim,'] [[The Guardian]] 12 October 2012</ref> The calculation excluded factors such as the collapse of agriculture due to the blockade which dried up access to seed markets.<ref name="Howard-Hassmann, p.127"/>{{efn|The complicated procedures for obtaining clearances from Israel at the transit points also caused notable spoilage further reducing the food allowed in. Prospective import goods had to arrive in Israeli trucks, which were unloaded as the goods were transferred to 'neutral' trucks that then were allowed transit to the Gaza side. Once there, the consignments had to be unloaded from the neutral trucks and reloaded on Gazan trucks.<ref name="State Food Crimes">{{cite book |title=State Food Crimes |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=3LTDDAAAQBAJ  |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |access-date=18 January 2024|year=2016 |page =127| isbn=978-1-107-13352-5 }}</ref>}} Restrictions on foodstuffs included basic commodities like pasta, -that particular item was reintroduced after [[John Kerry]] protested at its inclusion in the list of banned imports- and any delicacies, such as honey, sesame snack [[halvah]], [[Bamba (snack)|bamba]],{{efn|A peanut-butter flavoured corn snack, prohibited because, according to one Israeli official, 'We don't want [[Gilad Shalit]]'s captors to be munching Bamba right over his head".'<ref>Alex Renton, [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2009/jun/16/gaza-blockade-israel-food 'No gourmets in Gaza,'] [[The Guardian]] 16 June 2009</ref>}} tea, coffee, sausages, semolina, milk products in large packages, most baking products and limitations on meat and domestic cooking gas.<ref>Renton, 2009</ref>
+Diplomatic cables subsequently published by [[WikiLeaks]] revealed that Israel had informed the United States in 2008 that, while it would take measures to prevent a humanitarian crisis, it intended to keep Gaza's economy on the "brink of collapse".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE7041GH/ |title=Israel said would keep Gaza near collapse: WikiLeaks |work=[[Reuters]] |date=5 January 2011 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> Precise calculations were made to determine the minimum calorific requirement (2,279 calories per person a day) to avoid malnutrition in the Gaza Strip, and these formed the basis for Israel's determination of the truck numbers for food supplies from 2007 to 2010.<ref>{{harvnb|Filiu|2014|p=57}}: "The fact that Israel could feel empowered to decide how much a Palestinian could eat on a daily basis shows how perverse and degrading the post-2005 occupation of the Gaza Strip had become."</ref><ref name="Reuters2012" >{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSBRE89G0NM/ |title=Israel Gaza blockade study calculated Palestinians' calories |work=[[Reuters]] |date=17 October 2012 |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref><ref>[[Associated Press]], [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/oct/17/israeli-military-calorie-limit-gaza 'Israel used 'calorie count' to limit Gaza food during blockade, critics claim,'] [[The Guardian]] 12 October 2012</ref> The calculation excluded factors such as the collapse of agriculture due to the blockade which dried up access to seed markets.{{sfn|Howard-Hassmann|2016|p=127}}{{efn|The complicated procedures for obtaining clearances from Israel at the transit points also caused notable spoilage further reducing the food allowed in. Prospective import goods had to arrive in Israeli trucks, which were unloaded as the goods were transferred to 'neutral' trucks that then were allowed transit to the Gaza side. Once there, the consignments had to be unloaded from the neutral trucks and reloaded on Gazan trucks.{{sfn|Howard-Hassmann|2016|p=127}} }} Restrictions on foodstuffs included basic commodities like pasta, -that particular item was reintroduced after [[John Kerry]] protested at its inclusion in the list of banned imports- and any delicacies, such as honey, sesame snack [[halvah]], [[Bamba (snack)|bamba]],{{efn|A peanut-butter flavoured corn snack, prohibited because, according to one Israeli official, 'We don't want [[Gilad Shalit]]'s captors to be munching Bamba right over his head".'<ref>Alex Renton, [https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2009/jun/16/gaza-blockade-israel-food 'No gourmets in Gaza,'] [[The Guardian]] 16 June 2009</ref>}} tea, coffee, sausages, semolina, milk products in large packages, most baking products and limitations on meat and domestic cooking gas.<ref>Renton, 2009</ref>
 
-The [[Goldstone Report]] discovered that during the [[Gaza War (2008–2009)|2008-2009 Gaza War]], Israel’s invasion had caused  deliberate and massive destruction of Gaza’s agricultural sector.{{efn|The agricultural sector, including crop farming, fisheries, livestock farming and poultry farming, suffered direct losses worth some US$ 170 million. Indirect losses have still to be definitively calculated. One business organization estimates that 60 per cent of all agricultural land had been destroyed, 40 per cent directly during the military operations.  Moreover, 17 per cent of all orchards, 8.3 per cent of livestock, 2.6 per cent of poultry, 18.1 per cent of hatcheries, 25.6 per cent of beehives, 9.2 per cent of open fields and 13 per cent of groundwater wells were destroyed. Agriculture had already lost a third of its capacity since the start of the second intifada and the frequent Israeli incursions, according to NGO estimates used by UNDP-Gaza . . Some 250 agricultural wells were reportedly destroyed or severely damaged.<ref>Howard-Hassmann , ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 p.127</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Human Rights in Palestine and Other Occupied Arab Territories: Report of the United Nations Fact-Finding Mission on the Gaza Conflict |last=Goldstone |first =Richard|author-link= Richard Goldstone|url= https://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/docs/12session/a-hrc-12-48.pdf |website=[[United Nations Human Rights Council]] | pages =261–262 |access-date=18 January 2024|date=25 September 2009 }}</ref>}}   Israel also declared 30% of the most arable land in the Strip [[No-go areas|no-go zones]]. After 2012, the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] secured an agreement to allow Gazan farmers to cultivate crops of various heights, in areas respectively at 300 metres to 1 kilometre from Israel's [[Gaza–Israel barrier|fortified border fence]]. Both cultivators and their rudimentary irrigation devices nonetheless were often exposed to sniping and automated machinegun fire, and crops along the armistice line were, without warning, sprayed by [[Monsanto]]'s [[Roundup (herbicide)|Roundup herbicide]].<ref>Ron Smith, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/45406228 'Israel's Permanent Siege of Gaza,'] [[Middle East Report]], No. 290, Spring 2019 pp.38-42 pp.39-40.</ref> Likewise, Israel placed severe restrictions on fishing within Gaza's waters — the 20 nautical miles agreed to under the [[Oslo Accords]] were unilaterally reduced to nine — with fishable areas demarcated with buoys.<ref>[[Jean-Pierre Filiu]], [https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.1525/jps.2014.44.1.52 'The Twelve Wars on Gaza,'] [[Journal of Palestine Studies]] Vol. 44, No. 1, SP Autumn 2014  pp.52-60 p.56.</ref> In 2009 Israel further reduced this to a 3 nautical mile limit with the result that 85% of Gaza's fishing water was blocked by Israeli warships.<ref>Howard-Hassmann, ''State Food Crimes,'' 2016 pp.125-127.</ref> Israel gunships reportedly fired on local fishermen even within these areas.<ref>Ron Smith, 2019 p.40</ref>
+The [[Goldstone Report]] discovered that during the [[Gaza War (2008–2009)|2008-2009 Gaza War]], Israel’s invasion had caused deliberate and massive destruction of Gaza’s agricultural sector.{{efn|The agricultural sector, including crop farming, fisheries, livestock farming and poultry farming, suffered direct losses worth some US$ 170 million. Indirect losses have still to be definitively calculated. One business organization estimates that 60 per cent of all agricultural land had been destroyed, 40 per cent directly during the military operations. Moreover, 17 per cent of all orchards, 8.3 per cent of livestock, 2.6 per cent of poultry, 18.1 per cent of hatcheries, 25.6 per cent of beehives, 9.2 per cent of open fields and 13 per cent of groundwater wells were destroyed. Agriculture had already lost a third of its capacity since the start of the second intifada and the frequent Israeli incursions, according to NGO estimates used by UNDP-Gaza . . Some 250 agricultural wells were reportedly destroyed or severely damaged.{{sfn|Howard-Hassmann|2016|p=127}}<ref>{{cite web |title=Human Rights in Palestine and Other Occupied Arab Territories: Report of the United Nations Fact-Finding Mission on the Gaza Conflict |last=Goldstone |first=Richard |author-link=Richard Goldstone |url=https://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/docs/12session/a-hrc-12-48.pdf |website=[[United Nations Human Rights Council]] |pages=261–262 |access-date=18 January 2024 |date=25 September 2009}}</ref>}} Israel also declared 30% of the most arable land in the Strip [[No-go areas|no-go zones]]. After 2012, the [[International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement|Red Cross]] secured an agreement to allow Gazan farmers to cultivate crops of various heights, in areas respectively at 300 metres to 1 kilometre from Israel's [[Gaza–Israel barrier|fortified border fence]]. Both cultivators and their rudimentary irrigation devices nonetheless were often exposed to sniping and automated machinegun fire, and crops along the armistice line were, without warning, sprayed by [[Monsanto]]'s [[Roundup (herbicide)|Roundup herbicide]]. {{sfn|Smith|2019|pp=39–40}} Likewise, Israel placed severe restrictions on fishing within Gaza's waters — the 20 nautical miles agreed to under the [[Oslo Accords]] were unilaterally reduced to nine — with fishable areas demarcated with buoys{{sfn|Filiu|2014|p=56}} In 2009 Israel further reduced this to a 3 nautical mile limit with the result that 85% of Gaza's fishing water was blocked by Israeli warships.{{sfn|Howard-Hassmann|2016|pp=125–127}} Israel gunships reportedly fired on local fishermen even within these areas.{{sfn|Smith|2019|p=40}}

Full stop."<ref name="DeYoung Hudson 2024 g056">{{cite news | last1=DeYoung | first1=Karen | last2=Hudson | first2=John | title=Despite U.S. pressure on Israel, casualty count in Gaza remains high | newspaper=Washington Post | date=15 January 2024 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2024/01/14/israel-gaza-low-intensity/ | access-date=19 January 2024}}</ref>
+The IDF has alleged Hamas stole humanitarian aid;<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ynetnews.com/article/bydb7zgit |title=IDF releases video of Hamas stealing aid from Gazans |newspaper=Ynet News |date=December 9, 2023 |author=Einav Halabi |accessdate= January 19, 2024}}</ref> killed people seeking humanitarian aid;<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.jpost.com/israel-hamas-war/article-781286 |title=Gazans to IDF: Hamas steals UNRWA food, kills civilians who ask for aid |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=January 8, 2024 |author= |access-date=January 19, 2024}}</ref> and keeps its own supply reserves.<ref name="TI">{{cite web |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/arab-western-officials-agree-hamas-keeping-gaza-food-fuel-for-itself-ny-times/ |title=Arab, Western officials agree Hamas is keeping Gaza food, fuel for itself - NY Times |newspaper=Times of Israel |date=October 28, 2023 |author= |accessdate= January 19, 2024}}</ref> The U.S. and the UN both denied Israeli claims that Hamas plays a significant role in causing the famine, with a senior U.S. official stating that "the Israeli government has not brought to the attention of the U.S. government… any specific evidence of Hamas theft or diversion of assistance provided via the U.N. and its agencies. Full stop."<ref name="DeYoung Hudson 2024 g056">{{cite news |last1=DeYoung |first1=Karen |last2=Hudson |first2=John | title=Despite U.S. pressure on Israel, casualty count in Gaza remains high |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=15 January 2024 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2024/01/14/israel-gaza-low-intensity/ |access-date=19 January 2024}}</ref>

 ==Famine==
 On 3 January 2024, Arif Husain, the chief economist at the World Food Programme, stated 80 percent of all people in the world experiencing famine or catastrophic hunger were in the Gaza Strip, stating, "In my life, I’ve never seen anything like this in terms of severity".<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Chotiner |first1=Isaac |title=Gaza Is Starving |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/q-and-a/gaza-is-starving |magazine=The New Yorker |date=3 January 2024 |access-date=4 January 2024 |archive-date=4 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240104000711/https://www.newyorker.com/news/q-and-a/gaza-is-starving |url-status=live }}</ref> Food prices rose in Gaza as food stock ran out.<ref>{{cite web |title=Action Against Hunger calls for permanent ceasefire in Gaza |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/action-against-hunger-calls-permanent-ceasefire-gaza#:~:text=Food%20stocks%20are%20running%20low,Palestinian%20Central%20Bureau%20of%20Statistics. |website=ReliefWeb | date=2 December 2023 |publisher=Action Against Hunger |access-date=5 January 2024}}</ref>
 
-The United Nations humanitarian chief [[Martin Griffiths]] stated on 5 January 2024, "People are facing the highest levels of food insecurity ever recorded."<ref>{{cite web |title=World News in Brief: Gaza relief 'an impossible mission', COVID spreading fast again, food prices fall |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2024/01/1145327#:~:text=People%20are%20facing%20the%20highest,hostage%20in%20Gaza%2C%20he%20added. |website=UN News | date=5 January 2024 |publisher=United Nations |access-date=5 January 2024 |archive-date=5 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240105202255/https://news.un.org/en/story/2024/01/1145327#:~:text=People%20are%20facing%20the%20highest,hostage%20in%20Gaza%2C%20he%20added. |url-status=live }}</ref>   Experts warned that the famine in the Gaza Strip was the worst instance of man-made starvation in nearly 100 years.<ref name="Looming Starvation in Gaza"/> [[António Guterres]] stated, "The long shadow of starvation is stalking the people of Gaza".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Guterres |first1=António |title=Secretary-General's statement to the press on the Middle East |url=https://www.un.org/sg/en/content/sg/speeches/2024-01-15/secretary-generals-statement-the-press-the-middle-east#:~:text=The%20long%20shadow%20of%20starvation,law%20that%20we%20are%20witnessing. |website=United Nations |access-date=16 January 2024}}</ref>

-On 16 January, [[UNOCHA]] reported 378,000 people in Gaza were in IPC Phase 5, or catastrophic levels of hunger.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hostilities in the Gaza Strip and Israel Flash Update #94 |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/hostilities-gaza-strip-and-israel-flash-update-94 |website=ReliefWeb |date=17 January 2024 |publisher=UNOCHA |access-date=17 January 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Over one hundred days into the war, Israel destroying Gaza’s food system and weaponizing food, say UN human rights experts |url=https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/01/over-one-hundred-days-war-israel-destroying-gazas-food-system-and |website=OHCHR |publisher=United Nations |access-date=24 January 2024}}</ref> It reported all 2.2 million people in the Gaza Strip were facing acute food insecurity – the highest proportion of a population experiencing starvation in recorded history.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Regan |first1=Helen |title=Hundreds of thousands are starving in Gaza as famine arrives at 'incredible speed,' UN aid chief warns |url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/01/16/middleeast/gaza-famine-starvation-un-israel-war-intl-hnk/index.html# |website=CNN |date=16 January 2024 |access-date=17 January 2024}}</ref> The  Famine Review Committee (FRC) which compiled the Gaza data on famine in terms of the  [[Integrated Food Security Phase Classification]] (IPC) on December 1, 2023, forecast that the total population will be at Phase 3 by 7 February and that 25% or 500,000 Gazans will reach Phase 5.<ref name="B'tselem" />

 ===Humanitarian aid===
 {{see also|Humanitarian aid during the Israel–Hamas war}}
-On 9 January, [[Gisha (human rights organization)|Gisha]] reported that only 6,000 aid trucks had entered Gaza since 7 October, the equivalent of twelve days of aid before the conflict's start.<ref>{{cite web |title=Just 6,000 aid trucks enter Gaza over past three months: Israeli group |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/8/israel-war-on-gaza-world-must-look-says-wael-dahdouh-as-son-killed?update=2604624 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=9 January 2024 |archive-date=9 January 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109012358/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/8/israel-war-on-gaza-world-must-look-says-wael-dahdouh-as-son-killed?update=2604624 |url-status=live }}</ref> Colonel Moshe Tetro, who heads the Israeli unit overseeing deliveries of humanitarian aid, stated that there was no food shortage in Gaza and that existing reserves are sufficient.<ref name="Burke" /> Another Israeli official stated, "Don't forget that this is an Arab, Gazan population whose DNA is to hoard, certainly when it comes to food."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gontarz |first1=Nir |title=Half a Million Gazans Are Suffering From Acute Hunger. Let That Sink In |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2024-01-12/ty-article-magazine/.highlight/half-a-million-gazans-are-suffering-from-acute-hunger-let-that-sink-in/0000018c-fd57-d517-af9d-fd7f19b10000 |website=Haaretz |access-date=17 January 2024}}</ref>

-Officials stated that the worsening crisis was partly attributable to the limited amount of aid being allowed into Gaza, with [[Cindy McCain]] stating, "People in Gaza risk dying of hunger just miles from trucks filled with food".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Khaled |first1=Mai |last2=Saleh |first2=Heba |title=‘We’ve all lost weight’: the desperate struggle to find food in Gaza |url=https://www.ft.com/content/e8b98b73-e8c5-4543-82a5-362a93c6cec1?shareType=nongift |website=Financial Times |access-date=22 January 2024}}</ref> Arif Husain, the WFP chief economist, stated on 24 January that only between 20 and 30 percent of needed aid was entering Gaza,<ref>{{cite web |title=WFP official says 20 to 30 percent of needed aid entering Gaza |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/23/israels-war-on-gaza-ground-shaking-in-hospital-amid-israeli-attacks?update=2643549 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=24 January 2024}}</ref> as UNOCHA accused Israel of "systematically denying" humanitarian assistance into northern Gaza.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tétrault-Farber |first1=Gabrielle |title=Risk of 'pockets of famine' in Gaza, World Food Programme says |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/little-aid-reaching-gaza-prompting-risk-pockets-famine-wfp-2024-01-23/ |website=Reuters |access-date=24 January 2024}}</ref>

@@ -32,5 +32,5 @@
 On 17 October 2023, an [[explosion]] took place in the parking lot of the courtyard of [[al-Ahli Arab Hospital]] in [[Gaza City]] during the [[2023 Israel–Hamas war]], resulting in a large number of fatalities and injuries.
 
-The hospital, along with the entire northern part of the Gaza Strip, had received evacuation orders from Israel four days earlier. At the time of the explosion, many displaced Palestinians were taking refuge at the hospital. Reports of the number of fatalities vary widely, with the total still unknown. The [[Hamas]]-run [[Gaza Health Ministry]] initially reported a figure of over 500 deaths, before revising the count to 471. The Anglican Diocese that manages the hospital believes 200 people died in the explosion, while the U.S. intelligence agencies assessed a death toll between 100 and 300. 
+The hospital, along with the entire northern part of the Gaza Strip, had received evacuation orders from Israel four days earlier. At the time of the explosion, many displaced Palestinians were taking refuge at the hospital. Reports of the number of fatalities vary widely, with the total still unknown. The [[Hamas]]-run [[Gaza Health Ministry]] initially reported a figure of over 500 deaths, before revising the count to 471. The Anglican Diocese that manages the hospital believes 200 people died in the explosion, while U.S. intelligence agencies assessed a death toll between 100 and 300. 
 
 The cause of the explosion is contested. Israel, the United States, France, the United Kingdom, and Canada said that their intelligence sources indicate the cause of the explosion was a failed [[Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel|rocket launch]] by the [[Palestinian Islamic Jihad]] (PIJ) from within Gaza, while the PIJ has denied any involvement. Hamas said that [[Israel]] carried out an [[airstrike]] on the hospital. Experts largely agreed that a misfired rocket launched from within Gaza was the likely cause of the explosion based on video analysis and the extent of the damage caused by the impact.

@@ -379,9 +379,11 @@
 
 For the first time the United Nations officially commemorated the [[Nakba]]. The event was attended by many member states from Asia, Africa, Central and South America and the Middle East including the majority of EU member states. The US and United Kingdom did not send a representative. The Israeli UN Ambassador called the event despicable, false and anti-Semitic while the Israeli foreign minister accused the Palestinians of spreading lies and distorting history. In his speech, the Palestinian president said that more than 1,000 UN resolutions concerning Palestinians had never been implemented and suggested that Israel should have its UN membership suspended.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/15/world/middleeast/palestine-displacement-israel-un.html|title=In First, Palestinian Displacement Commemorated at United Nations|first1=Farnaz|last1=Fassihi|first2=Hiba|last2=Yazbek|date=15 May 2023|work=The New York Times|access-date=16 May 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=The U.N. is marking the 75th anniversary of Palestinians' displacement|url=https://www.npr.org/2023/05/15/1176097958/un-nakba-day-explained-anniversary-palestine-israel|work=NPR|first1=Emma|last1=Bowman|first2=Daniel|last2=Estrin|access-date=16 May 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/palestinians-nakba-united-nations-israel-abbas-13a80a94426c6a54e557c69071bc88b1|title=Abbas urges UN to suspend Israel during first commemoration of 1948 flight of the Palestinians|date=15 May 2023|website=AP News|first=Edith M.|last=Lederer|access-date=16 May 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-05-16/ty-article/.premium/despite-israeli-pleas-most-eu-states-attend-uns-nakba-day/00000188-2483-d18b-a79d-24db84dd0000|title=Despite Israeli Pleas, Most EU States Attend UN's Palestinian Nakba Event|work=Haaretz|first=Amir|last=Tibon|date=16 May 2023|access-date=17 May 2023}}</ref>
+
 === 18 May ===
 The heavily-policed parade of Israel's Jerusalem Day passed without serious violence. The United States and the United Nations subsequently condemned anti-Arab slogans chanted during the event by overwhelmingly male Orthodox teens and young men.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-hamas-jerusalem-march-gaza-6058a191644b6bde5366a40d7f736590|title=Israeli crowds chant racist slogans, taunt Palestinians during Jerusalem march|date=18 May 2023|website=AP NEWS|first=Ilan|last=Ben Zion}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/us-un-condemn-anti-arab-chants-jerusalem-march-2023-05-19/|title=US and UN condemn anti-Arab chants at Jerusalem march|first=James|last=Mackenzie|date=19 May 2023|work=Reuters|access-date=20 May 2023}}</ref>
 
 === 19 May ===
-OCHA issued the Protection of Civilians Report covering the period 2–15 May 2023. During the reporting period, 45 Palestinians (139 year to date) were killed by Israeli forces and 1 Israelis (18 year to date) were killed by Palestinians. There were 124 Israeli military search and arrest operations in the West Bank (1405 year to date), and 44 Palestinian-owned structures were demolished (340 year to date including 96 in East Jerusalem). There were 33 attacks on Palestinians by Israeli settlers (385 year to date).<ref>{{Cite web|title=Protection of Civilians Report {{!}} 2-15 May 2023|url=https://www.ochaopt.org/poc/2-15-may-2023|website=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs - occupied Palestinian territory|date=19 May 2023 }}</ref>
+OCHA issued the Protection of Civilians Report covering the period 2–15 May 2023. During the reporting period, 45 Palestinians (139 year to date) were killed by Israeli forces and 1 Israelis (18 year to date) were killed by Palestinians. There were 124 Israeli military search and arrest operations in the West Bank (1405 year to date), and 44 Palestinian-owned structures were demolished (340 year to date including 96 in East Jerusalem). There were 33 attacks on Palestinians by Israeli settlers (385 year to date).<ref>{{Cite web|title=Protection of Civilians Report {{!}} 2–15 May 2023|url=https://www.ochaopt.org/poc/2-15-may-2023|website=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs - occupied Palestinian territory|date=19 May 2023 }}</ref>
+

 === 19 June ===
 Israel shortened the procedure of approving settlement construction and gave Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich the authority to approve one of the stages, changing the system operating for the last 27 years. The United States said it was "deeply troubled" by the Israeli plans that explicitly violate previous commitments made by Israel to the Biden administration. "The United States is deeply troubled by the Israeli government’s reported decision to advance planning for over 4,000 settlement units in the West Bank. We are similarly concerned by reports of changes to Israel’s system of settlement administration that expedite the planning and approvals of settlements". Tor Wennesland, United Nations Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process urged a halt and reversal of the decisions and said "I am deeply concerned by the Israeli Government’s decision yesterday to alter settlement planning procedures that have been in place since 1996, which is expected to expedite settlement expansion. I am also alarmed by the anticipated advancement next week of over 4,000 settlement housing units by Israeli planning authorities". The Israeli press reported that the US has informed Israel that the Negev forum on regional cooperation will be postponed as a result of the Israeli moves.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-06-19/ty-article/.premium/israeli-government-gives-pro-settler-minister-control-over-west-bank-settlement-planning/00000188-d147-d52d-adef-f54f66db0000|title=U.S. ‘Deeply Troubled’ by Israeli Settlement Plans That Violate Commitment to Biden|via=Haaretz}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/18/world/middleeast/israel-west-bank-settlements-rules.html|title=Israel Eases West Bank Settlement Rules, Clearing Way for New Homes|first=Isabel|last=Kershner|date=18 June 2023|work=The New York Times|access-date=19 June 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newarab.com/news/us-postpones-negev-summit-over-new-israel-settlement-plans|title=US postpones Negev Summit over new Israel settlement plans|date=19 June 2023|website=The New Arab|access-date=19 June 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-west-bank-settlements-smotrich-1f16401de915559965e906f70269908b|title=Israeli government gives settler minister control over West Bank settlement planning|date=18 June 2023|website=AP NEWS|first=Ilan|last=Ben Zion|access-date=19 June 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=UN Special Coordinator concerned about Israel's decision to alter settlement planning|url=https://english.wafa.ps/Pages/Details/136369|publisher=WAFA}}</ref>

 Israeli forces killed a 24-year-old Palestinian near the village of Umm Safa according to Palestinian health ministry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-07-07/ty-article/.premium/palestinian-killed-from-israeli-army-fire-in-west-bank/00000189-30b1-df82-a78f-75b3aa3a0000|title=24-year-old Palestinian Killed by Israeli Army Gunfire in West Bank|via=Haaretz}}</ref>

 === 8 July ===
 OCHA issued the Protection of Civilians Report covering the period 13 June–4 July 2023. During the reporting period, 32 Palestinians (177 year to date) were killed by Israeli forces and 5 Israelis (24 year to date) were killed by Palestinians. There were 139 Israeli military search and arrest operations in the West Bank (1800 year to date), and 41 Palestinian-owned structures were demolished (451 year to date including 129 in East Jerusalem). There were 84 attacks on Palestinians by Israeli settlers (525 year to date).<ref>{{Cite web|title=Protection of Civilians Report {{!}} 13 June – 4 July 2023|url=https://ochaopt.org/poc/13-june-4-july-2023|website=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs - occupied Palestinian territory|date=2 June 2023 }}</ref>
@@ -497,4 +507,5 @@
 === 11 July ===
 Following the rejection of a final appeal, a 45-year-long legal battle ended with the eviction of a Palestinian family from their apartment in Jerusalem’s Old City. Activists say the eviction is part of a wider trend of Israeli settlers seizing property in East Jerusalem while Israel describes it as a real estate dispute. Israeli law allows Jews to reclaim properties owned by Jews before 1948 while there is no equivalent right for hundreds of thousands of Palestinians who fled or were forced from their homes to return to lost properties.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-jerusalem-old-city-evictions-east-c53ae70f2fa76e4b1f4b528bca4ff35e|title='I will not stay quiet': Israel evicts Palestinian family from home after 45-year legal battle|date=11 July 2023|website=AP News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-07-11/ty-article/.premium/palestinian-family-evicted-from-east-jerusalem-home-to-make-way-for-israeli-settlers/00000189-43c7-d9a2-a5af-5bf7264a0000|title=Palestinian Family Evicted From East Jerusalem Home to Make Way for Israeli Settlers|via=Haaretz}}</ref>
+
 === 20 July ===
 A 19-year-old Palestinian was killed during clashes between Israeli troops and Nablus residents that broke out during a visit of thousands of Jewish worshipers, including Israel's police chief Kobi Shabtai, to [[Joseph's Tomb]], heavily accompanied by security forces. Four other Palestinians were wounded by gunfire, and 30 others suffered tear gas inhalation, including a baby and a 12-year-old girl. The IDF reported that Palestinians attacked the group as they entered the city, prompting security forces to respond with crowd dispersal measures and gunfire. The Nablus battalion of the Al-Quds Brigades stated they were fighting against the occupation forces and settlers in the area. Senior police officials criticized Shabtai for the dangerous and unnecessary visit.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Palestinian Killed by Israeli Forces After Rare Visit to Josephs Tomb by Police Chief |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-07-20/ty-article/.premium/palestinian-teen-killed-by-israeli-forces-in-occupied-west-bank/00000189-7083-de6d-a1ef-f5e303bd0000 |via=Haaretz}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last1=Fabian |first1=Emanuel |last2=Staff |first2=ToI |title=Palestinian teen killed in clashes with IDF during pilgrimage to Joseph’s Tomb |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/palestinian-teen-killed-in-clash-with-idf-during-pilgrimage-to-josephs-tomb/ |website=www.timesofisrael.com}}</ref>

 === 5 August ===
 A Palestinian gunman opened fire in central Tel Aviv, killing a 42-year-old Israeli municipal patrol officer before being shot and killed by another officer. The perpetrator was identified as a 27-year-old man from the Jenin area, who had been evading capture in the refugee camp for the past six months. The attack was praised by the Islamic Jihad. The Israeli military prepared the family home of the Palestinian for demolition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-west-bank-tel-aviv-violence-ed24814265413b13db6d83c35ab749a8|title=Israel kills 3 suspected Palestinian militants as West Bank violence shows no signs of slowing|date=6 August 2023|website=AP News|access-date=9 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/one-israeli-critically-injured-tel-aviv-shooting-2023-08-05/|title=Palestinian attack leaves one Israeli dead in Tel Aviv, shooter killed|date=5 August 2023|work=Reuters|access-date=9 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/05/world/middleeast/palestinian-shooting-israel-tel-aviv.html|title=Palestinian Kills Israeli in Tel Aviv, a Day After West Bank Violence|work=The New York Times|first=Patrick|last=Kingsley|date=5 August 2023|access-date=8 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Israeli Patrolman Killed in Shooting Attack in Tel Aviv; Palestinian Assailant Shot Dead |language=en |work=Haaretz|first1=Bar|last1=Peleg|first2=Josh|last2=Breiner|first3=Jack|last3=Khoury|first4=Ben|last4=Samuels|date=5 August 2023|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-08-05/ty-article/israeli-seriously-wounded-in-suspected-shooting-attack-in-tel-aviv/00000189-c665-d9f3-a1cd-f7ffbf3c0000 |access-date=2023-08-06}}</ref>
+
 === 6 August ===
 Israeli forces killed three Palestinian gunmen in a car south of Jenin. The military said the men were on their way to carry out an attack.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-08-06/ty-article/israeli-army-kills-two-palestinians-near-jenin/00000189-cb43-d9f3-a1cd-ffdba95d0000|title=Israeli Army Kills Three Palestinians Near Jenin; IDF Say They Thwarted Attack|work=Haaretz|first=Jack|last=Khoury|first2=Yaniv|last2=Kubovich|date=6 August 2023|access-date=9 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/8/6/israel-forces-kill-3-palestinians-in-occupied-west-bank-attack|title=Israel forces kill three Palestinians in occupied West Bank attack|website=Al Jazeera|date=6 August 2023|access-date=8 August 2023}}</ref><ref name="auto6"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/troops-kill-3-palestinian-gunmen-en-route-to-carry-out-attack-near-jenin-idf/|title=Troops kill 3 Palestinian gunmen en route to carry out attack near Jenin – IDF|website=The Times of Israel|first=Emanuel|last=Fabian|date=6 August 2023|access-date=8 August 2023}}</ref>

 A 17-year-old Palestinian wounded earlier near [[Silwad]], died. IDF sources said that on 2 August the Palestinian threw a firebomb towards Ofra and was shot by Israeli soldiers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-08-07/ty-article/.premium/palestinian-teen-hit-by-israeli-fire-in-west-bank-dies-of-wounds-health-ministry-says/00000189-ce89-d821-afdd-dfad7b080000|title=Palestinian Teen Hit by Israeli Fire in West Bank Dies of Wounds, Health Ministry Says|work=Haaretz|first=Jack|last=Khoury|date=7 August 2023|access-date=9 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Youth, 17, dies of wounds sustained by an Israeli settler’s bullets a few days ago|url=https://english.wafa.ps/Pages/Details/137069|publisher=WAFA|date=7 August 2023|access-date=9 August 2023}}</ref>

 Israeli forces killed a 27-year-old Palestinian militant during a raid on [[Zawata]], west of Nablus. The military said that a Palestinian suspect fired at its troops who returned fire.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinian-killed-army-shooting-678cb2c3f16dd0b4338007ebd4c549ed|title=Israeli forces kill a Palestinian militant in the West Bank, the latest death in a wave of violence|date=10 August 2023|access-date=10 August 2023|website=AP News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-forces-kill-palestinian-militant-west-bank-clash-2023-08-10/|title=Israeli forces kill Palestinian militant in West Bank clash|date=10 August 2023|work=Reuters|access-date=10 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/8/10/israeli-forces-kill-palestinian-man-during-raid-in-occupied-west-bank|title=Israeli forces kill Palestinian man during raid in occupied West Bank|work=Al Jazeera|date=10 August 2023|access-date=10 August 2023}}</ref>

 ===11 August===
 Israeli forces killed a 23-year-old Palestinian militant in during a raid on Tulkarm. The military said Palestinians fired at them and they returned fire.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-west-bank-fighting-e57d9e427ba437f8d959d78dd00c9969|title=An Israeli army raid in the northern West Bank kills a Palestinian militant|date=11 August 2023|website=AP News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-forces-kill-palestinian-wound-eight-west-bank-raid-news-agency-2023-08-11/|title=Israeli forces kill Palestinian, wound eight, in West Bank raid|date=11 August 2023|via=www.reuters.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/8/11/israeli-forces-kill-palestinian-wound-eight-in-occupied-west-bank-raid|title=Israeli forces kill Palestinian, wound eight, in occupied West Bank raid|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref>
 
 OCHA issued the Protection of Civilians Report covering the period 25 July – 7 August 2023. During the reporting period, 11 Palestinians (196 year to date) were killed by Israeli forces and 1 Israeli (26 year to date) was killed by Palestinians. There were 116 Israeli military search and arrest operations in the West Bank (2152 year to date), and 56 Palestinian-owned structures were demolished (626 year to date including 144 in East Jerusalem). There were 20 attacks on Palestinians by Israeli settlers (692 year to date).<ref>{{Cite web|title=Protection of Civilians Report {{!}} 25 July – 7 August 2023|url=https://www.ochaopt.org/poc/25-july-7-august-2023|website=United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs - occupied Palestinian territory|date=2 June 2023 }}</ref>
+
 ===12 August===
 Saudi Arabia named its ambassador to Jordan, Nayef al-Sudairi, as  “nonresident ambassador to the State of Palestine” and also as consul general in Jerusalem for Palestinian engagement in a nod to Palestinian claims in Jerusalem. The move comes amid discussion of a potential normalization of relations between Israel and Saudi Arabia although sources stress this as some way off.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/palestinians-accept-first-saudi-ambassador-2023-08-12/|title=Palestinians accept first Saudi ambassador|date=12 August 2023|via=www.reuters.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/saudi-arabia-appoints-first-envoy-to-palestine-will-also-serve-as-jerusalem-consul/|title=Saudi Arabia appoints its first ever non-resident ambassador to Palestine|first=Jacob|last=Magid|website=www.timesofisrael.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/2023-08-12/ty-article/saudi-arabia-appoints-ambassador-to-the-palestinian-authority/00000189-ea42-d1f1-a5df-ea4ec5cd0000|title=Saudi Arabia Appoints Ambassador to the Palestinian Authority|via=Haaretz}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/927187f1-ae36-482f-8591-a12e3c12c879|title=Saudi Arabia appoints first envoy to Palestinians|first1=Samer|last1=Al-Atrush|first2=James|last2=Shotter|date=13 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/13/world/middleeast/saudi-envoy-palestinians.html|title=Riyadh Appoints Envoy to Palestinians Amid Push for Saudi-Israeli Ties|date=13 August 2023}}</ref>
+
 ===15 August===
 Israeli forces killed two Palestinians, aged 16 and 25, during a raid on the Aqabat Jabr refugee camp. The military said that Palestinians opened fire at them and they returned fire.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-west-bank-raid-9e552961589904c64caf30820cf1a831|title=An Israeli raid in the occupied West Bank kills 2 Palestinians, health officials say|date=15 August 2023|website=AP News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-forces-kill-2-palestinians-raid-west-bank-refugee-camp-says-medical-2023-08-15/|title=Israeli forces kill 2 Palestinians in West Bank raid - medical sources|date=15 August 2023|via=www.reuters.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/2023-08-15/ty-article/.premium/two-palestinians-killed-in-exchange-of-fire-with-israeli-army-in-west-bank/00000189-f782-de6e-a1ff-fffeb2300000|title=Two Palestinians Killed in Exchange of Fire With Israeli Army in West Bank|via=Haaretz}}</ref>
+
 ===17 August===
 Israeli forces killed a 32-year-old Palestinian militant during an arrest raid in Jenin. The military said they came under fire and shot back.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/israel-palestinians-jenin-raid-killed-3cd54687eb1f7b63604f0f4d3d9d80d2|title=Israeli troops kill a Palestinian militant in a gunbattle outside a West Bank bakery|date=17 August 2023|website=AP News}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israeli-forces-kill-palestinian-gunman-west-bank-raid-2023-08-17/|title=Israeli forces kill Palestinian gunman in West Bank raid|date=17 August 2023|via=www.reuters.com}}</ref>

@@ -998,5 +998,5 @@
 
 ===UTS Glenda Adams Award for New Writing===
-The UTS Glenda Adams Award (originally the UTS Award for New Writing) is given for a published book of fiction by an author who has not previously published a work of fiction that is book­length. It was established in 2005, and the winner currently receives a A$5,000 prize from the [[University of Technology, Sydney]].<ref name="utsaward">{{cite web |title= UTS Glenda Adams Award for New Writing |publisher= NSW Premier's Literary Awards |url= http://www.pla.nsw.gov.au/awards-shortlists/uts-glenda-adams-award-for-new-writing |accessdate= 24 January 2012 |year=2012}}</ref> The first recipient was [[Denise Young]], and the most recent recipient was [[Rohan Wilson]] for his novel, ''The Roving Party''<ref>{{cite web|last=State Library of New South Wales|title=2012 NSW Premier's Literary Awards: Winners|url=http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/about/awards/premiers_awards/2012_Literary_award_winners.html|accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref> . No individual has won the Award more than once.<ref name="listofwinners"/> The award renamed in 2008 to honour [[Glenda Adams]], the late Australian novelist.<ref name = adams>{{cite web |title = Message from the Minister |publisher = Arts NSW |url= http://www.arts.nsw.gov.au/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=Gzv6vuJlaTk%3d&tabid=109&mid=598 |accessdate= 2008-03-11}}</ref>
+The UTS Glenda Adams Award (originally the UTS Award for New Writing) is given for a published book of fiction by an author who has not previously published a work of fiction that is book­length. It was established in 2005, and the winner currently receives a A$5,000 prize from the [[University of Technology, Sydney]].<ref name="utsaward">{{cite web |title= UTS Glenda Adams Award for New Writing |publisher= NSW Premier's Literary Awards |url= http://www.pla.nsw.gov.au/awards-shortlists/uts-glenda-adams-award-for-new-writing |accessdate= 24 January 2012 |year=2012}}</ref> The first recipient was [[Denise Young]], and the most recent recipient was [[Rohan Wilson]] for his novel, ''The Roving Party''<ref>{{cite web|title=2012 NSW Premier's Literary Awards: Winners|url=http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/about/awards/premiers_awards/2012_Literary_award_winners.html|accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref> . No individual has won the Award more than once.<ref name="listofwinners"/> The award renamed in 2008 to honour [[Glenda Adams]], the late Australian novelist.<ref name = adams>{{cite web |title = Message from the Minister |publisher = Arts NSW |url= http://www.arts.nsw.gov.au/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=Gzv6vuJlaTk%3d&tabid=109&mid=598 |accessdate= 2008-03-11}}</ref>

And we will continue to document Israel’s crimes and to show our people’s suffering and worries in the Gaza Strip."<ref>{{cite web |title=‘We will continue’: Al Jazeera’s injured correspondent Ismail Abu Omar |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/14/israels-war-on-gaza-live-afraid-to-leave-as-israel-fires-on-hospital?update=2708346 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=16 February 2024}}</ref>
+Abu Omar, an ''Al Jazeera'' journalist severely wounded by an Israeli drone strike in Rafah, stated in February 2024, "We will continue the coverage. And we will continue to document Israel’s crimes and to show our people’s suffering and worries in the Gaza Strip."<ref>{{cite web |title=‘We will continue’: Al Jazeera’s injured correspondent Ismail Abu Omar |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/2/14/israels-war-on-gaza-live-afraid-to-leave-as-israel-fires-on-hospital?update=2708346 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=16 February 2024}}</ref> [[Wael al-Dahdouh]], who lost multiple members of his family and was himself wounded by an Israeli military attack, stated, "Journalists are facing a massacre, a bloodbath in Gaza" and called "for this massacre to stop."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Salam |first1=Yasmine |title=A Palestinian journalist loses another son in an Israeli strike, but vows to keep reporting |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/wael-dahdouh-palestinian-journalist-son-killed-israeli-strike-gaza-rcna132791#:~:text=“Journalists%20are%20facing%20a%20massacre,a%20part%20in%20any%20conflict. |website=NBC News |access-date=16 February 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Yee |first1=Vivian |title=Two More Journalists Killed in Gaza, Including Son of Al Jazeera Reporter |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/07/world/middleeast/journalists-gaza-al-jazeera-reporter-son.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=16 February 2024}}</ref> [[Motaz Azaiza]] stated, "Israel won’t allow international journalists into Gaza and is killing those reporting from within. It is a deliberate attempt to obscure the Palestinian narrative and erase the truth."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Begum |first1=Thaslima |title=Photojournalist Motaz Azaiza: ‘The ghosts of Gaza follow me everywhere’ |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2024/feb/16/motaz-azaiza-interview-gaza-ghosts-photojournalist |website=The Guardian |access-date=16 February 2024}}</ref>

 On 16 January, [[UNOCHA]] reported 378,000 people in Gaza were in IPC Phase 5, or catastrophic levels of hunger.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hostilities in the Gaza Strip and Israel Flash Update #94 |url=https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/hostilities-gaza-strip-and-israel-flash-update-94 |website=ReliefWeb |date=17 January 2024 |publisher=UNOCHA |access-date=17 January 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Over one hundred days into the war, Israel destroying Gaza’s food system and weaponizing food, say UN human rights experts |url=https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/01/over-one-hundred-days-war-israel-destroying-gazas-food-system-and |website=OHCHR |publisher=United Nations |access-date=24 January 2024}}</ref> It reported all 2.2 million people in the Gaza Strip were facing acute food insecurity – the highest proportion of a population experiencing starvation in recorded history.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Regan |first1=Helen |title=Hundreds of thousands are starving in Gaza as famine arrives at 'incredible speed,' UN aid chief warns |url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/01/16/middleeast/gaza-famine-starvation-un-israel-war-intl-hnk/index.html# |website=CNN |date=16 January 2024 |access-date=17 January 2024}}</ref> The  Famine Review Committee (FRC) which compiled the Gaza data on famine in terms of the  [[Integrated Food Security Phase Classification]] (IPC) on December 1, 2023, forecast that the total population will be at Phase 3 by 7 February and that 25% or 500,000 Gazans will reach Phase 5.<ref name="B'tselem" />
 
-On 21 January, a journalist in the Gaza Strip reported that people were making flour using animal food.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gaza hunger: Making flour out of animal food |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/1/21/israels-war-on-gaza-live-deadly-israeli-attacks-across-gaza?update=2637281 |website=Al Jazeera |access-date=22 January 2024}}</ref> On 21 January 2024, the UN reported there were only fifteen bakeries still in operation across the entirety of the Gaza Strip.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hostilities in the Gaza Strip and Israel Flash Update #98 |url=https://www.ochaopt.org/content/hostilities-gaza-strip-and-israel-flash-update-98 |website=UNOCHA |publisher=United Nations |access-date=24 January 2024}}</ref> By 30 January 2024, ''[[CNN]]'' reported that Palestinians were eating grass to stay alive.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Haq |first1=Sana Noor |title=‘We are dying slowly:’ Palestinians are eating grass and drinking polluted water as famine looms across Gaza |url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/01/30/middleeast/famine-looms-in-gaza-israel-war-intl/index.html |website=CNN |access-date=31 January 2024}}</ref>

-On 27 October, the [[United Nations General Assembly]] voted for a [[United Nations General Assembly Resolution ES-10/21|resolution]] calling for an immediate truce.<ref name="auto10">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/oct/27/israel-hamas-war-live-us-strikes-iran-linked-targets-in-syria-eu-calls-for-humanitarian-pauses-in-gaza |title=Israel-Hamas war live: Gaza phone and internet cut off as Israel intensifies attacks |first1=Adam |last1=Fulton |first2=Léonie |last2=Chao-Fong |first3=Ashifa |last3=Kassam |first4=Helen |last4=Sullivan |first5=Adam |last5=Fulton |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=28 October 2023 |access-date=27 October 2023 |archive-date=27 October 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231027052142/https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2023/oct/27/israel-hamas-war-live-us-strikes-iran-linked-targets-in-syria-eu-calls-for-humanitarian-pauses-in-gaza |url-status=live}}</ref> It received 121 votes in favor and 44 abstentions; 14 countries voted no: Israel, the U.S., Austria, Croatia, the Czech Republic, Fiji, Guatemala, Hungary, Marshall Islands, Micronesia, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Paraguay and Tonga.<ref name="auto6">{{Cite news |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2023/10/27/unga-calls-for-humanitarian-truce-in-israel-hamas-war-how-countries-voted |title=UNGA urges humanitarian truce in Gaza: How did your country vote? -Numerous heads of state, government officials and institutions, and international bodies have called for a [[ceasefire]]. On 8 October, [[Moussa Faki Mahamat]], the [[Chairperson of the African Union Commission|Chair]] of the [[African Union Commission|African Union]], called for an end to the conflict and the establishment of a Palestinian state.<ref>{{cite web |title=African Union urges end to Israel-Gaza war |url=https://www.theafricareport.com/324303/african-union-urges-end-to-israel-gaza-war/ |access-date=24 October 2023 |work=The Africa Report}}</ref> On 11 October, Brazilian President [[Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva]] called for a ceasefire, stating, it was "urgently needed in defense of Israeli and Palestinian children".<ref>{{cite news |date=11 October 2023 |title=Brazil's Lula calls for ceasefire, humanitarian intervention in Israel-Palestinian conflict |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/israel-palestinians-brazil/brazils-lula-calls-for-ceasefire-humanitarian-intervention-in-israel-palestinian-conflict-idUSKBN31B1DM |access-date=25 October 2023}}</ref> On 15 October, Venezuelan President [[Nicolas Maduro]] called for an immediate ceasefire.<ref>{{cite news |date=15 October 2023 |title=Venezuela's Maduro speaks to Abbas, condemns Israel's actions |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/venezuelas-maduro-speaks-abbas-condemns-israels-actions-2023-10-15/ |access-date=25 October 2023}}</ref> On 16 October, Pakistani Prime Minister [[Anwar ul Haq Kakar]] called for an immediate ceasefire and the end of the Gaza blockade.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Saifi |first1=Sophia |date=16 October 2023 |title=Pakistan's prime minister calls for ceasefire in Gaza amid nationwide pro-Palestinian rallies |publisher=[[CNN]] |url=https://www.cnn.com/middleeast/live-news/israel-news-hamas-war-10-16-23/h_775a2fd8dadea8032e74513ea2e1676a |access-date=25 October 2023}}</ref> On 18 October, [[Dáil Éireann]] passed a resolution calling for a ceasefire.<ref>{{cite news |last1=O'Leary |first1=Naomi |title=Motion calling for immediate humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza passed in Dáil |newspaper=[[The Irish Times]] |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/politics/2023/10/18/tanaiste-announces-additional-13m-humanitarian-aid-funding-for-palestinians/ |access-date=25 October 2023}}</ref> On 19 October, Chinese President [[Xi Jinping]] stated, "The top priority now is a ceasefire as soon as possible", and called for the establishment of a Palestinian state.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gan |first1=Nector |date=19 October 2023 |title=China's Xi seeks swift end to Israel-Hamas conflict, calls for two-state solution |publisher=[[CNN]] |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/10/19/china/china-xi-israel-hamas-ceasefire-comment-intl-hnk/index.html |access-date=24 October 2023}}</ref>

-Various ambassadors and dignitaries also supported a ceasefire. On 18 October, [[Lana Zaki Nusseibeh]], Ambassador of the United Arab Emirates, stated her country's support for "no less than a full humanitarian ceasefire".<ref>{{cite web |date=18 October 2023 |title=Israel-Gaza crisis: US vetoes Security Council resolution |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2023/10/1142507 |access-date=25 October 2023 |work=UN News}}</ref> On 21 October and during a subsequent UN Security Council meeting on 24 October, UN Secretary-General [[António Guterres]] called for a ceasefire.<ref>{{cite news |date=21 October 2023 |title=UN chief urges ceasefire to end Gaza's 'godawful nightmare' |work=[[France 24]] |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20231021-un-chief-urges-ceasefire-to-end-gaza-s-godawful-nightmare |access-date=25 October 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Fassihi |first=Farnaz |date=24 October 2023 |title=Cease-fire Calls Dominate Fiery U.N. Israeli officials criticized Guterres, with Israeli foreign minister Eli Cohen canceling a meeting and demanding Guterres's resignation.</ref> Russian U.N. Ambassador [[Vassily Nebenzia]] stated, "the whole world" is expecting the UN to call for a ceasefire.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Al-Mughrabi |first1=Nidal |date=25 October 2023 |title=World leaders seek to suspend Israel-Hamas fighting for Gaza aid |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/world-leaders-seek-suspend-israel-hamas-fighting-gaza-aid-2023-10-24/ |access-date=25 October 2023}}</ref> On 29 October, [[Pope Francis]] called for a ceasefire and release of hostages.<ref>{{cite news |date=29 October 2023 |title=Pope calls for Israel-Hamas ceasefire, hostage release |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/pope-calls-israel-hamas-ceasefire-hostage-release-2023-10-29/}}</ref> On 31 October, UN refugee commissioner [[Filippo Grandi]] called for a ceasefire.<ref>{{cite news |title=UN refugee chief: Disregarding the basic rules of war ... is increasingly becoming the norm |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English|Al Jazeera]] |url=https://aje.io/93du7y?update=2452261 |access-date=31 October 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Cassidy |first1=Caitlin |date=November 2023 |title='Ceasefire now': Australian Jewish group holds vigils for peace in Sydney and Melbourne |work=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/01/ceasefire-now-australian-jewish-group-breaks-ranks-with-vigils-for-peace}}</ref>

Haniyeh claims to seek 'political negotiations' |work=[[Times of Israel]] |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/as-idf-advances-in-gaza-hamas-chief-haniyeh-claims-to-seek-political-negotiations/ |access-date=4 November 2023 |archive-date=3 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231103224921/https://www.timesofisrael.com/as-idf-advances-in-gaza-hamas-chief-haniyeh-claims-to-seek-political-negotiations/ |url-status=live }}</ref>{{efn|[[East Jerusalem]] is considered Israeli-occupied Palestinian territory under international law.<ref>{{Cite web |date=23 December 2022 |title=The Illegality of the Israeli Occupation of the Palestinian West Bank (including East Jerusalem) and Gaza: What the International Court of Justice Will Have to Determine in its Advisory Opinion for the United Nations General Assembly |url=http://opiniojuris.org/2022/12/23/the-illegality-of-the-israeli-occupation-of-the-palestinian-west-bank-including-east-jerusalem-and-gaza-what-the-international-court-of-justice-will-have-to-determine-in-its-advisory-opinion-for-th/ |access-date=3 January 2023 |website=Opinio Juris |language=en-US |archive-date=3 January 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230103164733/http://opiniojuris.org/2022/12/23/the-illegality-of-the-israeli-occupation-of-the-palestinian-west-bank-including-east-jerusalem-and-gaza-what-the-international-court-of-justice-will-have-to-determine-in-its-advisory-opinion-for-th/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ochaopt.org/sites/default/files/wb_thematic_9_0.pdf |title=East Jerusalem – OCHA |date=December 2018 |access-date=1 December 2023 |archive-date=28 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231128035628/https://www.ochaopt.org/sites/default/files/wb_thematic_9_0.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref>}} This followed the 1 November statement by Hamas official Ghazi Hamad that Hamas would repeat the 7 October attack time and again until Israel is annihilated.<ref name="LBC_NEWS">{{Cite news |title=We will repeat the October 7 attack time and again until Israel is annihilated, says Hamas official Ghazi Hamad |language=en |url=https://www.lbc.co.uk/news/hamas-october-7-attack-repeat-israel-annihilated-ghazi-hamad/ |access-date=20 November 2023 |archive-date=9 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231109214430/https://www.lbc.co.uk/news/hamas-october-7-attack-repeat-israel-annihilated-ghazi-hamad/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On 3 November, Benjamin Netanyahu stated Israel would not agree to a ceasefire unless Hamas releases all hostages.<ref>{{cite news |date=3 November 2023 |title=Netanyahu says Israel opposes temporary ceasefire unless all hostages are freed |publisher=[[CNN]] |url=https://edition.cnn.com/middleeast/live-news/israel-hamas-war-gaza-news-11-03-23/h_fca09ba45ac58e234925ae089404f90a |access-date=10 November 2023 |archive-date=10 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231110205606/https://edition.cnn.com/middleeast/live-news/israel-hamas-war-gaza-news-11-03-23/h_fca09ba45ac58e234925ae089404f90a |url-status=live }}</ref> On 6 November, both Israel and Hamas rejected calls for a ceasefire.<ref name="Al-Mughrabi">{{cite news |last1=Al-Mughrabi |first1=Nidal |last2=Al-Mughrabi |first2=Nidal |date=6 November 2023 |title=Gaza death toll tops 10,000; UN calls it a children's graveyard |language=en |publisher=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/pressure-israel-over-civilians-steps-up-ceasefire-calls-rebuffed-2023-11-06/ |access-date=1 December 2023 |archive-date=7 November 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231107235020/https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/pressure-israel-over-civilians-steps-up-ceasefire-calls-rebuffed-2023-11-06/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On 15 November, Hamas official Izzat al-Risheq stated Israel was "stalling to continue its aggression and war against defenceless civilians."<ref>{{cite web |title=Israel 'continues to evade, procrastinate' on truce: Hamas |url=https://aje.io/rpfpqc?update=2489693 |access-date=15 November 2023 |publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref>
